title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: Given the recent debate that arose due to the statement by the mayor of Bogotá, Claudia López, on the relationship between migrants and crime in the city, many voices have come out to reject what the president expressed.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: In an interview with EL TIEMPO, Fermín Mármol, a Venezuelan criminal lawyer, university professor and security expert, explained how the migration process of his compatriots has been, rejected the opportunism of politicians who fly nationalist flags that generate xenophobia, but acknowledged that he has There have been criminals who have taken advantage of the diaspora to take their criminal behavior to other countries in the region.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: How has Venezuelan migration been, in your opinion

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: The first thing that is logical to understand is that when a country, whatever it may be, increases its poverty levels and the political system ceases to be republican and democratic, this will generate an exodus of citizens to routes that allow a better future.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: That has happened in all continents and times, and very unfortunately today it is Venezuelas turn.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: Democracy was replaced by revolution and that left deep levels of poverty and a diaspora in three waves.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: Initially from businessmen, industrialists and merchants who wanted to protect their assets and established interests and businesses both in Europe and in other parts of Latin America.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: That was a first wave in 2002.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: Then came a wave of trained professionals from the oil and chemical industry.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: But then there were other types of migrants.We must understand that after 2014 there has been a migration of different waves.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: It was generated that a Venezuelan popular class not classified academically emigrated  not as had been the previous migratory currents, which all did it by air transport, commercial lines, private planes.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: This was an exodus by land, without money, without documents, who were going to earn a living at any cost, and about five years have passed since then.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: In this current there have been people who had debts with the justice system, who were obviously willing to do anything to earn a livelihood, and criminal issues were generated in Ecuador, Peru, Panama, Aruba, Miami, Florida and , of course, in Colombia.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: But these facts are not representative in the figures.They are very specific events.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: When one has studied the statistics, one realizes that they are very specific events if the crime levels of these cities and the number of Venezuelans are taken into account.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: But they have been events that have had a great impact on public opinion because the political factor is involved.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: There are many who have raised the flags of patriotism and nationalism, and that generates xenophobia, and on the other hand, events have occurred that were not common in the daily life of that city or municipality.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: I must say that parallel to this, crime in Venezuela is mostly violent crime.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: We have to say that unfortunately so far in the 21st century, very violent crime has been taking shape and a generation of young men has been formed who saw violent crime as a means of subsistence, and various behaviors have emerged that are worrying the risk of perversity there is a crime that enjoys harming another and, two, heinous crimes, where fury and violence exceed necessity.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: I am very sorry for the politicians who, due to an electoral, circumstantial issue, raise flags that do not distinguish between the good and the bad, but instead stigmatize people based on their nationality.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: We receive Spaniards, Italians, Germans, Colombians, Peruvians, Uruguayans, since before the 70s.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: I understand that crime is persecuted without taking into account nationality, but stigmatizing a group of people generates xenophobia and even more so when we have seen children who are insulted in schools, people who are insulted in a business.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: It has happened in Chile, in Peru, it has already happened in Ecuador.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: Men, women and children who, due to xenophobic signs, have been treated unfairly.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: What structures of violent crime are present in Venezuela

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: From autochthonous ideological structures we have the Venezuelan urban paramilitaries, which we call armed and violent groups.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: Which comes from what was called the Bolivarian circles, urban paramilitaries that call themselves collectives.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: This is a crime structure in urban areas.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: There are also Venezuelan rural paramilitaries, called los Boliches, which are Bolivarian liberation fronts and their factions.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: These are nonideologized violent structures that control territory in Venezuela.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: We will call a megagang a popular zone structure that has more than 100 members, that have grenades and rifles, and that dominate a sector, a population and make a criminal economy flourish.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: We must have some 18 criminal mega gangs that are not ideologized, that are dedicated to drug trafficking, human trafficking, kidnapping and extortion.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: The ELN is also a big problem in Venezuela.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: We did not prepare for Plan Colombia and Democratic Security, a scenario that led a part of the ELN to take refuge in Venezuela.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: But when there are changes here, an institution that is going to fight the ELN in Venezuela, they will want to return to Colombia.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: In addition, we have the FARC dissidents in Venezuela, and the paramilitary dissidents that are the BACRIM.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: It is a very complicated fauna, and all this is possible in Venezuela due to actions and omissions that the public power has allowed.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: In no country that has a robust, serious, strong institutional framework, you can have 92 percent impunity, that out of every 10 crimes only 2 are punished is serious.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: What are the crime figures today in your country

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: There is a very strong opacity on the subject of figures, but what must be said is that 78 percent of violent crimes are committed using a firearm.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: We are not a country of the use of the knife, the blunt object or physical force to produce submission.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: In Venezuela it is very easy to get firearms and ammunition.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: Regarding the homicide, personally I am guided a lot by the Venezuelan Observatory of Violence, I separate myself from the figures of the revolution.

title: ‘It was an exodus to earn a living at any cost’
text: In 2019, the homicide rate was 60.3 per 100,000 inhabitants.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Colombia finished at 25.4 Brazil at 19.7, but well, Venezuela finishes at 60.3, and the closest was Jamaica, with 47.4 percent.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: If isolation or terror of contagion in times of coronavirus is not something easy to handle, imagine all this lived in a foreign country after having been forced by circumstances of scarcity, hunger and desperation to leave behind your land, your family and everything for which you have fought in life.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Being in the middle of nowhere, emptyhanded and not knowing where to call home to comply with a preventive isolation measure is desperate.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: And that is the reality that at this moment does not let Lala Lovera sleep, a woman from Caracas residing in Colombia who is not afraid to raise her voice to remember that if the migratory wave had been difficult, now it is twice as difficult for more than 1825,000 Venezuelans living in the country, a figure revealed in the latest report by Migration Colombia.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: And it is that, according to Lovera, it is as if from one day to the next the long walks, the cold, living on the street, crossing trails, walking kilometers to go to school and all those things that afflict the migrant population had turned into trifles compared to what they are currently experiencing due to a pandemic that took us all by surprise and is changing our lives.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Lets not fool ourselves, the return of Venezuelan migrants is not taking place entirely voluntarily, as has been shown.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: It is being generated as a consequence of fear and the uncertainties that have been generated by this situation, an idea that, she says, makes her itch.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: For this 45yearold woman, the most important thing is to assume and face what is happening with teamwork, which is why she invites each citizen to go beyond the headlines that have appeared in the media talking about the return of Venezuelans to their homeland as a response to covid19 and the socalled lockdowns or mandatory preventive confinements, to understand that these are really mirages that have been formed in the midst of the crisis, hiding the painful life stories of families, young people and children who are being doubly victimized.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: It is a euphemism to hide a painful, dangerous and denaturalizing displacement problem.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: The reality of migration must be integrated and this is a task for civil society as a whole, Lovera mentions in one of his working documents.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: In this way, it ensures that these people have been additional victims of the pandemic and of local measures to contain it, since they have found themselves in a terrifying situation in which confinement has been ordered in homes that, in many cases, they lack. , while surviving the lack of moral and psychological support.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: According to her, added to this is the execrable action of the Venezuelan government, which at any cost wants to propagandize itself and use its migrant nationals as a token in the middle of the posttruth game.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Now that she dedicates her time to the Share for a Life foundation in Colombia (ComparteColombia), Lala Lovera lives between Bogotá and Cúcuta, so she has seen firsthand the faces of need.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Despite the confinement, his work has not stopped.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: He does everything to keep up to date with what is happening there, because each child in the project feels like family.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: He affirms that with the current situation a new hell has appeared, faced by those who have been left with their belongings in the border area and must face armed groups that charge them tolls to return to their country.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Some find themselves with closed borders, others are afraid to make the legal crossing because they do not have the necessary documents and, after crossing, some collide with violent forces from Venezuela who receive them with threats for having left the neighboring country.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: But it is a reality of the fist that few know and that only they suffer.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: That is why we must urgently raise our voices for Venezuelan migrants, adds this woman who warns that although no country was prepared to receive these citizens and children in a state of vulnerability, malnourished, without vaccinations or without a health system , it is important that those who have in their hands the possibility of helping, do so.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: The secret, he argues, could be to get people to understand that it is not a matter of nationality, nor a competition to compare who is worse off or suffers more, but rather that discussions should start from the idea that all human beings have rights regardless of the flag.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: If asked about the panorama of this situation, Lovera describes with concern that the majority of the Venezuelan migrant population in Colombia works informally and is irregular, so the hardest thing at this time has been knowing that they can stay at home because they have neither a roof nor what to eat.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: The situation does not improve for those who live in paydays, since in these places between 12 and 15 people live in the same space, which makes these places a space where an outbreak can easily occur.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: With the aggravating circumstance that the education of minors becomes impossible, since they are children who are in places where connectivity to attend virtual classes is almost impossible.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: We see children with empty bellies, in a state of overcrowding and without access to education, so the lack of all these basic needs that are not met becomes a serious problem, he declares.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Currently, since its foundation, they are advancing care projects in the midst of the crisis for this population in fact, they have just joined Colombia Takes Care of Colombia, the national alliance of more than 240 civil society organizations and the private sector.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Thanks to this we have been able to provide a response by supporting foundations in Bogotá and, articulated in Norte de Santander with the mayors office of Villa del Rosario and Cúcuta, to date we have benefited more than 7,000 people by delivering markets that last 20 days and cover 50 of the necessary intake of the family, he says.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: The verb give is perhaps the most used by Lala Lovera.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: For her, putting it into practice is like entering a twoway highway where both the giver and the receiver learn something by putting themselves in the others shoes.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: She has understood this from a very early age, because this woman, born in Caracas on October 9, 1974, says that since she was young she managed to learn that one should always try to serve others in something and that is why she has made social work her style of life.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: She is the second of three sisters from a family full of women and marked by the strength of a leading grandmother and a fighter mother by nature, who was left alone with her little ones and showed them with facts what it means to be a great mother and successful executive by Same time.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: As a child, when she was invited to work with the disabled community in the Association for the Development of Complementary Education, Asodeco, she began to understand that, when she grew up, she wanted to help others.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Thanks to that experience, she decided to study Special Education in Caracas at the Avepane University Institute and later at the José María Vargas University.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: It was the beginning of a long career in all kinds of jobs as an English teacher in a preschool, coordinator on integration issues with large food chains, director of a kindergarten (which she preferred to close when she was forced to comply with a curriculum full of indoctrination, as part of the new government model of Chávez), and even manager of a beauty salon, a place where he made the manicurists part of the shareholders to show that in these spaces you can also work to generate community.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: On that journey he got married and built his life project hand in hand with the lawyer Laureano Siegmund and their two children.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: However, Venezuela began to get complicated on security issues.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: I didnt understand why we all had to, due to insecurity, get used to living in fear of going out on the street and being kidnapped.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: I always said that the day I had an incident like this, it was going to be time to leave, he recalls.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: One morning, when she was going to the bakery, some motorized vehicles tried to take her away, a consequence of what she describes as the modus operandi of the insecurity in her country.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: My husband eventually traveled to Colombia to work, so I told him Lets go and if your project ends, well go back, with that idea he arrived in Colombia in 2011.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Initially she thought she would take care of her role as a mother 100, but an uncle connected her with Bárbara Escobar, from the Casa de la Madre y el Niño, and she volunteered as a teacher.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: It was a project that I saw grow during the nine years that I worked there, he adds.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: One Friday in 2017, at five in the afternoon, while at the Casa de la Madre y del Niño, five Venezuelan children arrived for protection, accompanied by the Police and the ICBF, who were removed from Ciudad Bolívar because their rights were being violated. .

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: At that moment, she felt that her eyes were opened to a problem in which she had to intervene.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: I found myself with a frightening reality, because although the border area had always been one of coming and going from one side to the other, never had so many young people and children been seen crossing the border to survive on their own, he recalls.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: It was so in January 2018, after seeing a program on television about a rector who received children who walked 15, 18 and 20 kilometers every day from Venezuela to study, that without thinking he took a plane and went to that school to find out how I could help.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: I discover that they are not only Venezuelan children but returnees and I decide to start moving in Bogotá to see who would join me so that we could do something.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Thats where this tireless battle that I have now begins, he adds.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Hand in hand with a movement that was already working from Venezuela and several groups of friends, he set up the Colombia chapter of Share for a Life to assist the between 8,000 and 12,000 children who cross the border every day.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: The project has been changing, as they went from donating milk, shoes and basic necessities to working to activate an entire aid route for intervention in the medium and long term.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: We started with 40 children and we already have 500 little ones.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: We deal with malnutrition and malnutrition with the creation of protective spaces in educational entities, he says.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Each story she has heard has decided to make it part of herself, of her dreams and nightmares, and therefore of her way of acting.

title: The drama experienced by Venezuelan migrants due to the coronavirus
text: Not out of obligation, but because it is clear to her that the only title she is interested in being granted is that of volunteer.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: The rate at which Venezuelan immigrants are arriving in Colombia has doubled in the last two years eight out of ten have a high school education at most, and one out of five is under 11 years of age.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: An analysis carried out by the Universidad del Rosario based on the Dane household surveys found that almost 350,000 Venezuelans settled in the country who have arrived since 2011 have been detected in these surveys.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: The analysis shows the increase in the rate of arrival of people from Venezuela, which raises questions about the pressure both in the labor market and in health and education services.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: According to the study Characteristics of migrants from Venezuela to Colombia, by the Labor Observatory of the Universidad del Rosario, in health, only 36.96 percent of the most recent migrants have access, while among those who arrived between more than two and less than five years, access rises to 71.83 percent.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: Colombia is, therefore, one of the first destinations that Venezuelans have in mind due to aspects such as proximity, the opening of borders that the country has offered them and the ties of family and friendship that unite many, in the exodus exacerbated by the political and social crisis in Venezuela.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: According to the report, the migrants from Venezuela who arrived between 2011 and 2016 are 348,312 people, but almost half  47.11 percent, or 164,086 people  arrived in the last two years, 2015 and 2016.

text: The other 52.89 percent (184,226 people) had migrated more than two years ago and less than six (before 2015 and after 2011).

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: The acceleration of the passage of people in recent years highlights the dramatic dimension of the phenomenon, since in two years as many people migrated as had migrated in the previous four years.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: Juan Carlos Guataquí, leader of the Rosario study, considers that the motivation of this work is to call attention to stop ignoring such a high migratory trend and understand what can happen in Colombia as the situation in Venezuela worsens.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: The fact that in recent days Panama, without having the geographical proximity that we have, has decided to require a visa from Venezuelans is an interesting indicator, added the researcher.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: For him, likewise, these two waves of migrants have different characteristics.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: Those who did it more than two years ago and less than six had better economic conditions compared to those who arrived recently, and over time that human capital may continue to be lower the more the crisis in the neighboring country worsens.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: And here an additional cultural situation must be analyzed and that has a double discourse, according to Guataquí.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: We have carried out studies for the International Organization for Migration (IOM) and the Ministry of Labor on the profile of the work exercise of an occupation, and in Colombia it is very hard to exercise a profession for a foreigner, added Guataquí.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years
text: Most have only reached high schoolThe study indicates that the immigrant population of Venezuela is not precisely characterized by having very high educational levels, since more than 80 percent have a maximum of secondary education.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years

Thus, unemployment for Venezuelans who arrived between 2011 and 2014 is 10 percent, while for those arrived between 2015 and 2016 is 15.7 percent.

title: 350,000 Venezuelans have settled in the country in the last 6 years

title: Pope, hopeful with resolution of crisis on the border
text: Pope Francis said Sunday that the meeting between the bishops of Colombia and Venezuela was a clear sign of hope for a solution to the border dispute between the two nations, which has caused some 16,000 Colombians to leave the country that welcomed them.

title: Pope, hopeful with resolution of crisis on the border
text: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro closed several sectors of the border between the two countries and deported 1,300 Colombians last month, in what he called a blow against smuggling and crime in the border territory.

title: Pope, hopeful with resolution of crisis on the border
text: In these days, the bishops of Venezuela and Colombia have met to examine together the painful situation that has been created on the border between the two countries, the Pope said.

title: Pope, hopeful with resolution of crisis on the border
text: I see in this meeting a clear sign of hope.

title: Pope, hopeful with resolution of crisis on the border
text: I invite everyone, in particular the beloved Venezuelan and Colombian peoples, to pray so that, with a spirit of solidarity and brotherhood, the current difficulties can be overcome, he added.

title: Pope, hopeful with resolution of crisis on the border
text: Francis, the first nonEuropean pope in 1,300 years, asked Catholics to pray for a speedy solution to the dispute, two days after the foreign ministers of Brazil and Argentina visited Bogota in a bid to bring the sides closer together.

title: Pope, hopeful with resolution of crisis on the border

title: This Monday began to operate migration card on the Venezuelan border
text: Starting this Monday, Venezuelans who wish to enter Colombian territory through the seven land crossings that connect these neighboring countries must present their passport or the preregistration document for the new Border Mobility Card (TMF), established by Migración Colombia to regulate the daily entry of 50,000 people through this border area.

title: This Monday began to operate migration card on the Venezuelan border

text: The closure of the ColombianVenezuelan border that has been going on since last August 19 and that, after several critical episodes, left more than 1,500 deportees was one of the news that marked the political agenda of the last months of the year in Colombia and in the neighboring country.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: The arrival of the issue of the Venezuelan crisis and its impact on Colombia at the council of ministers in the Casa de Nariño on Tuesday placed the matter at the level of maximum interest for the government of President Juan Manuel Santos.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: The progressive degradation of respect for life in that country, which increases daily the flow of migrants in search of help, led the high government to review its plan to address the risks of a worsening of the situation.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: On the subject, Foreign Minister María Ángela Holguín spoke with EL TIEMPO.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: What does it mean that the Venezuelan issue has reached the council of ministers

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: It means that it has the highest level of importance within the National Government.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: The President and I have followed up in detail since the Colombian deportee crisis itself, in August 2015, 29 months ago.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: The Ministers of Health and Education have deployed important care measures for the Venezuelan population and, in general, we are permanently assessing the situation so that the actions are well dimensioned, we act with the greatest responsibility for an issue that is not only of the National Government and the Colombian State, but also the country.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: Immigration issues impact us all people, institutions, even companies.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: Many countries have grown positively with a good vision of their migration policies.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: What decisions did the council of ministers make last Tuesday

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: The decisions were to adjust a new phase of the strategy for the application of existing migration controls, update the assessment and projections of the services provided in education, health and other sectors such as those for the protection of children and adolescents.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: This to measure the financial impacts and seek a regulatory framework for the population that achieves higher levels of regularity and, therefore, of contributions of this population in the labor market and the insurance system.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: Also, several measures in terms of security and control of border crossings and nonregular areas of access to our country on the border line, and in the same way the National Risk and Disaster Management Unit was delegated the task of advance a process of logistical and operational prepositioning that, under international humanitarian standards, allows for a response to the current situation.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: A whole package of very important measures that will be announced shortly by the President.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: What is the governments assessment of the situation

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: Here, without a doubt, we are facing a problem that this country had not experienced in its entire history.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: We changed from seeing deported Colombians to a significant flow of Colombians in the process of returning in 2016.

title: 'Venezuelan migration, at the highest level of importance' Chancellor
text: As of 2017, the figures show us that the flows have been reversing and now mainly Venezuelan migrants arrive, 65 percent, according to studies we have done with the United Nations International Organization for Migration.

title: Gradual reopening with Venezuela will be done in five controlled steps
text: The presidents Juan Manuel Santos, of Colombia, and Nicolás Maduro, of Venezuela, took the first steps this Thursday between their countries and put an end to the uncertainty of nearly a year.

title: Gradual reopening with Venezuela will be done in five controlled steps
text: They decided that there will be a gradual reopening of the pass at five border points.

title: Gradual reopening with Venezuela will be done in five controlled steps
text: After a meeting of more than four hours, the two leaders decided to begin a progressive opening of the border area, which had been closed by decision of the Bolivarian Government since August 19 of last year.

title: Gradual reopening with Venezuela will be done in five controlled steps
text: It will be a temporary opening while we learn and we adapt the decisions so that each step we take is accurate and positive, and if we see any problem we will take the precaution of correcting it immediately, Santos explained at the end of the meeting with Maduro.

title: Gradual reopening with Venezuela will be done in five controlled steps
text: For now, the most immediate agreement is the one that will allow the passage on foot of citizens of the two countries, which will be enabled from tomorrow between 5 in the morning and 8 at night, Colombian time.

title: Prostitution networks would be exploiting migrants in Santa Marta
text: The authorities of Santa Marta are behind a network that is dedicated to the sexual and labor exploitation of Venezuelan migrants in the city.

title: Prostitution networks would be exploiting migrants in Santa Marta
text: At least 60 percent of the cases are believed to involve women, 20 percent to LGBT members, and another 15 to children.

title: Prostitution networks would be exploiting migrants in Santa Marta
text: The situation was revealed by the Secretary of Government, Adolfo Bula, who reported that this scourge with which they abuse Venezuelans is especially concentrated in El Rodadero and Santander or Parque de los Novios, forcing them to carry out lowpaid activities. and offer sexual services.

title: Prostitution networks would be exploiting migrants in Santa Marta
text: They are small groups that have organized themselves and take advantage of the needs that Venezuelans suffer in Santa Marta to exploit them, said Adolfo Bula, who explained that the victim, from the moment he enters and without knowing it, is already being a victim and cannot do anything. to avoid it.

title: Prostitution networks would be exploiting migrants in Santa Marta
text: According to the official, these sexual exploitation networks have triggered prostitution in the streets of the capital of Magdalena, especially in tourist sites, where Venezuelans who have been linked to these groups are observed at night, selling their bodies. at low costs.

title: Prostitution networks would be exploiting migrants in Santa Marta
text: The community and business owners are the ones who have been alerting the Police about this problem.

title: Prostitution networks would be exploiting migrants in Santa Marta

title: Prostitution networks would be exploiting migrants in Santa Marta
text: For Bula, with the supposed help that these networks make, they are attacking the human rights of women, children, youth and adolescents, for that reason we are going to work on identifying those who would be behind this scourge so that they are responsible before the Justice.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: Coordinator of the Women and Society group

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: When Venezuelans arrive in Colombia in search of opportunities to live, they encounter another difficult situation xenophobia.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: In recent weeks there have been reports throughout the national territory of acts of discrimination and violence.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: In addition to this, foreigners would also be living in situations of overcrowding and labor exploitation.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: In an interview with a local station in Cundinamarca, Felipe Muñoz, manager of the border with Venezuela, of the Presidency, explained that between 55 and 60 percent of migrants remain in border regions such as La Guajira, Norte de Santander and Arauca. .

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: The others are distributed throughout the rest of the country.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: Muñoz also recalled that on June 8 the migrant registration process will end, for those who have entered the country irregularly.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: It is a free process that can be done in more than 900 points.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: The registry is not to take sanctioning measures, but so that the authorities have clarity regarding the number of migrants in order to provide them with services.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: If people do not register, as of June 8 they will be in an irregular situation and this could have migratory consequences.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: Regarding the issue of combating labor exploitation and the uncertainty that Colombians have regarding sanctions for hiring illegal immigrants, the Government has a series of manuals available to citizens on how to hire Venezuelans.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: For this, registration is also important, since the authorities would be contemplating granting a special permanence permit that would allow these people to work in legal conditions.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: Currently 180 thousand Venezuelans have this permit.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: In the department there are 10 thousand Venezuelans.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: The municipalities where they are most found are Chía and Soacha.

title: The life of Venezuelans in Colombia, between rights and xenophobia
text: On the other hand, in matters of health, the governor of Cundinamarca explained that Venezuelans can already be registered in the Sisben, they have the right to use the emergency medical and vaccination services, and lastly, the care of children and pregnant mothers.

title: Venezuelan citizens invade Santa Marta hills
text: The hills of Santa Marta are being invaded by the Venezuelan population that has built irregularly, putting at risk the houses that are in the lower part in different sectors.

title: Venezuelan citizens invade Santa Marta hills
text: The complaint was brought to the attention of the Mayors Office by several community leaders, who said that with the beginning of the rains small landslides began to appear in several mountains that surround the capital of Magdalena.

title: Venezuelan citizens invade Santa Marta hills
text: The latent danger that currently exists in Santa Marta due to this illegal occupation was confirmed by the municipal director of Risk Management, Jaime Pérez, who stated that the chances of avalanches and landslides occurring are high due to the deforestation of the hills.

title: Venezuelan citizens invade Santa Marta hills
text: Leaders of the Samario Neighborhood Committees confirmed that they are undermining the mountains, which could cause considerable earth movement in the middle of winter with very serious consequences, said Pérez.

title: Venezuelan citizens invade Santa Marta hills
text: The members of the Cobaza have acted preventively by informing the illegal builders, the community and the authorities, however, the problem continues to grow.

title: Venezuelan citizens invade Santa Marta hills
text: According to some residents, new people arrive every night in the lower areas of the hills, mostly Venezuelans, who set up cabins or build zinc houses for two or three families to occupy.

title: Venezuelan citizens invade Santa Marta hills
text: The most worrying thing is that in some cases, it has been identified that those who build are also Colombians, who are taking advantage of the need of migrants to build houses in the mountains without any legal requirement and rent them for 100,000 pesos per month.

title: Venezuelan citizens invade Santa Marta hills
text: The phenomenon is widespread in all the hills, which are running out of their surface mantle that serves as a barrier to prevent landslides, explained the director of Risk Management.

title: Venezuelan citizens invade Santa Marta hills
text: The problem is already in the hands of the Secretary of Government, which scheduled a meeting yesterday, Monday, with the security forces and Migration Colombia to start operations to evict and demolish those properties that have been built illegally on the hills of the capital of Magdalena.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: We also invite you to watch the first chapter of the documentary series Dreams sometimes hurt, in which Naycore Gallando undertakes a long journey to reach Peru

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: The passing of days has shown that it is not easy to deal with Nicolás Maduro.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: The Bolivarian President does not relent in his efforts to assimilate himself more and more to that uncomfortable tenant who does not find a way to annoy his neighbor and against whom there is no authority, conversation or valid reason to make him see reason.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: With many flaws, the Colombian Foreign Ministry has fulfilled a relatively decent role, the fruits of which would be more visible if we were dealing with a normal president, in a regular situation.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: But this is not the case Nicolás Maduro is a basic, rudimentary man, without education or manners, who after falling as a paratrooper in the Miraflores Palace is not aware of the role he must play as the leader of a nation plunged into misery and uncertainty.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: In contrast, the President of Colombia with all his successes and mistakes, with his late moves and his incomprehensible silences is a man who has prepared himself all his life to govern and who values diplomacy as the only valid language between two countries that, as so much has been repeated, they are condemned to understand each other.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: The problem is that Santos diplomatic apparatus has been far surpassed by Maduros propaganda apparatus, as was seen in the OAS vote, in which Colombia lost by one vote the possibility of summoning all the foreign ministers of the continent to discuss the border mess with Venezuela.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: The support obtained from countries as important as Canada, the United States, Mexico or Chile, among others, refutes those who argue that Colombia has been isolated on the international plane.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: However, it is clear that  with the exception of Peru  we cannot expect solidarity from our neighbors, starting with Ecuador, a country with which it is assumed that we had already smoothed things over and that voted against us.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: Undoubtedly, the Foreign Ministry and our ambassador to the OAS sinned by being naive when arriving at the discussion with the scant 18 votes that were required to approve the request, because, after the somersault in Panama, we were left in the hands of Unasur, a scenario handled with a little finger by Maduro, with the approval of the Secretary General, former President Ernesto Samper.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: As was logical, after the plot in Washington, the roles were reversed and the Government of Venezuela, which has always viewed the OAS with disdain, came out to collect its victory and ponder the result of the vote, while the representatives of Colombia country which has always been respectful of the institutional framework  chose to question the role of the entity.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: At this point, the Santos administration should accept that the problem is not the OAS, since that is how it has always worked, but rather the ineffectiveness of our speech, which was not enough to convince the member countries of the seriousness of the humanitarian drama unleashed by Maduro.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: Without digesting the taste of defeat, María Ángela Holguín said that the one that lost was the OAS, for not advancing the debate while others consider that the setback was for the Government.

title: diplomacy vs. the advertising
text: They are all wrong the great loser is not in Washington or Bogotá, but rather on that border that has been turned into a cauldron by an inept and rowdy president who, with an atrocious speech, full of halftruths, expressions of bad taste and highsounding phrases, is far from a lot of the President that a country needs to get out of the deep crisis into which he himself has pushed it.

title: Migrant accused of crimes against the family deported to Venezuela
text: For having taken her 3yearold son from Venezuela to Colombia, without his fathers permission, Migration Colombia expelled in the last few hours the Venezuelan citizen Hilary Verónica Yucleidy Machado, who was wanted by the authorities of that country for crimes against family or child abduction.

title: Migrant accused of crimes against the family deported to Venezuela
text: For a month the woman had a blue circular from Interpol, to facilitate her location and delivery to the country in which she was required.

title: Migrant accused of crimes against the family deported to Venezuela
text: Machado was located by the Colombian authorities in one of the procedures carried out by Migración Colombia on the highways of the department of Norte de Santander.

title: Migrant accused of crimes against the family deported to Venezuela
text: At the time of the arrest, which occurred when the woman and the minor were traveling on board a special service bus, thanks to an alert from the information systems of the Colombian immigration authority, the woman stated that she had registered the minor in Venezuela, without the fathers surnames and hidden from him.

title: Migrant accused of crimes against the family deported to Venezuela
text: She also indicated that four months ago she took the minor out of that country and that her idea was to travel to Ecuador, but that the health emergency had forced her to modify her plans.

title: Migrant accused of crimes against the family deported to Venezuela
text: After being detained, Machado was notified of the expulsion measure against her and transferred to the border, where she handed herself over to the immigration authorities of the neighboring country.

title: Migrant accused of crimes against the family deported to Venezuela
text: In this same verification procedure carried out by Migration on the highways, 69 more Venezuelan migrants were located, 66 adults and three minors, who were traveling on board two buses, one from the city of Montería with 20 occupants and another from Ipiales with 49 passengers.

title: Venezuela the tragedy of having to flee home
text: Those who huddled together were indigent, the vast majority of whom were Venezuelans.

title: Venezuela the tragedy of having to flee home
text: Some of them, I might say a quarter, were dressed in rags, dirty and famished, but still carrying their luggage.

title: Venezuela the tragedy of having to flee home
text: The suitcase is in many cases the unequivocal sign of another life, one that has disappeared, but that keeps its traces in the hair dryer, the shoes, the shirts that give reason for a past.

title: Venezuela the tragedy of having to flee home
text: Path to the origin of the row.

title: Venezuela the tragedy of having to flee home
text: We are in Cúcuta, it is noon, it is almost 40 degrees Celsius and a religious congregation offers food every day to a few hundred hungry people here, in front of the soccer stadium, as in other parts of the city.

title: Venezuela the tragedy of having to flee home
text: A nuns hands reach through a fence to offer a plastic bag with something slimy inside.

title: Venezuela the tragedy of having to flee home
text: And also, a second bag, just as small, carries what one woman describes as a complete meal with grain, rice, even some meat.

title: Venezuela the tragedy of having to flee home
text: The content is hidden behind the white plastic.

title: Venezuela the tragedy of having to flee home
text: Those who do not want to get their hands dirty, open a broken one and suck.

title: Venezuela the tragedy of having to flee home
text: A small group eats slowly on a platform.

title: Venezuela the tragedy of having to flee home

title: They are counting the Venezuelans who arrive in Soacha
text: In the last month, the Mayors Office of Soacha has identified 1,759 Venezuelan families who have registered in the census that the municipality began to carry out to identify the citizens of the neighboring country who came to live in that population.

title: They are counting the Venezuelans who arrive in Soacha
text: The census began to be carried out on April 9 at three service points authorized by the municipality to serve Venezuelan families.

title: They are counting the Venezuelans who arrive in Soacha
text: According to the information compiled to date by officials, most of the people who have registered stated that they arrived in that population since mid2017 and that they would be willing to return to their country once living conditions and economic situation that led them to migrate to Colombia.

title: They are counting the Venezuelans who arrive in Soacha
text: The mayor of Soacha, Eleázar González, reported that this migrant population has been concentrated mainly in commune two, where 712 families have been registered, and in commune 3, with 449.

title: They are counting the Venezuelans who arrive in Soacha
text: These two sectors add up to 1,161 families, most of which have been identified with the census.

title: They are counting the Venezuelans who arrive in Soacha
text: Among the documents that are valid to certify Venezuelan nationality and to be able to register are the foreigners identity card, the passport, the resident, migrant and visitor visa the special residence permit, the border mobility card, the Venezuelan identification number, the birth certificate, the live birth certificate or any Venezuelan document.

title: They are counting the Venezuelans who arrive in Soacha
text: The municipality has asked Venezuelan citizens to come with the entire family nucleus to register each one of them.

title: They are counting the Venezuelans who arrive in Soacha
text: The mayor explained that the aim is to identify the conditions in which they live and what are the needs of the migrants who remain in the municipality, to contribute with the information collected to the formulation of the design of the comprehensive humanitarian care policy that the National Government will use to determine the possible expansion of the institutional offer.

title: They are counting the Venezuelans who arrive in Soacha
text: Venezuelans who have a valid special residence permit, ColombianVenezuelans with a certification of Colombian nationality, or those who have an immigration card or visa or tourism permit will not be included in this census.

title: They are counting the Venezuelans who arrive in Soacha
text: The Mayors Office specified that this census does not grant any type of migratory status nor does it provide authorization to stay or regularize.

title: They are counting the Venezuelans who arrive in Soacha
text: Nor does it replace current travel documents or generate civil or political rights.

title: 88 _ of Venezuelans who have arrived in Colombia plan to stay
text: The balance of the first month of the census of Venezuelans who are irregularly in Colombia showed that there are 203,989 foreigners in the country, of which 88 percent plan to settle in national territory.

title: 88 _ of Venezuelans who have arrived in Colombia plan to stay
text: The panorama, which was presented on Monday by Felipe Muñoz, manager of the Border with Venezuela, and Carlos Iván Márquez, director of the National Unit for Disaster Risk Management (UNGRD), showed that after analyzing the results of the first month of the Administrative Registry of Venezuelan Migrants in Colombia (RAMV), 88 percent of those registered (181,157 people) stated that they intended to settle in the country for a while, although they do not define how long.

title: 88 _ of Venezuelans who have arrived in Colombia plan to stay
text: Of that group of Venezuelans who indicated that they plan to remain in Colombia added Muñoz, 70 percent said that, if the situation improves in their country, they will consider the idea of returning in the medium term, said the manager of the Border with Venezuela.

title: They ask the ICC to investigate Maduro for crimes against humanity_R
text: Venezuelan victims and opponents have submitted a request for the prosecution of the International Criminal Court (ICC) to investigate President Nicolás Maduro and several highranking officials of his country for crimes against humanity, opponent Carlos Vecchio announced Wednesday in Madrid.

title: They ask the ICC to investigate Maduro for crimes against humanity_R
text: Yesterday we formally presented a request for the Court to open a preliminary examination against senior officials, particularly Maduro, because we believe that crimes against humanity have been committed, Vecchio said at a press conference, accompanied by lawyer Juan Carlos Gutierrez.

title: They ask the ICC to investigate Maduro for crimes against humanity_R
text: In The Hague, an ICC source confirmed the filing of the request with the prosecution.

title: They ask the ICC to investigate Maduro for crimes against humanity_R
text: The petition, which has been made on behalf of a group of victims, including Vecchio himself, is directed against a group of eight highranking Venezuelan officials, including Maduro, said the opposition leader, without wanting to give further details about the same for reasons of confidentiality and judicial strategy.

title: They ask the ICC to investigate Maduro for crimes against humanity_R
text: We are convinced that the requirements established by the Rome statute are met to say that we are facing a case of crimes against humanity that have to do with murder, torture, illegal detention, persecution, inhuman treatment, explained Vecchio, coordinator of the Popular Will party of the opposition Leopoldo López.

title: They ask the ICC to investigate Maduro for crimes against humanity_R
text: The petition denounces a systematic, generalized behavior, by the Venezuelan State, of different institutions (.) structurally directed to attack, to produce forceful and effective damage on any focus of dissent or mere criticism of the national government, he explained. Gutierrez.

title: They ask the ICC to investigate Maduro for crimes against humanity_R
text: The report presented to the ICC prosecutors office, which will decide whether to admit carrying out a preliminary investigation, includes the account of more than 30 alleged homicides, 3,700 detentions that the opposition considers illegal, nearly 400 alleged cases of torture, and some 800 people injured, from February 2014 to the present.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: We have formed a team of specialists to care for these cases, since many Venezuelan migrants suffer from this disease, he pointed out.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: The president of Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro, stressed that the border with Colombia will remain closed until minimum conditions are met, which include the capture of the perpetrators of the attack on the Venezuelan military and the dismantling of paramilitary groups in the area.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: In a press conference with international media that focused on the problems with Colombia, Maduro ruled out that in the short term these minimum conditions can be met for the reopening of the border.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: The border will remain closed, gentlemen, until we restore a minimum of coexistence, respect for legality and life, and the economy.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: It will remain closed, whatever they say in Bogotá, in Cúcuta, I dont care what they say about me, Maduro said.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: The Venezuelan president assured that last Thursdays attack on three Venezuelan soldiers and a civilian was not accidental, but an order for which 100 million Colombian pesos were paid behind which are the paramilitaries led by (former president Colombian) Álvaro Uribe, against whom he hopes that there will be international justice.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: Behind the noble people who come to work come the bands of smugglers, of paramilitaries, Maduro said about what he described as a silent paramilitary invasion within the framework of a special plan decreed by Uribe to end the Bolivarian revolution. .

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: Maduro stressed that since the death of his predecessor in office, Hugo Chávez, the conspiracy against Venezuela has worsened and affirmed that in one year they have neutralized products related to smuggling and the hoarding of enough food to satisfy for two months the Venezuelas demand.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: Venezuela is a victim of paramilitarism and drug trafficking, of the capitalist model of the Colombian right, Maduro insisted and wondered how much damage drug trafficking and paramilitarism from Colombia have done to South America.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: The president trusted that the meeting next Wednesday in Cartagena between the foreign ministers of Venezuela and Colombia together with the governors of the affected border areas will be a positive step to build a new, productive, healthy, humane border, respectful of life of the law and of international law.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: The objective of the meeting on Wednesday is to make a deep and dramatic demand because enough is enough.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: Lets take all the evidence of how they train Venezuelans there to come and assassinate Robert Serra, he said, referring to the Chavista deputy assassinated in October 2014 at his home in Caracas.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: And he hoped that in Cartagena the foundations would be laid so that the terrorist dictatorship that paramilitary criminal groups, criminal gangs, smugglers have imposed on the border of both Colombia and Venezuela will be definitively abolished.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: In his opinion, the closure of the border causes great benefits to restructure the area from the serious damage caused by the paramilitaries and smugglers.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: Maduro also stressed the need to limit Colombian immigration to Venezuela and pointed out that his country cant take it anymore, Venezuela is fighting for its dignity, for its development and we cant take it anymore because they are coming in mass exodus.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: And there we have the data, this year 121,000 Colombians have arrived, Maduro insisted before noting, on the other hand, that the price of a barrel of Venezuelan oil today stood at 37 dollars compared to about 100 dollars at which it was quoted. 11 months ago.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: Meanwhile, the Venezuelan president announced that the alleged Colombian paramilitaries involved in the attack on the Venezuelan military have already been identified, and that one of them has been arrested and they are about to capture the rest.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: He explained that for weeks these alleged criminals had been followed up and said that their capture was carried out thanks to the collaboration of all Colombian authorities and President (Juan Manuel) Santos.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: Likewise, Maduro reported the arrest of 10 paramilitaries in the La Invasión neighborhood of the Venezuelan border city of San Antonio del Táchira, where one of the passages to Colombia was closed in an operation where weapons, explosives, paramilitary uniforms and paramilitary insignia.

title: Maduro rules out reopening the border in the short term
text: The president also added a new border municipality to the five in which he declared last Friday a state of emergency for 60 days to combat smuggling and organized crime groups.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: Exultant and happy, a stocky, tall and grayhaired man arrived at one of the few commercial stores open in San Antonio del Táchira after having bought basic necessities in Cúcuta on Sunday.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: He ordered a cold beer, took a sip and exclaimed No foooooooo I bought everything rice, sugar, oil, mayonnaise, tomato sauce, toothpaste, deodorant, toilet paper.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: I spent 100 million bolívares (of the old ones).

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: That amount of money is equivalent to about 250,000 Colombian pesos, he was going to the city of San Cristóbal, one hour from the border by car, with the products in his truck.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: And the best thing, he said, is the way the Colombians treated him.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: In the middle of the bridge with bags of water and medical services ready in case of an emergency, They tell you welcome and from here see you later, thanks for coming and we look forward to seeing you again.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: Because in the midst of the humanitarian crisis that Venezuelans are experiencing, what most impresses them is the cordiality of both the Colombian authorities and Cucuteños.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: As if they have not felt loved for a long time by their government, which denies the scarcity, the crisis and represses them.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: While those here are aggressive, they do not respect, they are corrupt and they want to take away from you what little you get, because I read on (social) networks that this morning in Peracal (the customs office about four kilometers from the border) the military wanted to take away things but people got angry (angry) until they had to let them pass without problems, added this 55yearold man.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: It is not a minor problem for the authorities of that country that three weeks ago people separated the Venezuelan army through Puerto Santander, one hour from Cúcuta, after crossing the bridge, bought and returned, just as mothers of families did two in Ureña, which forced the government of Nicolás Maduro to give free rein to the border the last two weekends.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: People are tired and are demonstrating their power.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: This morning (Sunday) the Guard wanted a line of one person and six blocks were already there, until the crowd, knowing that they had already opened, knocked down the barricades, pushed the Guard aside and went to Colombia, said Isabel Castillo, president of the San Antonio Chamber of Commerce.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: Because if in Venezuelan territory desperation leads them to disobey their own authorities, when they cross the border line they are filled with hope, while Colombians see them with a mixture of satisfaction and sadness.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: Their hope is to buy the basics, the satisfaction of Cucuteños is that they can do it and satisfy their needs for a couple of days, and the sadness of seeing the little money they arrive with, due to unemployment and the devaluation of the Bolivar .

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: Said the owner of the El Triunfo supermarket, in La Parada, the first neighborhood they come across when crossing the Simón Bolívar bridge, It is sad to know that they need everything but the money is not enough for them.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: Almost all of them had to take things out of the shopping baskets and leave them in the register.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: On Saturday afternoon, Mrs. Beatriz exclaimed when crossing the border line from Venezuela Blessed be my God, back in my country

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: And he said that it had been eleven months, since the closure of the border, without seeing his children who live in Cúcuta, that he had not been able to come last Sunday because he had no money, that throughout the week his daughter and soninlaw collected 20,000 bolívares (42,000 pesos) so that he could come and buy.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: The constant is that they need everything, they would like to buy everything, but the devalued bolivars are only enough for an average of 50,000 pesos.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: Because if the crisis in Venezuela shows anything, it is that people travel two hours by car, and some up to five, sleep outdoors on the bridge for a whole night, just to buy a bag of sugar, another of rice, lentils, beans, peas, a bottle of oil, flour, and mainly, toilet paper.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up
text: Toilet paper was the product that passed the most or perhaps the most voluminous.

title: A day with the Venezuelans who crossed the border to stock up

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: Doing so requires complex bilateral state agreements, which we have to promote even if our souls are wounded.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: Violence against children takes many sinister forms.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: In homes, schools, communities it manifests itself in physical and emotional abuse.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: In humanitarian emergencies  especially those driven by unrelenting armed conflict  violence can result in death, serious injury and trauma.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: Another type of violence is when children are deprived of health, nutrition, water, education and other basic needs.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: Thus begins the document Humanitarian Action for Children 2019, a Unicef report that underlines the urgency of protecting children in crisis from all threats to their lives, wellbeing and dignity.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: It should be noted that there are many countries that are in crisis and, in addition to those on this list, that are going through armed confrontations, lack of resources, corruption, human rights violations by the state, among other situations.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: Some of these nations mentioned in the Unicef report are Libya, Ukraine, Bangladesh, Burma, Democratic Republic of the Congo and Ethiopia.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: Every conflict comes with terrible consequences for children, who are always among the most vulnerable.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: In the worst cases, children are at risk of immediate harm from targeted and indiscriminate attacks, as well as abuses such as sexual and genderbased violence, kidnapping, and recruitment into armed forces and groups.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: If we fail to stop these violations, and if the perpetrators are not held accountable, children will grow up to see violence as normal, acceptable, even inevitable, the report says.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: Nearly eight years after the start of the conflict in the Syrian Arab Republic, some 13.1 million people will require humanitarian assistance, including 5.6 million children, 493,000 of whom live in hardtoreach areas.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: In addition, more than 2.5 million Syrian children live as refugees in Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey, where the demand for basic services such as health and education continues to outstrip the capacity of institutions and infrastructure to respond.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: In Afghanistan, an estimated 3.8 million children are in need of protection and humanitarian assistance this 2019 due mainly to violence, natural disasters, including drought, and the harsh winter, which will further undermine families access to basic services.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: The conflict has fueled the humanitarian crisis in Yemen and has been described as the largest emergency in the world with more than 22 million people in need of humanitarian assistance.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: It is estimated that 12 million Yemenis, including 2 million children, will require food assistance this year.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: Nearly 21 million people in Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, the Niger and Nigeria are affected by ongoing conflict.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: In Nigeria, displacement increased in 2018, averaging 4,000 individuals, mainly women and children.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: In Cameroon, nearly half a million people are internally displaced and vulnerabilities continue to deepen.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: In the Central African Republic, 1.5 million children  two out of three in the country  require humanitarian assistance.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: Different countries in Latin America and the Caribbean are hosting at least 2.4 million Venezuelans.

title: Five countries where crises will affect children the most in 2019
text: Refugees and migrants continue in an unpredictable flow that has not allowed the international community to obtain accurate figures of how many families and children are being affected and the exact conditions in which they find themselves.

text: This project is a comprehensive migration policy, which seeks to establish the principles, guidelines, definitions that provide a framework for migration management in the country, which is a public policy in the short, medium and long term, regardless of the government and that this helps coordinate and articulate the different action entities that are aimed at serving the migrant population.

text: Because before migration was a conjunctural phenomenon, but now Colombia has become a receiving country and migrants with a vocation for permanence continue to grow. That is why there are more than 1,731,017 Venezuelans who are in the territory of Colombia.

title: Colombia would have a comprehensive migration policy for the first time
