text: The JEP linked 37 former FARC chiefs to this case, and 14 will begin to render free statements on December 9.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: On the other hand, in a report on conflict events in the first six months of this year, the OAS Mission to Support the Peace Process (MappOEA) recorded that the ELN continues to recruit minors in areas such as Catatumbo, in Norte de Santander, and in municipalities such as Segovia, in Antioquia, Santa Rosa del Sur and Simití, in Bolívar, and Alto Baudó, Bajo Baudó, Bojayá, Riosucio and Juradó, in Chocó.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: The OAS warned that especially in the last two sites, indigenous people are being recruited.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: The agency also registered cases of recruitment by dissidents in San Vicente del Caguán, Cartagena del Chairá and Solano, in Caquetá The Macarena, Meta St. Joseph of the Guaviare and Miraflores, Guaviare Suarez and Corinth, Cauca and Arauca and Arauquita, in Arauca.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: As for last year, the UN report indicated that the main perpetrators of recruitment were the Farc dissidents, with at least 82 children, followed by the Eln, with 69, and the Gulf clan, with 12 cases. .

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: Roberto Menéndez, head of the MappOAS, said that they have detected an increase in the trend of linking minors by all the armed groups and called for them to stop using them in their ranks.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: A local authority from Caquetá, who asked not to be mentioned for security reasons, told EL TIEMPO that after the signing of the peace agreement with the FARC there was more or less a year and a half of tranquility, but since June of last year they began to feel the presence of the socalled dissidents.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: And as of December of last year, children began to be forcibly taken from the rural areas of San Vicente del Caguán, Cartagena del Chairá, Puerto Rico and Solano.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: Regarding how many minors have been recruited, he indicated that there is no exact record or complaints A mother told me that they took her eldest son, 16 years old.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: The boy did not want to leave, and the easy thing was to tell him that if he did not go with them, they would kill his mother.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: In Putumayo, a member of the Catholic Church confirmed that there are more cases than complaints of recruitment.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: Unofficially, it is stated that there are at least 150 minors, many from indigenous communities, who have been recruited in 18 months, between 12 and 17 years old, they said.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: And in Guaviare, a leader from the education sector commented that the alert is mainly in Miraflores and Calamar, where dissidents from the FARCs first and seventh fronts take minors.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: The recruitment alert is in boarding schools, where children are from Sunday afternoon to Friday.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: For six months, each parent has been required to pick them up and take them, because the danger is in sending the minors alone on the way they are taken by force, he said.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: Another worrying fact is that for a few months it has been detected that illegal groups are not only arming Colombian minors, but also that they are using Venezuelan migrant children, as the Ombudsman has warned.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: On the other hand, Martínez pointed out that another serious situation is that recruitment also happens in the cities.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: And he added that some minors who are rescued from their perpetrators end up eventually returning to the areas where their families live and where they were recruited, running the risk of being recruited again.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: While the Government announced, through Francisco Barbosa, Presidential Adviser for Human Rights, the launch of a policy against recruitment on November 19, the fate of the violent minors generated rejection in the country and the international community, which issued pronouncements such as that of the French ambassador in Colombia, Gautier Mignot, who posted on his Twitter account a moving message about the pain of just imagining that his daughter suffered the fate of the dead minors of Caquetá and that she was recruited by force by some illegal armed group, exploited, transformed into a military target with the risk of ending up torn apart by a bombardment, without knowing about it.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: Later, Mignot added Of course, it is a theoretical vision because these things do not happen in France or in the privileged neighborhoods of Bogotá, where we live.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: What is the role of the ICBF

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: The director of the ICBF, Juliana Pungiluppi, explains that the work of this institution in the territories where organized armed groups recruit minors focuses on risk prevention through the generation of protective environments.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: Social mobilization processes are contemplated that seek to raise awareness and distort practices associated with the risk of recruitment, and promote the configuration of life projects, says Pungiluppi.

title: Minors taken to war a crime that still does not stop
text: The official points out that plans are developed that include prevention activities, but above all territorial strengthening, that address the structural roots of illegality in the areas.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: The director recalls that the High Council for Human Rights created a policy to counteract this phenomenon, which will prioritize the areas where the armed groups are concentrated and all those municipalities where the socalled strategic corridors for drug trafficking routes are located. .

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: For two months, when Nicolás Maduro ordered the border closure of the three international bridges of Norte de Santander on February 23, the productive sectors of Cúcuta and its metropolitan area have been shipwrecked in an economic abyss, from which they have been recovering little by little. .

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: Fronts such as supermarkets, currency exchange and cargo transport experienced a drop in sales, which had not been seen since the 2016 border blockade.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: However, other business lines, such as the automotive sector, the sale of gasoline and some household appliances, as is the case of dieselbased electric power generation plants, have reported a rate that is increasing and that, even, shows positive numbers.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: According to the National Federation of Merchants (Fenalco), vehicle registration and car sales increased by 37 percent in March, compared to the same period of the previous year.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: A total of 475 license plates were registered in the city, while 1,467 cars were purchased by Cucuteños.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: Last year only 185 license plates were registered and 572 units were purchased.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: The positive result is due, in the first place, to the restriction of vehicular passage that has been maintained through the overpasses since 2016, and to the operations carried out by the Fiscal and Customs Police, in the irregular crossings, better known as trails, which have left 173 car apprehensions.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: A similar situation occurs at gasoline service stations, which, thanks to procedures against fuel smuggling, have maintained their supply.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: As the situation in Venezuela deteriorates, some sectors have a higher level of crisis, foreign citizens look to the city to provide these products, as happens with food.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: Regardless of the border closure, there is a demand that will remain there, until there is a change in political and economic conditions, said Carlos Luna, director of the Cúcuta Chamber of Commerce.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: The union leader asserts that this economic rhythm is also perceived in a perimeter of the border city, on the seventh avenue with diagonal Santander, where six stores of agricultural machinery sales remain full of migrants, who cross the border and go there to buy dieselbased power plants.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: One of these businesses, which used to sell between 25 and 30 machines of this type monthly, managed to sell nearly 200 in one day.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: Very conjunctural circumstances, such as the energy crisis, have generated a greater acquisition of these mobile generators to be taken.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: This happens throughout the border where this situation is being presented.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: Cúcuta is a city that generates its own dynamics and has elements that mark the commercial rhythm however, a diplomatic effort must be made to normalize the binational passage, Luna asserted.

title: The economic _boom_ in Cúcuta left by the Venezuelan crisis
text: This bonanza occurs to a lesser extent, in supermarkets near the Simón Bolívar and Francisco de Paula Santander international bridges.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: During a visit to the city of Cúcuta last Friday, the nations attorney general, Alejandro Ordoñez, reported that the agency was alerted to a situation in which people, apparently public officials, would be requesting information from citizens. who were deported or returned from Venezuela who are refugees in the shelters of Cúcuta and Villa de Rosario, in Norte de Santander, about the places where they have eventually fulfilled their right to vote.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: Which denotes a great risk of electoral manipulation with the help they may be receiving.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: This is information that we must verify, but we will be very attentive to neutralize those efforts that are open electoral crimes, the Attorney General pointed out.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: Interior Minister Juan Fernando Cristo also spoke about this fact, saying that he is waiting for the complaints to be made with the names of those candidates, political leaders or public servants who are trying to fish in a troubled river.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: If these accusations that have reached the Public Ministry are true, it is a shame, it is unacceptable and all measures will be taken.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: If they are public servants of the National Government, they will be punished as it should be, said the head of the ministerial portfolio.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: Cristo added that having as a precedent that the humanitarian crisis on the border was generated in the middle of the electoral season, the alerts about this type of risk were turned on from the beginning.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: If the complaints and the names of the candidates who are in that activity in the shelters are confirmed, the action of the electoral authorities will be requested.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: Curiously, during all this time we did not have those complaints, when there were more people in the shelters, when the situation was a little more complicated.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: Now that the presence of people in the shelters has been reduced, it would be unfortunate if that situation were to arise, said the Minister of the Interior.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: As reported by the unified command post installed in the border area to coordinate the humanitarian assistance actions of Colombians deported and returned from Venezuela, to date 1,743 people continue to be cared for in the shelters, of the more than 5,600 who have passed through those sites.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: Meanwhile, it has been announced that it is expected that next week the 18 shelters that serve as homes for nationals will be reduced to just one.

title: Officials would be campaigning in shelters for deportees
text: The shelter that will shelter the group of nationals will be located in the city of Cúcuta, in the place where Interferias used to be.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: The process for issuing the permit is free and must be done through the Colombia Migration website.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: More than some kind of balance of what the first 100 days of President Iván Duques government have been, what transcends more clearly are the challenges that the president and his government will have from now on.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: The uncontrollable increase in Venezuelan migration, the tax reform to cover the fiscal gap, the demands of students for more resources for higher public education, the reduction of illicit crops and the expectations of peace, almost all inherited structural problems, are the main challenges that President Duque and his government will have to deal with.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: The situation of the country in the remainder of its mandate will largely depend on what the Duque government does to manage these problems.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: On some of these fronts, Duque has already begun to act.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: For example, he managed to get the international community to commit to managing the increasingly growing Venezuelan migration.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: On another very critical front, such as the expectations of peace, Duque has demanded that the National Liberation Army (ELN) commit to sincere acts of peace such as returning the hostages it has in its power.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: He hasnt sat down at the table with that organization, but he hasnt said he wont either.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: The challenges for Duque, in his 100 days, are just beginning.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: For several weeks, thousands of students have taken to the streets to protest to demand more resources for public higher education.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: The right to protest has already been clouded by acts of vandalism this week, which have made the government think about increasing the penalties against the protagonists of this type of violence.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: On October 23, the students marched in the main cities of the country.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: This October 31 there is a new call.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: But, in addition to seeking the best treatment for the presence of those thousands of students on the streets, the government has the challenge of allocating more resources to education, a claim that has arisen government after government.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: President Duque increased the education budget from 37.5 billion today to 41.4 billion in next years budget.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: The students are demanding 500,000 million pesos for this year, and Duque has said that there is none.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: Figures from experts such as the International Organization for Migration (IOM) and the refugee agency (Acnur), both United Nations entities, speak of more than one million Venezuelan migrants in Colombia.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: The figures are not exact because the phenomenon is very irregular.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: Although the Colombian authorities have carried out censuses on migrants and have regularized more than 400,000 of them, thousands of others continue to enter illegally through the border trails.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: Foreign Minister Carlos Holmes Trujillo recently said, in an EL TIEMPO forum, that in the most critical scenario some 4 million migrants could arrive, which could cost the country some 26 billion pesos.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: Whatever the dimension of the phenomenon, the government of President Duque will have to confront it.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: Colombia will be the country with the most migrants from Venezuela.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: Today it is the nation with the largest number of migrants in the world.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: President Iván Duque is not committed to turning the peace agreement with the guerrillas into shreds, as sectors of his party suggested during the campaign.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: Its challenge is to implement it with some adaptations, and for this purpose it has obtained the support of the international community.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: The success of the reincorporation of thousands of excombatants who handed over their weapons and await their full return to civilian life will depend on the steps your government takes.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: And the achievement of this will largely determine the peace of the country.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: With the National Liberation Army (Eln) it maintains its decision not to advance in any negotiations until this organization makes real peace gestures, such as returning the hostages it has in its power.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: In this demand, President Duque has the support of the international community.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: The government of President Iván Duque will ultimately be responsible for resolving the lack of money to keep the state running.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: In the language of the experts, it will have to remedy the fiscal deficit.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: He is already in opposition to all the parties, including his own (the Democratic Center) and his boss, former president Álvaro Uribe, for the way in which this problem should be resolved.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: Uribe and his party took the lead to tear down the backbone of the tax reform project presented by the Duque government to Congress the VA to the family basket.

title: Challenges that Duque faces in what remains of the government
text: After Uribes warning that he will not vote for the extension of VAT to the entire family basket, and that he will not support tax measures that punish the middle class, the other parties came to support him.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: No one has questioned the substance of the content and the evidence revealed there.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: With white shirts and flags, a group of Venezuelans gathers this afternoon in the El Poblado park in Medellín to protest against the government of Nicolás Maduro and his decision to remove the country from the Organization of American States (OAS).

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: Toni Vitola, coordinator of the Voluntad Popular political party in Medellín, explained that Venezuelans living in 80 cities around the world will unite to support people facing the crisis in their country.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: Vitola explained that since April 4, when the protests began, in the neighboring country, there have been 29 homicides and more than 1,000 detainees.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: Venezuelans abroad will send a message to our brothers who fight every day for change in our country.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: We also reject the abuses by the government of Nicolás Maduro towards them, he stressed.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: In which the citizen of that country, Adriana Galindo, agreed, explaining that Venezuela is so hungry that it has been protesting for almost a month.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: We are against the atrocious things that President Maduro does, for all the dead that go, for this horrible crisis, which has already gotten out of control, he said.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: Galindo affirmed that in addition to the homicides, in Caracas and other cities, people allow themselves to die of hunger, illness and depression, they do not fight because they do not see a light.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: Living in Venezuela is dying, but being alive.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: A friend who is still there told me that they cut off their power and water, that they are killing people, there is no soap, toilet paper or shampoo.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: To all this is added that if your citizenship card ends in 4, you can only buy things on Wednesdays, not the rest of the week, he explained.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: According to figures from Voluntad Popular, there are some 30,000 Venezuelans in Medellín, but every day people cross the border and travel to the capital of Antioquia.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: According to the coordinator, only 8,000 of those have dual nationality.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: In the 70s, 80s and 90s, many Colombians went to Venezuela to look for opportunities, now they and their children are returning, explained Vitola.

title: Venezuelans gather in Medellin to protest against Maduro
text: He also warned that there is a high number of citizens of the neighboring country who have not been able to establish themselves legally because they do not have a work visa, they are on a tourist visa, which lasts three months.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: Venezuelans prefer to sell candies in Medellin than pursue our careers as lawyers, doctors and engineers in our country, Giraldo concluded.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: The Venezuelan humanitarian crisis represents a great opportunity for Latin America to show solidarity with those who suffer from the satrapy of the Chavista regime, but it has also exposed the most ignominious, repulsive and absolutely reprehensible side of some subhumans, who, taking advantage of the citizens need, objectify and it makes him an object of commercial traffic thereby subjugating his human condition in the most extensive meaning of the concept.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: In Peru, in recent days we have witnessed painful incidents that describe how a group of citizens capture, transport and transfer Venezuelan citizens with the aim of prostituting them or subjecting them to labor regimes in absolute job insecurity.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: According to the INEI report, in Peru during 2016, 429 complaints and 1,846 victims were registered, 96 of them women.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: Trafficking in persons as a global criminal figure is not new.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: In Peru, terrorist groups such as the Mrta and Sendero Luminoso, since their creation, found in the kidnapping of minors the way to swell their subversive ranks.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: The FARC or the ELN in Colombia and Islamist movements such as the Nigerian Boko Haram have made Human Trafficking their benchmark for exclusively propaganda purposes to instill terror in the countries where they operate.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: In addition to subversive groups, drug trafficking, illegal mining, informal work, illegal logging and the displacement of citizens fleeing authoritarian and dictatorial regimes are social, economic and political phenomena that promote, facilitate and carry out human trafficking. people.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: In Colombia, for example, the High Council for Human Rights reported that between the period 20122017, 328 cases of human trafficking were registered in that country, with 85 of the victims being women.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: The Global Report on Trafficking in Persons of 2016 cited by the Ombudsman of Peru gives the following data 65 of victims in Central and Southeast Europe were subjected to prostitution, while in South America the percentage reaches 57 .

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: Human trafficking for labor exploitation is alarming in Eastern Europe and Central Asia, reaching 64, followed by SubSaharan Africa at 53.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: Trafficking in persons is a crime that knows no borders, it is a crime that requires the assistance of an organized crime structure where the typical behavior of the active actors consists of capturing, transporting, transferring, hosting, receiving and retaining the victim. .

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: To do this, it uses means such as threats or coercion, kidnapping, payment, abuse of power, deception and even violence against the victim.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: Trafficking in persons has been addressed in the internal legislation of Peru and Colombia.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: In the Peruvian case, Law number 28950 was approved and promulgated, which modified articles 153 and 153A of the Penal Code, which typifies the crime of human trafficking and its aggravating circumstances, in addition to the approval of Supreme Decree number 0072008IN, that approves the Regulation of Law number 28950, on Trafficking in Persons and Illicit Smuggling of Migrants.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: In the case of Colombia we have Law number 985 of August 2005 that modifies article 188 of Law number 599, enacted in 2000.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: Unlike Peruvian legislation, Colombian law adds that (.) the consent given by the victim to any form of exploitation defined in this article shall not constitute grounds for exemption from criminal liability.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: We have pointed out that human trafficking is a crossborder crime, linked to international organized crime.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: Hence, the prevention, investigation, prosecution and criminal sanction in many cases requires the assistance of other administrations in the world, which is why it is necessary to standardize legislation, sign agreements and enter into agreements with other countries that prosecute and punish the crime of trafficking. of people.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: Thus, Peru and Colombia signed on May 25, 2015 the Agreement between Peru and Colombia for the prevention, investigation, prosecution of the crime of Trafficking in Persons and for the Assistance and Protection of its victims, which has the objective of strengthening political and strategic level coordination and cooperation actions between both countries to prevent, investigate and prosecute the crime of trafficking in persons and the assistance and protection of its victims.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: However, it was necessary for the Congress of the Republic of Peru, following the procedure ordered by article 56 and 102 of the Political Constitution of Peru, to approve and incorporate the Agreement into our internal legislation.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: Thus, on May 2, Legislative Resolution Number 30765 was enacted in compliance with the provisions of subsection f., numeral 1 of article 76 of the Regulations of the Congress of the Republic.

title: Peru-Colombia Agreement against human trafficking and Venezuela (Opinion)
text: In this way, Peru and Colombia join forces in their constant and permanent struggle to protect protected legal assets against the threat posed by international organized crime at the extreme of human trafficking.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: The transport sector has reported economic losses of approximately 10,000 million pesos for not being able to mobilize the vehicles that were trapped on Venezuelan soil.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: María Granados, Venezuelan, celebrated her 33rd birthday with the birth of her daughter Sofía.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: It was on February 8 at the Erasmo Meoz public hospital in Cúcuta, a city in northeastern Colombia that borders Venezuela.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: A day later, the mother still has an IV tube connected to her arm and therefore must be very careful when picking up her little girl.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: Despite this difficulty and the crying of the baby, this woman born in Valencia talks with BBC Mundo about a phenomenon that has multiplied dramatically between 2016 and 2017 Venezuelan women who cross the border to receive care, give birth and raise their children. children in Colombia.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: An exodus driven because those who remain in Venezuela face the risk of malnutrition during pregnancy, lack of medication and timely care, insecurity and fear for the future that may await the babies.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: Because she was born in Cúcuta, this little girl will have Colombian nationality.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: And that is something that María Granados had never imagined.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: I would have liked her to be born and live like me, in Venezuela, but I dont think its bad that she was in Colombia, says the mother, while playing with the hands of the newborn.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: Granados says that she always thought she was going to spend her whole life in her native country.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: I think that one is not happy when one is not where one wants, but I am not bad either, indicates María.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: She knows that, from now on, her daughters health will be more important than nostalgia for her land.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: Cúcuta is the epicenter of the arrival of tens of thousands of Venezuelans to Colombia.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: The phenomenon of women crossing the border to give birth is just one of the multiple dimensions of the Venezuelan migration crisis that does not seem to be close to stopping.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: The Simón Bolívar International Bridge, which is located between this city and the Venezuelan city of San Antonio del Táchira, registered an average of 27,000 daily admissions among people who cross the border to stay in Colombia, in transit to other countries, or who enter and they leave permanently.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: In Cúcuta you come across Venezuelans who literally sell everything they can, from rum to their own hair.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: There are those who cross the bridge every day at dawn and return to Venezuela before evening falls with a few pesos in their pockets, and also those who cross the border with several suitcases aware that they will not return to their country for a long time. .

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia
text: Just a few meters after passing the bridge, people can be heard offering oneway tickets to various destinations in Colombia.

title: The Venezuelans who cross the border to give birth in Colombia

title: District creates management to serve Venezuelan migrants in Bogotá

title: District creates management to serve Venezuelan migrants in Bogotá
text: In the midst of this situation and in order to face and attend to Venezuelans in an integral way, Mayor Peñalosa announced the creation of a specialized management, responsible for articulating all the actions of the district entities to guarantee their fundamental rights.

title: District creates management to serve Venezuelan migrants in Bogotá
text: This management, which will be headed by María Angélica Trujillo, will begin to function, like other decisions that are on the way, as of October.

title: District creates management to serve Venezuelan migrants in Bogotá
text: Another of the announcements is the launch of a kind of social supercade in the Salitre terminal, which will deal with social assistance units in such a way that they are provided with firsthand information about services and rights.

title: District creates management to serve Venezuelan migrants in Bogotá
text: There will be, among others, the Social Secretariat and those of Health, Education, Government and Security, to also prevent them from falling into the hands of networks of sexual or labor exploitation.

title: District creates management to serve Venezuelan migrants in Bogotá
text: The general secretary of the mayors office, Raúl Buitrago, specified that this large structure will be designed in the terminal, since it is the point of arrival of the largest number of migrants.

title: District creates management to serve Venezuelan migrants in Bogotá

title: District creates management to serve Venezuelan migrants in Bogotá
text: These decisions, which are added to the creation of four migrant care centers in different parts of the city the first will be in Teusaquillo, and will also come into service next month, were taken due to the number of migrants entering daily to the city.

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: Villegas and Padrino will meet at the Quinta de San Pedro Alejandrino, Santa Marta, where they will talk about smuggling and security issues, among others.

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: Criminal gangs dedicated to drug trafficking and gasoline smuggling, which is bleeding Venezuela dry as well as the difference in prices of basic products between the two nations, which also promote smuggling, are, according to the Colombian and Venezuelan foreign ministries, the main problems on the border between the two nations that today faces the greatest humanitarian crisis in their history.

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: However, there were no pronouncements on urgent and immediate action on this humanitarian crisis.

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: Those were the conclusions delivered, at the end of this Wednesday afternoon, by the foreign ministers of both nations, María Ángela Holguín (Colombia) and Delcy Rodríguez (Venezuela), after a 5hour meeting in Cartagena.

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: Drug trafficking, which affects both countries, and the price of gasoline and other products that are bleeding Venezuela dry, is doing immense damage and we recognize that, said Colombian Foreign Minister María Ángela Holguín, who recalled that the closure of border is not the way to fight organized crime.

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: In humanitarian matters, the only timid announcement, without an execution date, will be the trip of the Colombian Ombudsman, Jorge Armando Otálora, who will travel to the city of San Antonio (Venezuela) accompanied by the Governor of Táchira to accompany the deported Colombians to recover the goods they left behind in Venezuela.

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: There is a lot of legal movement, people who move to both sides of the border, who work and study and who need to be able to continue mobilizing, and we have called on Venezuela to reestablish the border crossing, Holguín added. .

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: Also without set dates, the two foreign ministries promised meetings between the ombudsmen of both countries to establish a bilateral protocol for the deportation of Colombians.

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: On the issue of smuggling, there has been work by the Colombian Fiscal and Customs Police, with the support of the Venezuelan authorities, who have seized merchandise and hydrocarbons and have captured 247 people and withheld almost 47 billion pesos, Foreign Minister Holguín highlighted.

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: The Ministers of Defense and Finance of the two nations will also meet to put an end to the economic, social and security chaos that the border is experiencing.

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: According to the Venezuelan Foreign Minister, Delcy Rodríguez, the situation that exists today on the border is the institutional overflow resulting from the commission of crimes on the borderIn the sister Republic of Colombia there is an important production of drugs and the neighboring countries are affected by their transit, we have also requested the pertinent authorities, the list of demobilized paramilitaries so that we can strengthen joint cooperation in this meaning, said the Venezuelan foreign minister.

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: The attack on the national currency, El Bolívar we have delivered to the Colombian authorities the legal and technical instruments that we have detected that favor the attack on the currency and that favor the smuggling of Venezuelan products into Colombia, added Foreign Minister Rodríguez, to who has not mistreated Colombians by the Venezuelan government.

title: _Closing the border is not the way to fight crime_ Foreign Ministry
text: The official also spoke of media manipulation that has lied to the people of Colombia and the international community about attacks on Colombian citizens.

title: Humanitarian corridor opened for students to cross the border
text: Hand in hand with their parents, hundreds of children arrived at 600 a.m. m. from this Friday to the Simón Bolívar and Francisco de Paula Santander international bridges, where students, including university students, who live in Venezuela and study in Colombian educational institutions, were allowed to cross into national territory through a humanitarian corridor.

title: Humanitarian corridor opened for students to cross the border
text: Last Thursday, in a statement, President Juan Manuel Santos set three conditions to meet with Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro.

title: Humanitarian corridor opened for students to cross the border

title: Humanitarian corridor opened for students to cross the border

title: High flow of migrants has increased the economy on the border
text: The volume of migrants that in these five days has circulated massively through the land crossings between Colombia and Venezuela, which are located in Norte de Santander, has triggered sales on some fronts of the economy of the border city of Cúcuta, where the largest number of citizens fleeing the neighboring country.

title: High flow of migrants has increased the economy on the border
text: When the border was closed in 2016 by order of President Nicolás Maduro, the North Sandanderean capital entered a stage of economic recession that resulted in staff cutbacks and temporary closures of businesses, whose demand depended on customers who crossed the dividing line.

title: High flow of migrants has increased the economy on the border
text: However, a year later and after 11 months of the gradual reopening of the border, some lines of the citys economy, which remains numb due to its high rates of informality and unemployment, experienced a slight increase in demand this week. .

title: High flow of migrants has increased the economy on the border
text: One of the sectors favored by this boom was land transport, whose number of passengers amounted to 20,000, who were dammed up in eThese days in corridors and chairs of the Central de Transporte de Cúcuta.

title: High flow of migrants has increased the economy on the border
text: Due to this high flow of travelers, who spent the night in the streets adjacent to this terminal, a humanitarian dining room was set up to offer a plate of food to those migrants who were waiting their turn to go to their destination.

title: High flow of migrants has increased the economy on the border
text: During this week there was a significant increase in travelers, lowincome people from Venezuela who want to move to other parts of the country.

title: High flow of migrants has increased the economy on the border
text: People without resources, who have lasted three or four days outside the terminal.

text: These foreigners are looking for a way to go to Pasto or Bucaramanga, mainly, said Óscar Sandoval, manager of this transport center.

title: High flow of migrants has increased the economy on the border
text: According to figures from this land port, the increase was represented by 5,000 travelers compared to the 15,000 that are served on average during a week.

title: High flow of migrants has increased the economy on the border
text: The sale of foreign currency has also benefited from this migratory flow from Venezuela, which caused a high traffic of Venezuelan bills, which generated a balance point in the price of the currency in this border area.

title: High flow of migrants has increased the economy on the border
text: Although it has not been possible to establish the figures for this currency buying and selling activity, which was preceded by long lines of Venezuelans seeking to exchange bolivars for Colombian pesos, the Association of Exchange Professionals of Norte de Santander (Ascoambios) is collecting the information between the exchangers of the region to offer a balance.

title: High flow of migrants has increased the economy on the border

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: I thank Colombia for all the support it gives us, both morally and physically, said Gabriel.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: A year after the border between Colombia and Venezuela was closed, the presidents of the two countries, Juan Manuel Santos and Nicolás Maduro, decided this week to reopen it, but also to try to build a new agenda.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: This new moment that the two governments are trying to create will be marked, as a priority, by attention to the migratory issue and the risks of a humanitarian crisis, greater border security, and the reorganization of the binational market, all matters strongly affected by the difficult situation that faces President Maduro.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: The gradual reopening of the border, which began this Saturday at 5 points along the border, became the first bilateral decision for the purpose of normalizing relations.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: A year ago, when the border was closed, it was done by a unilateral decision by President Maduro, who accused Colombian smugglers and paramilitaries of the worst evils.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: In fact, the trigger for the closure was the death of three Venezuelan soldiers, according to Maduro at the hands of paramilitaries, in San Antonio, a Venezuelan town near the border.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: The Venezuelan president also argued that the closure was intended to prevent Colombian smugglers from continuing to loot food subsidized by his government.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: Although the reopening of the border has just been done by agreement of the two leaders, the aspect that had the most influence was the pressure from the Venezuelan side.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: The political, economic and social crisis in Venezuela has led to an unprecedented shortage of basic products for the family basket in that country (flour, oil, sugar, toilet paper and medicines) and Colombia has become the most immediate source for supplying these provisions to the neighboring country.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: The most recent and notorious fact of this crisis was the avalanches of Venezuelans on the city of Cúcuta in search of food, last July, when the two governments authorized the reopening of the border for just a few hours, two weekends.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: Another of the agreements, at the suggestion of Colombia, between presidents Santos and Maduro, was the adoption of the socalled migratory card, a special document authorized to control the passage through the border.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: This document began to facilitate since this Saturday the mobility of the floating population that for different reasons, such as work or study, moves from one side of the border to the other.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: According to Foreign Minister María Ángela Holguín, during the meeting with her Venezuelan colleague, Delcy Rodríguez, this card will contain essential information on the activities of citizens in both countries and will help facilitate coexistence and border crossing.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: This identification can only be carried by the inhabitants of the border municipalities.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: With the migratory border transit card, not only is the passage between Colombia and Venezuela facilitated for the inhabitants of the border points, but the document will also serve the country to keep the population identified, we will be able to have control of who is in the border and who is entering and leaving, said Christian Krüger, director of Migration Colombia.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: The governor (e) of La Guajira, Jorge Enrique Vélez, assured that in his department the card will be very important, especially for the Wayú community, to be able to have an identification and a census of how many people are part of this indigenous community.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: The immigration document will be valid from now on in all border departments.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: Regarding economic matters, the two governments are aware of the need to strengthen trade, which fell to the lowest levels in history, for which it will be necessary to rebuild trust.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: Venezuela became the second commercial partner of Colombia to the point that the commercial exchange between the two nations reached 8,000 million dollars at the beginning of the 2000s.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: According to the latest reports from Dane, so far this year bilateral trade barely reaches 500 million dollars.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: The fall of the ColombianVenezuelan market was precipitated, fundamentally, by the difficult management of foreign exchange imposed by the Venezuelan government, which left businessmen without the possibility of paying the debts contracted with Colombian producers.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: Although Caracas has said for several years, after meetings of its presidents, that it will speed up the payment of debts to Colombian businessmen, this week it reiterated that promise.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: One of the most important issues for Colombia is border security.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: And between the working groups of the two governments, the security group has also advanced in formulations.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: The Minister of Defense, Luis Carlos Villegas, has been one of the forerunners in the creation of a binational center for the fight against international or transnational crime, which has already been finalized.

title: The new agenda of Colombia and Venezuela after reopening the border
text: Although the issue of peace has only been stated, it is also part of the binational agenda.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: On the last day of registration, which was June 8, the day at the Personerías headquarters was extended beyond 400 p.m. m., which was the normal schedule, until 12 midnight.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: In an office in Bogotá and on the transmilenio route, I observed two different and also similar scenes in October 2018.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: A group of Venezuelan journalists told with anxiety and sadness how the country was collapsing.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: Along the mass transit route, desperate migrants dragged their suitcases with difficulty and with them their dreams of a better future.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: Looking beyond to explain the migratory crisis was the impulse and commitment from the Data Journalism Unit of EL TIEMPO.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: How to cover an event that is changing Latin America, that of thousands of inhabitants fleeing a country, starring in the largest contemporary migration in the region

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: The answer is in that phrase that I say and say journalism is walking with the other to try to tell their stories.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: It is explaining and interpreting many times against the will of the public, for the necessary understanding of the facts.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: What was to begin in November of last year was a crossborder journalistic alliance led by EL TIEMPO, from Colombia.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: For this work we teamed up with media and journalists who live in different countries in Latin America we participate in a contest We won a scholarship from the Press and Society Institute (IPYS) and we started.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: Report of the Data Journalism UnitIntroductory video of Caracas without filter.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: The first installment of the report Expelled, is titled Venezuela on the run.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: It covers the migratory phenomenon of Venezuela, the largest in Latin America in recent times.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: At the time of the investigation, the sources consulted confirmed that 1,500,000 people had fled the country in the last two years due to the humanitarian crisis.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: The migration of despair, which noisily crosses Latin America and collides with xenophobia, brought us together with Cocuyo Effect, from Venezuela.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: The crossborder journalistic team traveled five thousand kilometers with the migrants, who pointed to three different destinations, Peru, Argentina and Curaçao described the farewell of relatives and the risks at the borders, revealed the migration figures, explained what it means for a country to stop being an oil power to become an expeller of its nationals, and recounted how Venezuelans live in six countries on the continent ( Argentina, Bolivia, Colombia, Chile, Mexico, Peru) and how those who stayed in the capital of Venezuela, Caracas, survive.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: The report includes 3 travel chronicles, 3 articles analyzing the migration crisis with digital infographics, 7 stories, a 33minute web documentary Dreams sometimes hurt, which narrates the journey of 2,900 kilometers on a bus with 35 migrants , 15 videos, and a visualization of data on the Venezuelan family basket.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: Each content responds to an intimate perspective, which extends to web design, to bring the user experience closer to the harsh reality of Venezuelans.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: The second installment is called Caracas without a filter and is a tour of the neighborhoods, hospitals, universities of Caracas, on the outskirts of prisons, in lines to buy bread or medicine, in improvised public transport vehicles.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: In all corners, Venezuelans confirmed that they were having a hard time and that they survive in the midst of hunger, uncertainty and fear.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: A Miss relates that she prepares food to distribute to homeless people.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: A grandmother goes to the clinic every week seeking medical treatment for her sick daughter.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: A nutritionist blames the government for deaths from malnutrition and international organizations for not declaring the humanitarian crisis.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: A disabled hairdresser denies the socialism of Nicolás Maduro.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: Some students and a professor mourn the empty university.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: A Chavista yells at the foreign journalist to leave and an opponent yells louder let it be known in your country what is happening to us.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: Along the green paths is the third installment that we are currently preparing.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: One by one we are visiting the neuralgic points where migrants pass legally or illegally, while we walk, listen, write down, interpret and explain, we produce a new documentary.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: Colombia has always been among the first places worldwide with the highest internal migration.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: The war and the difficult economic conditions, as well as the bonanza of the strong bolivar in the 70s and 80s, made many nationals go to seek better fortune in Venezuela.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: Today many of them were deported, some decided to return and others resist in the neighboring country.

title: The last migration from Latin America
text: From there also arises the responsibility to narrate this migratory phenomenon that transforms Latin American history, that transforms us all.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: In accordance with this contingency plan, in Cúcuta and in the municipalities of El Zulia and Puerto Santander, some sites will be adapted for the humanitarian reception of one million people who may cross the border into the national territory, fleeing from the political situation and society of the neighboring country.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: Many of the ColombianVenezuelan border hospitals continue their process of strengthening their institutional image, despite the difficulties that arise day after day with the massive arrival of Venezuelan migrants in the country.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: One of these is the San José de Maicao Hospital, which is characterized by being one of the medical care centers that provides the greatest attention to Venezuelans on the border.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: So far, the San José exceeds the barrier of 10,000 people medically assisted.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: Last year, the medical center treated 4,341 people and so far this year, the figure is 5,648 patients.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: For Alexandra López Pérez, intervening agent, affirms that if people continue to be received at the same rate, by the end of the year, there would be more than 15,000 people.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: The San José Hospital today faces a great challenge, which we have assumed with great responsibility and with a great humanitarian sense, and that is the care of the Venezuelan population in a condition of displacement.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: Between last year and so far this year, we have served more than 10,000 people and if we continue like this, we would close the year with more than 15,000 people served at the institution, he said.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: Despite the fact that the Nation, taking into account Decree 866 of 2017, assigned economic resources that were distributed to the hospitals that provide the greatest care to Venezuelans, this situation has put the financial situation of the hospital at risk.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: So far, a total of 6,000 million pesos has been billed, which is equivalent to a quarter of the institutions collection budget.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: However, López Pérez assures that in many ways, attempts have been made to mitigate the situation that is being experienced because it is a phenomenon that had no precedent.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: That is why, through the help of NGOs, international and national organizations, we continue in the task of receiving patients.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: He added that we try to ensure that the little we have reaches more people.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: And hoping with total confidence and tranquility that the State, doing what is pertinent, helps us to resolve this situation with the 40,000 million that are going to be distributed in the municipal ones that we are assuming the attention of Venezuelans, said the intervener.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: Day by day, the hospital seeks alliances to continue this process of caring for migrants.

title: The social commitment of the Hospital San José de Maicao on the border
text: But also, it is waiting for the Government and the other organizations, to which they have asked for help, to answer the call.

title: Migratory gaps would favor the commission of crimes by Venezuelans
text: This Monday he said that there were plans by the Armed Forces to steal the aid that he manages and present them as from the government of Nicolás Maduro, who rejected the aid, calling it foreign intervention.

title: Migratory gaps would favor the commission of crimes by Venezuelans
text: In a balance presented by the Metropolitan Police of Cúcuta that quantifies the commission of crimes by foreign citizens in the border region, there was an increase of 23 percent compared to the 192 crimes that were committed by people of other nationalities during 2015.

title: Migratory gaps would favor the commission of crimes by Venezuelans
text: The report showed a figure of 236 criminal behaviors that in different modalities have been carried out throughout this year by this population group, which mostly involves Venezuelans.

title: Migratory gaps would favor the commission of crimes by Venezuelans
text: The most frequent crimes within this criminal record are theft from passersby, with 46 cases robbery of commercial establishments, with 42, and smuggling, with 28 reported events.

title: Migratory gaps would favor the commission of crimes by Venezuelans

title: Four months of anxiety on the border with Venezuela

title: Four months of anxiety on the border with Venezuela
text: What was unthinkable for all the inhabitants of the ColombianVenezuelan border became a reality the closure of the same completed four months and its opening is seen more difficult every day due to the political, economic and social circumstances that Venezuela is experiencing.

title: Four months of anxiety on the border with Venezuela
text: On both sides of the border line between Norte de Santander and Táchira, the suspension of the border crossing is experienced differently.

title: Four months of anxiety on the border with Venezuela
text: Cúcuta, a city with 800,000 inhabitants in its metropolitan area, resists but has seen its economy suffer, while the populations of San Antonio and Ureña are experiencing a social and economic drama rarely seen.

title: Four months of anxiety on the border with Venezuela
text: In the capital of Norte de Santander, it is undeniable that the economy has been affected and will be even more so if measures are not established to increase or maintain cash liquidity in the metropolitan area.

title: Four months of anxiety on the border with Venezuela
text: The affected sectors continue to be coal, of which a little less than a third of what was done by Venezuela is being exported the formal exchange houses, which depend entirely on bilateral trade and their activity has dropped to 95 percent, are planning their definitive closure if the situation continues the hotel and restaurant sector maintains a 10 percent drop in its billings since before the crisis heavy cargo transport has dropped 60 percent, and travel agencies, whose main market was the island of Margarita in the Venezuelan Caribbean, saw their sales drop by up to 50 percent for the Christmas season.

title: Four months of anxiety on the border with Venezuela
text: On the other hand, for service stations, supermarkets, some products from the agricultural sector such as rice and meat, and drugstores, sales remain at high levels as they do not have to compete with contraband products.

title: Four months of anxiety on the border with Venezuela
text: As fewer products arrive illegally from Venezuela, the cost of living in the city rose 0.54 percent in November, in line with the countrys level, in an area where inflation used to be even negative.

title: Four months of anxiety on the border with Venezuela
text: But the situation is completely dramatic in the Venezuelan border towns of San Antonio and Ureña, where the closure implemented by President Nicolás Maduro has increased the shortage of products, unemployment, informality, and the closure of commerce and industry.

text: Of the 45,000 people who cross daily through the three binational crossings of Norte de Santander, the majority are citizens of Colombian origin who flee Venezuela in search of refuge in their country of origin, as revealed by a migration profile prepared by the Foreign Ministry. , the International Organization for Migration (IOM) and the Government of Norte de Santander.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: The last grade students, said Rincón, were given 8,000 booklets to continue their preparation for the Saber Tests.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: The first thing that we Colombians have to do in reaction to what is happening in Venezuela is to remain calm and understand that the options Colombia has are exclusively diplomatic.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: Many, justifiably outraged, ask the government to confront Venezuela firmly.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: But showing firmness is not synonymous with going to war.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: There are diplomatic options that allow us to be firm, without losing our heads, and making the situation created by Maduro hurt him as much or more than it does us.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: He is seeking to provoke Colombia to use it as a pretext to suspend the upcoming elections in his country.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: The way to make this ineffective is to not give him a reason to try to do it.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: Meanwhile, everything within our power must be done through diplomatic channels so that the international community sanctions the Government of Venezuela or at least censors its obvious violations of the human rights of our compatriots.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: Marking their homes with a D and proceeding to demolish them cannot be justifiable in a nation that claims to be democratic or at least civilized.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: It is an attack against the human rights of a group of people who have been singled out for being victims of this outrage simply because they were born in a sister country.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: No democratic government can remain silent in the face of these inhumane acts.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: The specter of atrocities committed for political reasons, obeying other types of prejudice or with different objectives, such as those that took place in Europe in the 1930s and 1940s, in the former Yugoslavia more recently, and in Ukraine today, is haunting our region as a consequence of the massive and unjustified expulsion of Colombians from Venezuela and the violence of an abusive State that has preceded it.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: We Colombians have the obligation to denounce this evident violation of the rights of our compatriots in all international, multilateral, private and public forums and in our own land to provoke a general repudiation.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: The government has taken the first steps in this direction by calling our ambassador for consultations and convening a meeting of Unasur foreign ministers, after having exhausted the possibility of solving the problem directly with Venezuela.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: Bearing in mind that Ernesto Samper has inexplicably tried to justify these acts of violence against Colombians, it is worth asking his allies in the Bogota mayoral campaign if they agree with his position.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: A clear response is expected from the candidate Clara López, from Iván Cepeda and Jorge Enrique Robledo, who have been figures of the democratic left.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: Hopefully the Central Committee of the Communist Party and Petro will also speak out to know what to expect.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: The Government has already gone to the OAS and is surely preparing the complaint before the InterAmerican Commission on Human Rights, in the United Nations, the International Criminal Court, before the Andean Commission of Jurists, with the heads of state of the Pacific Alliance and in the Convention European Human Rights.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: In addition, it is his turn to denounce Venezuela before the nongovernmental organizations that constantly besiege him with accusations and demands regarding respect for human rights in Colombia.

title: Venezuela what to do
text: Without a doubt, José Miguel Vivanco of Amnesty International is already working on this issue with Pax Christi and the UN High Commissioners for Human Rights and Refugees.

text: They are being raped, abused and exploited at border crossings and in the countries they reach.

title: A magnifying glass on Venezuelan migrant women

title: Santander became a destination for illegal migrants from Venezuela

title: Registered Venezuelans will have special permission
text: Of 870,093 Venezuelan migrants living in the country, some 442,462 Venezuelans who were registered in the Administrative Registry of Migrants (RAMV), a process carried out by the National Government for two months in the different capitals of Colombia, are waiting to regularize their situation in the country with the signing of a decree that will grant them a special permit to stay.

title: Registered Venezuelans will have special permission
text: The panorama was exposed by Christian Krüger, director of Migration Colombia, who delivered a balance of the migratory dynamics of Venezuelans in the country during the first semester of this year.

title: Registered Venezuelans will have special permission
text: According to the official, after the RAMV, a decree will be issued so that registered Venezuelans obtain their regularization, with a guideline similar to that of the special permanence permit (PEP), whose issue expired on June 7.

title: Registered Venezuelans will have special permission
text: This permit authorizes Venezuelans to carry out any legal activity or occupation in the country, including those carried out by virtue of an employment relationship or contract, with a maximum permanence of two years.

title: Registered Venezuelans will have special permission
text: In the next few days, a decree will be issued to obtain its regularization, which will be similar to that of the PEP.

title: Registered Venezuelans will have special permission
text: Beyond a plate of food or a temporary roof, here what we are looking for is to incorporate all this population into the productive life of Colombia, so that they can work with the same conditions as a Colombian and can join a social security system Kruger explained.

title: Registered Venezuelans will have special permission
text: In addition to those who are in the process of regularization with the census, there are 381,735 legal Venezuelans in the country and 45,896 illegals who remain in the country after entering by trails or after the maximum 180 days in which they could stay.

title: Registered Venezuelans will have special permission
text: Krüger added that once the process is completed after the signing of the decree, 94 of Venezuelans will be in regular condition.

title: Registered Venezuelans will have special permission
text: In this way, the Government will have identified the migrants and will be able to formulate public policies.

title: Registered Venezuelans will have special permission
text: We are looking for that population that wants to stay to be productive, to the extent that they can work and contribute to the country.

title: Registered Venezuelans will have special permission
text: And, in that sense, they will not represent a burden for the country, he said.

title: Registered Venezuelans will have special permission
