title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: The Second Municipal Civil Court of Envigado admitted a guardianship of a Venezuelan citizen against the mayor of Bogotá Claudia López, for her recent statements on security and Venezuelan migrants.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: Hernando Andrés Soto Valencia, protected by the right to equality and nondiscrimination, made a series of demands to López and the Mayors Office of Bogotá.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: The guardianship asks to order López to withdraw a tweet from October 30 in which the video was attached in which he says I do not want to stigmatize Venezuelans, but there are some immigrants involved in criminality who are making our lives small squares.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: The mayors post says Colombian law provides for the deportation of those who commit crimes in Colombia.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: That Law is not xenophobic, it is logical.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: Requesting that it be applied is not xenophobia either, it is using legal tools that we have to guarantee security, coexistence and justice for all.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: The guardianship also requires withdrawing a trill made through the Twitter account of the Bogotá Mayors Office on October 29 in which the same message is publishedAnd, in general, it is requested to order the mayor Claudia López to issue a public apology and that she promises not to repeat an act of xenophobia.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: So far, neither López nor the Mayors Office of Bogotá have spoken on the subject.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: They have a period of two days from the notification of the guardianship.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: Hernando Andrés Soto Valencia, 32, presents himself as born in Caracas (Venezuela), the son of Colombian parents and with a Colombian identity card.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: He is also a lawyer and is studying a specialization in administrative law.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: I am not a criminal, nor do I have a criminal record.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: In addition, I am a Binational Lawyer, I work for a law firm, I am currently studying a Specialization in Administrative Law and I always seek that my behavior as a citizen be the best possible, however, from these reprehensible statements by Mrs. Claudia López, they can generate xenophobic behavior or stigmatization against me, says the lawyer.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: Soto, in custody, collects evidence of the tweets of the mayor and publications of various media outlets that covered the news.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: From this, he assures Without a doubt, associating criminality with a nationality constitutes an act of reprehensible discrimination, because when someone has the status of a criminal, they do not do so by virtue of their nationality, but rather it derives from the loss of values as a human being and not as a Venezuelan, Colombian, Peruvian, etc.

title: Venezuelan citizen files guardianship against Claudia López
text: Obviously, criminality must be rejected regardless of its origin and the actions of the authorities must be supported so that criminals are captured and prosecuted.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: Dayana Zambrano has a very small belly for her almost nine months of pregnancy.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: The hunger she suffered in a Venezuela in crisis forced her to migrate to Colombia to receive medical care and give birth without it being a matter of life or death.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: She is admitted to the Erasmo Meoz University Hospital in Cúcuta, the city through which she entered Colombia three months ago after traveling more than 1,200 km by bus from Ciudad Bolívar (eastern Venezuela) to receive medical care, as more and more pregnant Venezuelans do.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: When I arrived here, I arrived with a very low weight for the time of my pregnancy.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: Thank God my weight increased and the doctor told me that the baby is fine, he just needed to mature his lungs a little, because they were small, this 21yearold told AFP.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: Her baby had a slower development than normal due to her poor nutrition, since she did not have three meals a day in Venezuela because she preferred to feed her oneyearold daughter.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: In addition, the long trip to Cúcuta with her partner affected her placenta and she began to bleed.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: Still pale and thin, she is happy to feel better at 34 weeks pregnant, according to what she says lying on one of the beds in the emergency obstetrics area of this public hospital, where Venezuelan patients pay nothing like Colombians.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: His decision is a reflection of an increasingly harsh reality in the neighboring country.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: As a result of the crisis, infant mortality increased 30.12 in 2016 with 11,466 deaths of children from 0 to 1 year old, and maternal mortality skyrocketed 65, according to figures from the Venezuelan Ministry of Health.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: In the room next to Zambranos, 19yearold Joselys Cañas is relieved to see her son born in Cúcuta, where she moved with her mother more than a year ago from Maracaibo, a city near the Colombian border. .

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: She feels very lucky mainly because there (in Venezuela) there are no medicines, there is nothing, but here there is, says the young woman, with honeycolored eyes, while she waits lying down for a doctor to see her.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: She clarifies, yes, that despite the crisis she feels proud to be Venezuelan.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: The number of Venezuelan patients at the Erasmo Meoz has been growing exponentially, hospital manager Juan Agustín Ramírez told AFP.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: Between September and December 2015, 655 Venezuelans were treated, in 2016 2,300 and so far in 2017 about 1,400, generating hospital costs of more than 1.6 million dollars, he explained.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: In the case of pregnant women, they arrive without any prenatal control and that includes them automatically in the (high) risk classification.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: If a tragedy of immense proportions were to occur, a displacement of Venezuelans, we would have to ask for international help, from the UN or the OAS, to build refugee sites where field hospitals would have to be built, he said.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: When Marbella Niño, 22, gave birth to Joshier at Erasmo Meoz, she still needed two vaccines and, according to her account, in Venezuela they asked her to buy the surgical kit for the caesarean section, but she couldnt.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: I really dont have the resources to buy it, he says.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: In this hospital they even gave her diapers for her baby, very scarce on the other side of the border.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: I preferred to have him here, where they could give him the shots and take better care of him, she says.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: In 20 days he will leave an aunts house where he is staying and return to Venezuela, but he is worried about the food and health crisis.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: Imagine that (Joshier) gets sick there, that you cant get any medicine either, says Marbella.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: María, a fictitious name for being a 16yearold teenager, gave birth to Juan David a day ago and sees the possibility of returning to Venezuela very far, due to the crisis and because she migrated to Colombia with a friend when she was barely 13, fleeing the mistreatment of their parents.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: They grabbed me as if I were a ball, they kicked me, they tied my hands (.) Thats why I decided to leave the house, get away from them for a while, she says shyly.

title: Matter of life or death, Venezuelans who travel to give birth in Colombia
text: Her hopes rest on the teacher who welcomed her into her home in Tibú, a troubled Colombian area on the border with Venezuela.

text: Yancy arrived in Colombia on November 22 last year and has already returned.

text: He had to pay 120,000 pesos for a place on one of those buses, and although he appreciates the help of Migración Colombia and several foundations that appeared to feed them along the way, he remembers that trip as one of the hardest experiences of his life.

title: Migrants, resist in the midst of the pandemic
text: From his home in San Juan de los Morros, he says that the conditions of the first shelter they arrived at, a school in Apure state, were even harsher.

title: Migrants, resist in the midst of the pandemic
text: When we arrived, they separated us women and men.

title: Migrants, resist in the midst of the pandemic
text: I was in a room with 35 women, and in total we were 265 people.

title: Migrants, resist in the midst of the pandemic
text: We had to sleep on the floor there werent even mats, we only covered ourselves with the sheet that each one had he says (.) That school was horrible the bathrooms didnt work, they were covered, the grass was very high.

title: Migrants, resist in the midst of the pandemic
text: At six in the morning we women had to be awake and clean the bathrooms and living rooms and the men, to cut the grass and pick up the garbage.

title: Migrants, resist in the midst of the pandemic
text: And he adds It was like a humiliation We thought that if they treated us so badly it was as punishment for having left the country.

title: Migrants, resist in the midst of the pandemic
text: XENOPHOBIA IN THE COUNTRY THAT HAS WELCOMED THEM BESTThose who see them making their way to the east do not believe that it will be long before they return.

text: The spike in xenophobia, in a country that has suffered for decades from its nationals being stigmatized abroad due to the crimes of a few, is one of the most worrying effects of the pandemic.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: The Secretary of Security of Bogotá, Hugo Acero, spoke in an interview with EL TIEMPO about how they planned to guarantee the tranquility of the citizens during the days of mandatory isolation drills that ended last night, about emergency situations such as looting of supermarkets and riots in the prisons, and how they enforced the call to stay home.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: Between Friday March 19 and Tuesday March 24 at 6 pm, the authorities had imposed 1,089 sanctions on people for noncompliance with the decree, and nine fights had been reported.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: Acero stated that he hopes that at the end of the month, when the data on crimes in the city is delivered, thefts, which, as he explained, had been declining before the coronavirus contingency, would continue to experience a decrease.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: How did you prepare to protect the city during these days of isolation

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: Various items entrances and exits of the city were taken into account, because if we were going to lock ourselves up, the control of entrances and exits had to be effective, and we had to decide where the army would be, where the police would be, and what each of them would be in charge of. the strengths.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: We decided that important joint operations had to be carried out in certain areas of the city and we talked about the security measures around the prisons, a first ring that the police have and a second ring that the XIII Brigade had that way it was coordinated.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: Did you anticipate that supermarket looting could occur

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: These are the risks that exist, and we basically control it by providing security in matters of large commercial establishments, of the neighborhoods themselves, because there is a risk that some people may take advantage of that solitude in the city to commit this type of act.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: But sometimes they are also people in need of food, that is why activities have been thought of to give food to those who work on a daily basis for the next days sustenance So thats a difficulty.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: Are migrants impacting acts of insecurity and violence these days

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: We had a looting of a warehouse in Los Mártires and unfortunately, well, the vast majority of migrants are good people, but there were some Venezuelans who ended up looting and five were the ones who ended up detained.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: How have safety indicators been like fights

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: They have certainly decreased much more than a normal day, just as thefts and other crimes have decreased.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: What is the status of thefts

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: Before these measures, the drill and now the internment that is going to take place, we already had a significant reduction in theft of cell phones and bicycles, and with what is happening, the reduction will be higher, but we had already managed to stop the growth and started to decline.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: This Tuesday there were many people in the streets, what do you think happened

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: I think that the difference in terms of one day between the decree that was issued for the drill and the decree of the Presidency that was the one on Tuesday caused a bit of misinformation, people believed that well, the President said that it was from this Wednesday and surely not everyone found out that the drill had been extended.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: I think it will be partly because of that, the other is that through networks there were unscrupulous people who said that they were going to deliver food to certain points in the city, which generated crowds.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: The National Government announced that thousands of prisoners will be released from prison to serve house arrest, what is your opinion on this

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: What we hope for in this case is that there will of course be some measures, because in the case of the URIs and the police stations we have people who have served sentences and also people under house arrest, others who have already served terms.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: This measure will benefit the reduction of overcrowding not only in prisons, but also in stations.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: Where can a citizen communicate in an emergency situation or for information

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: There is line 195 for information.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: We have it enabled and that has helped us a lot because many people call asking about the decree, if we are going to be able to leave or enter the city.

title: Secretary of Security explains how Bogotá was shielded for quarantine
text: If these types of requests reach line 123, they congest it for us and this does not allow us to have a response in health.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: In a visit made by EL TIEMPO, it became clear that there are several situations that the District, the national authorities and the other humanitarian aid organizations must resolve soon.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: The first is the departure of these people from the sector.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: Although Mayor Enrique Peñalosa ordered the creation of a department to attend to immigrants and the launch of a social care super center in the terminal, the reality is that they will have to leave this area, since the city does not allow any kind of settlement or appropriation of public space.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: Second, there, on Carrera 68D with Calle 22, it has been identified that at least 80 Venezuelans arrive daily from different locations to scavenge for aid, because there are no District personnel to channel the aid.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: What has been established in a preliminary way is that not all of them are newly arrived migrants, and the aid remains in the hands of the supporters, and not of those who really need it.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: This issue is already beginning to show overtones of territorial power.

text: The personera of Bogotá, Carmen Teresa Castañeda, said that the lack of organization for the delivery of aid, as well as the little interinstitutional coordination, is beginning to add the risk of crimes.

text: Thus, it is feared that the site will be permeated by human trafficking, sexual exploitation, criminal organizations and the phenomenon of drug dealing.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: Crime takes advantage of this situation of defenselessness and vulnerability, and that is why it must be solved, Castañeda warned.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: Next Tuesday, at 330 in the afternoon, there will be a meeting between senior officials of the entities to establish what is the mechanism of social intervention in the area, without violating human rights.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: The merchants of the Saltpeter sector also give their objections, since they invested in their businesses and today they feel affected.

text: Andrea Pinilla, a worker in the area, warns that the situation confronts her in many ways, because, on the one hand, there is the help they need but on the other, the way in which the arrival of clients has been affected.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: Regarding these difficulties, Peñalosa has asked the people of Bogota not to fall into the trap of xenophobia and has recalled the time when Colombians, in the midst of crisis, crossed the border in search of a better future.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: For her part, the social secretary of the District, Cristina Vélez, indicated that the response in attention has been effective and that they work so that the issue does not overflow.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: It is expected that on October 1, the manager for the care of Venezuelans, María Angélica Trujillo, will be in charge of articulating national, district and international actions.

title: The crossroads of the city with the Venezuelan cambuches
text: In parallel, the District must launch a social supercade in the transport terminal that provides firsthand information to migrants, as well as have 50 transitory shelters for the attention of the most urgent cases, among them the Salitre cambuches .

title: Thousands of Venezuelans break security barriers and arrive in Colombia
text: A panorama of chaos and desperation took over the border with Venezuela through Norte de Santander on Tuesday after thousands of citizens of the neighboring country broke the blockade imposed for more than a month by Nicolás Maduro.

title: Thousands of Venezuelans break security barriers and arrive in Colombia
text: This struggle took place around 11 in the morning between the Bolivarian National Guard and thousands of migrants, who were unable to cross the irregular steps, better known as trails, flooded by the swollen waters of the Táchira River.

text: The largest damming of the migrant population occurred on the Simón Bolívar international bridge, located between the municipality of Villa del Rosario (Norte de Santander) and the Venezuelan population of San Antonio, where passersby formed a human avalanche that knocked down the fences and mocked containers installed by the Chavista government.

title: Thousands of Venezuelans break security barriers and arrive in Colombia
text: Since last February 23, Nicolás Maduro broke off diplomatic relations with Colombia and closed the border, which prevented pedestrian passage through the binational bridges of Norte de Santander, hindered by containers and barricades.

title: Thousands of Venezuelans break security barriers and arrive in Colombia
text: Almost a month later, on March 11, Caracas enabled a humanitarian channel to guarantee the passage of Colombian high school students, who reside in that country, and patients in need of care in the Cúcuta health system.

text: Regarding what happens on the Simón Bolívar bridge, Christian Krüger, director of Migration Colombia, blamed Nicolás Maduro and the members of the Bolivarian National Guard for what could happen to the people who travel daily between Colombia and Venezuela.

title: Unions dissatisfied with Santos' response on the border situation
text: And that is one more demonstration of the repressive mechanisms of a dictatorial regime, pointed out Rafael Villamizar Ríos, president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of Colombia in Norte de Santander and coauthor of the lawsuit.

title: Unions dissatisfied with Santos' response on the border situation
text: In a meeting held last Tuesday, the President of the Republic, Juan Manuel Santos, evaluated with different actors from Norte de Santander society the situation of the binational blockade between Colombia and Venezuela, which was resolved after a communication between the two heads of Condition.

title: Unions dissatisfied with Santos' response on the border situation
text: As part of this dialogue, Santos received a call from the economic unions to combat smuggling, which prompted him to order an increase in the force at the border line to combat the problem of smuggling and reduce the control of the structures criminals in the irregular steps.

text: The unusual passage of thousands of people crossing the three international bridges between Colombia and Venezuela, which are located in Norte de Santander, uncovered this week a humanitarian situation in the streets and parks of Cúcuta, which has the Catholic Church concerned.

text: Entire families spending the night outdoors and children without receiving adequate medical attention are some of the painful images that the Bishop of Cúcuta, Monsignor Víctor Ochoa, who leads a humanitarian mission to offer almost 1,200 food rations, describes in dialogue with EL TIEMPO. daily in the border sector of La Parada.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: What are your impressions of the migratory phenomenon that occurred with the unusual passage of almost 30,000 people in one day, recorded last Monday, July 24

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: This is a humanitarian situation that does not stop growing.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: I think that every day we see a greater phenomenon of people who go to Colombia full of suitcases.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: More and more people are coming to look for medicines and there is a new phenomenon, which is the presence of children who come to Cúcuta to look for vaccines.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: Nor can we forget that many of those who pass are Colombians returning to their place of origin.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: In what economic situation do these migrants arrive in Cúcuta

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: A very painful climate of desperation is perceived due to the difficult economic situation that these people face.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: They spend with a wad of bolivars that, to obtain it, they have to work a lot, but here it has no value.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: What kind of assistance does the Catholic Church offer for those who are crossing the border

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: The Diocese is being several things, first of all we offer firsthand attention.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: We provide them with food, almost 60,000 portions in a month, prepared in the border sector of La Parada, next to the parish.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: We also have several communal dining rooms, where we welcome you with various foods.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: We are distributing vouchers that can be redeemed with food, in agreement with a world food program, and we are designing a service route to address those Colombians who are returning from Venezuela.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: How do you rate the States response to this humanitarian situation

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: I think there is an absence of institutions of the Colombian State, with the exception of the Police and Migration Colombia.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: And this is because we are facing a very large phenomenon that we are barely recognizing.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: However, the actions have not been enough.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: What happens in Venezuela is very delicate, because the deaths that occur are close to the border.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: The States response has not been focused, there is a need to be much more in tune with what is really happening.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: What social problems could be aggravated by this lack of attention to the high migratory flow at the border

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: We are seeing people in great need in the city.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: There are many people sleeping in the parks and on the streets, outside the churches.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: A phenomenon with great health implications is also taking place, because we have children without vaccines and people without sufficient medical care.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: This is a problem that can get out of hand and affect us all.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: Likewise, we have perceived the increase of girls and young women practicing prostitution, they come to Cúcuta and are exploited.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: What would be missing to improve this humanitarian assistance at the border

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: It is necessary that the State institutions dialogue and offer solutions with very precise paths for the attention of the migrant.

title: _We are facing a problem that is barely being recognized_
text: We need to offer something stable and orderly, with clear information to guide people.

title: _We are concerned about the increase in xenophobia_ Felipe Muñoz
text: Muñoz acknowledges that the coronavirus emergency has generated a setback in the progress that had been made to integrate the more than 1.8 million Venezuelans who have arrived since 2015 and warns that many of the more than 70,000 who have returned for these days to their country will be back in Colombia in the medium term.

title: _We are concerned about the increase in xenophobia_ Felipe Muñoz

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: Sodaisy Carvajal, a Venezuelan born in Barquisimeto, is in Colombia irregularly, despite the fact that she entered the country presenting her passport, which expired three months ago.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: Today he does not have a job and cannot access one either, since he does not have the respective permits.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: In order to be regularized, in the Venezuelan black market they are charging him 500 dollars to issue him a new passport.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: Leonardo Alberto García, a Venezuelan chef, is in limbo because, due to ignorance, he did not register in the Administrative Registry of Venezuelan Migrants (RAMV) in charge of the National Unit for Disaster Risk Management (UNGRD).

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: The registration process concluded on June 8, and now Leonardo does not know what his immigration status is because the permit to enter the country has already expired.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: Manuel Alejandro Luces is a Venezuelan civil engineer who has not been able to exercise his profession because he does not have a way to apostille his degree.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: For this procedure they are charging him, in the black market of Venezuela, 450 dollars.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: He approached an office of the Personería in Bogotá, but the officials did not want to enroll him in the RAMV because by that date he had a threemonth permit granted by Migration Colombia.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: Just like Sodaisy, Leonardo and Manuel, thousands of Venezuelans who entered the country regularly in the last two years today remain, due to various circumstances, irregular.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: Although the National Government has made a great effort to support the regularization of many Venezuelans (Decree 1288 of July 25, 2018), particularly those who entered the country through nonregular trails and border crossings, the reality is that in Right now a significant number of citizens of that country find themselves in a legal limbo.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: In July 2017, the Government created the Special Permanence Permit (PEP) as a mechanism for migratory regularization so that Venezuelan citizens who were in the country not only had an identification document and permanence for two years, but also decent conditions. for their access to the institutional offer in terms of health, education and work.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: The deadline to apply for the PEP expired on June 7 however, the Government extended (according to Resolution 6370 of August 1, 2018) its validity, but only for those Venezuelan citizens who registered with the RAMV.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: This means that Venezuelans who entered the country regularly through authorized immigration posts, but did not register with the RAMV, today find themselves in an irregular situation in Colombia and, worse, cannot access the institutional offer.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: It is urgent that the National Government correct these shortcomings in the regulations and resolve the situation of Venezuelans who regularly entered the country.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: Immigration regularization is the priority, since it not only allows us to know the magnitude of the phenomenon, but also helps combat the abuse to which these citizens are exposed by some national employers who accept them to work in unequal conditions and without complying with the law on social security.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: A viable alternative for those thousands of Venezuelans who are in Colombia today would be for a new decree to be issued to correct what happened to those who were regular on the date of the RAMV and who are currently irregular.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: Likewise, that an adjustment be made so that those who complete two years of permanence and have appropriate job stability receive an indefinite permanence and can automatically access a working life that contributes to the development of the countrys economy and does not generate greater tax burdens.

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: Likewise, the possibility of granting special treatment for the validation of professional titles should be studied, since the current requirements are an additional problem for hundreds of people who cannot exercise their profession, additionally causing this labor force to be wasted in Colombia. .

title: Venezuelans in limbo
text: Finally, the current regulations regarding PEPs must be modified, with the aim of not only addressing the migratory phenomenon in the short term, but also really making it part of a public migratory policy that understands that migrations are a real opportunity.

text: On August 28, it extended to four more municipalities of this entity (Zone 2) and finally on Monday, in the northwestern state of Zulia, it extended the decision of the border closure and state of emergency to three more municipalities (Zone 3).

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: Carla Betania García Díaz, a Venezuelan mother who lives in Colombia, warned about the situation of her minor son, who is being illegally held or hidden by a man whom she identified as William Caprio, also from that neighboring country.

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: García Díaz reported that she met the young Venezuelan William Caprio in the municipality of Bello, who gained her trust and took care of the child while she worked, but when she pretended that he would return him, he moved from Bello to the municipality of Rionegro and has not been able to locate it.

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: According to the alert from the Personería de Medellín on this case, the woman of Venezuelan origin has been in this situation for five months and has sought support from the Police, the Prosecutors Office and the Colombian Institute of Family WelfareICBF, without receiving a positive response.

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: He gave me a help and I trusted him.

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: At first he behaved very well, but in May when I went to pick up my son to bring him here, they told me that he had moved.

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: He gave me an address where he is living in Rionegro, but I have gone with my partner many times and we cannot find his whereabouts, the woman told EL TIEMPO.

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: According to the mother, she met the man in October 2019 and never had any complaints about him.

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: In addition, she added that Caprio told her that he was no longer in the country, a version that she discards because he does not have the documents of the minor, in addition to the fact that the photos that he has uploaded to social networks are with the furniture and all the things I had in Niquía.

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: From the photos he sends me of my son, he has it very well.

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: He has always been aware of the child, but in reality I already want to have my son, he cannot continue after him.

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: He tells me that in a message he announced that he was moving, but that is a lie, said the mother.

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: Given this, the Medellin Ombudsman urgently requested the Antioquia Police, the Attorney Generals Office and the Colombian Institute of Family WelfareICBF, to activate special routes for the search, care and comprehensive protection of a Venezuelan child separated from his mother. .

title: The drama of a Venezuelan mother looking for her kidnapped son in Antioquia
text: William Yeffer Vivas Lloreda, representative of Medellín, stated that he has already asked the Prosecutors Office to act in the face of the situation and help prosecute the man.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: In the case of the municipality of Hato Corozal, the ruling tells it that it must coordinate with the government, Migration Colombia and the Presidencys Border Management, in order to guarantee the reception of migrants, their location in places of passage, and the safe and dignified transfer to the limits with Arauca.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: Zuneika Dhisnays González is a 26yearold Venezuelan, founder of the organization Venezolanos Unidos en Barranquilla, who came to the city four years ago, looking for a better future for herself and her daughter, who now reside in the La Playa neighborhood.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: The decision was made primarily by her daughter, who was 4 months old at the time.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: Due to the difficult situation she was experiencing, going out to buy diapers, milk and food was a long process and she wanted to give her a better life.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: It was a big change, adapting to a new city and, the most difficult thing, having to move away from his whole family that is still in Venezuela.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: He longs to return to his country, but that reality is far from being realized.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: At the time of entering the city, he did so with his passport for 90 days, and after they expired he had to repeat the arduous process to extend the time.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: Once they expire you have to make another request.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: I had to do the whole process alone, I was disoriented and this is something that could happen to many more Venezuelans, González said.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: This experience is how the idea of creating Venezuelans united in Barranquilla was born, a community on the social networks Facebook and Instagram to support and guide other migrants, disseminating information about migration processes and talking about how to stay on your feet.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: The group grew rapidly, more and more coming knocking on the door for a helping hand.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: Therefore, they decide to start doing activities and integrations to bring the entire community together, get to know each other and be able to provide them with the necessary help.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: I feel good helping my people, because I know what its like to arrive alone in a foreign country.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: I have been an activist for about a year and my goal is to legally register Venezolanos Unidos en Barranquilla, to have a physical space where I can help my compatriots.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: In Venezuela I never did something like this, says González.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: His goal is to ensure that the people who are arriving, in every step they take, leave Venezuela on high.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: That each Venezuelan who joins Colombia is part of the change and the solution, not the problem.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: That is why I decided to create this social network to support people, he says.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: It is a nonprofit, nongovernmental organization that emerged from the initiative of Venezolanos Unidos in Barranquilla, which aims to achieve the inclusion, wellbeing and empowerment of women through the integration of cultures, talents and resources to achieve a impact on community development.

title: A hand that helps Venezuelans in the city
text: Its mission is to be a support for women in vulnerable situations, having as a priority the returned Venezuelan and Colombian migrant population, in order to strengthen the resilience of girls, boys, adolescents, young women and adults to motivate them to build a life project.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: A total of 40 million dollars in support to Colombia to deal with Venezuelan migration is the aid given by the Agency for International Development (USAID), the United States agency that accompanies some processes in the country.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: This was told to EL TIEMPO by USAIDs deputy administrator for Latin America and the Caribbean, John Barsa, who made his first visit to Colombia a few days ago and explained the efforts to address this phenomenon.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: How has USAID supported Colombia in the Venezuelan migration crisis

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: As USAID we have provided close to 40 million dollars to strengthen the capacity of the Colombian government and civil society to respond to the humanitarian situation created by the increased population flow from Venezuela.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: USAID is working with Colombian authorities at the national, departmental and municipal levels in the implementation of public policies to normalize the migratory status of returned Venezuelans and Colombians and facilitate their inclusion in the labor market.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: As a complement to these activities, we are supporting awareness initiatives to protect human rights and prevent xenophobia, violence and discrimination.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: What programs have been implemented for this accompaniment

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: I was impressed that, for example, in the school feeding program that we are supporting, Venezuelan children receive their lunch on par and under the same conditions as Colombian children.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: But also some of the ladies who prepare the food are Venezuelan.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: That is, this population is part of the solution.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: Seeing Venezuelan mothers preparing food for Colombians gives us hope.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: Do you see that there may be a quick solution to the crisis in Venezuela

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: We have on the brink, on the Colombian border, a crisis created by a human being that has no precedent.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: What we are seeing in Venezuela has led to a crisis in the region and as such we are providing regional support.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: How has the participation of the private sector been in the postconflict

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: The economy does not work if there is no private company.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: I see some organizations entering new territories, making efforts.

title: US$ 40 million, USAID aid to Colombia for the Venezuelan crisis
text: Development is not possible without the private sector.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: Thats why I think that from Friday we can start writing a new story, said the politician.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: A month ago, after the presentation of the Quality of Life Report of the Pereira program How We Are Going, Mayor Juan Pablo Gallo affirmed that the help of the National Government was necessary to face the situation generated in the city by the large number of Venezuelan migrants and returned Colombians.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: A good number of citizens of that country have joined the Venezuelans who are dedicated to rummaging as street vendors, who are located at traffic lights to change bolívares that no longer have any value for a few coins or Colombian pesos.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: Others sell strawberries, each for a thousand pesos.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: Most of these migrants are those who have arrived after the closure of the border with the neighboring country and have arrived in Colombia without a passport, that is, as illegal immigrants.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: Other Venezuelans are practically practicing begging, because they have not been able to find a formal or informal subsistence activity.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: However, other Venezuelans are exchanging something very different from bolívares ten Venezuelan women were found practicing prostitution in three brothels in the Corocito sector.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: In addition to the above, according to information from the Secretariat of Social and Political Development and the Personería de Pereira, there are already outbreaks of xenophobia towards Venezuelan migrants by some Pereirans.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: This situation had been denounced to this medium by Luz Neila Polo, a Venezuelan lawyer who has become the leader of a group of Venezuelans dedicated to street sales.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: In Pereira, according to Fernando Fontal Bueno, who in the Secretary of Social and Political Development of the Municipal Mayors Office coordinates the affairs of migrants and returnees, in Pereira there are about 2,400 Venezuelans.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: In 2017, 1,288 Venezuelans had been counted in the city, but as of August 31 another 1,100 had been counted.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: However, Fontal warned that there is a large number of migrants who are hidden in the city.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: In Pereira, according to the official, there are about 420 Venezuelans who entered the country with their identity documents and passport up to date and have a special permit to stay for two years, issued by Migration Colombia.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: With that immigration status, these people can work and access health and education services.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: But there is a good number who arrive in Pereira only with their identity card.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: There have even been cases of families arriving with minor children, without any documents.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: Because of the situation that exists there (Venezuela), many of them come along the trail and only bring their identity card.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: We are waiting for Migración Colombia to reopen the census of Venezuelans to register the people who arrived after June 8 (when the census was closed) and find out what we are going to do with them, Fontal explained.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: Last Friday, the personera of Pereira and president of the National Federation of Personeros (Fenalper), Sandra Lorena Cárdenas, made a new tour of the places in the city where Venezuelans change their countrys bills to survive.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: After that inspection, she arrived more worried than she was.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: Since the month of July, an excessive influx of the Venezuelan population into our country has been observed.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: In our city there are many people in an irregular situation at traffic lights, also carrying out begging activities and, in general, accessing sources of formal and informal employment, he commented.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: Another situation that worries a lot is xenophobic behavior, discrimination against them has already begun to be seen due to multiple factors, which must be rejected from any perspective, said Cárdenas.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: Fontal affirms that xenophobia occurs in the labor field, especially in restaurants due to the ability of some Venezuelans to cook.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: The Venezuelan minor who last May murdered a police officer in the CAI located on the César Gaviria Trujillo viaduct is detained at the Marceliano Ossa de Pereira Rehabilitation Center for Minors.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: This criminal act has been the most delicate in which a migrant from that country has been involved in Pereira.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: However, according to the commander of the Metropolitan Police of Pereira, Colonel Gustavo Moreno, some Venezuelans, like other foreigners, have been involved in thefts.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: It is worth remembering the case of a Venezuelan family that was brought to Pereira under the modality of human trafficking and was practically locked up under intimidation in a house and forced to carry out microtrafficking activities.

title: Venezuelan migrants in Pereira, between search and xenophobia
text: Both Fontal and Cárdenas are concerned about what could happen in Pereira with the Venezuelans if the National Government does not take action.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: These workshops were like a balm that allowed many to smile at life again, despite the difficult situation they are going through, he said.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: After the closure of the border with Venezuela ordered by the National Government in the face of Covid19, thousands of people have resorted to illegal steps or trails to enter Colombia.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Although the National Police and the Army do not allow the entry of the migrant population, and the authorities maintain control in the vicinity of the Simón Bolívar and Francisco de Paula Santander international bridge, some porters and criminal gangs that operate on the border offer travelers the I pass through the trails.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: The measure was taken in order to prevent the spread of covid19 in the border areas of the country.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: In previous days, the local leaders and congressmen of the Republic demanded that the president close the steps located in Norte de Santander.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Normally the border between Venezuela and Colombia is closed at 800 p.m. and many people were locked up on both sides of the border.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: This unleashed concern and fear in the inhabitants.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: The migratory flow goes from 20,000 to 50,000 people a day.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: It is estimated that about a third of the people who cross the border into Colombia do so with some type of health condition.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: For now, traffic to the La Parada corregimiento from Cúcuta is restricted and at least three security rings have been installed.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Before the closing order given to the immigration authorities and the Public Force, the people went to the wellknown trails.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: These illegal steps  which are estimated at about 150, according to the authorities  have been an alternative for migrants in previous border closures.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Also, porters and other organized armed groups often take advantage of the situation to charge people for letting them cross through these areas of dense vegetation and complex paths.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: However, on this occasion, the Public Force also prevented the passage there.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: The situation became critical and unleashed boos to the National Police.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Most of the people who tried to cross begged the uniformed men to let them pass.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Many of them come with the intention of buying products that they cannot get in Venezuela or going to work.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Those who tried to cross only reached the middle of the river, from there with the strong flow due to the rains the authorities ordered them to return.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Faced with this, people shouted at them let them work, let us see our families, we dont have a way to call them.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: If they dont let me in, Ill lose my job, its the only money I have to support my children.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Informal traders have also taken advantage of the situation.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: The price of the masks or plugs required by the authorities range from 3,000 Colombian pesos per unit and 45,000 pesos per box.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: However, given the massive presence of Venezuelans, Migration Colombia and the Metropolitan Police of Cúcuta enabled the passage to Venezuela.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Immediately pregnant women, older adults and those who were accompanied by minors, ran to Venezuelan territory.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: We are going to let groups of 100 people leave for Venezuela in a controlled manner, we prioritize pregnant women and older adults.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: We ask you to be patient and cooperate with the authorities, said Colonel of the Cúcuta Metropolitan Police, José Luis Palomino.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: More than 500 uniformed National Police officers and drones have been deployed to monitor illegal binational crossings.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: In addition, the operations extended several kilometers, reaching the historic complex of Villa del Rosario.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Therefore, the Casa General Santander museum closed its doors to the public.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Insecurity has permeated the inhabitants of Villa del Rosario.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: Those who reside in condominiums and houses near the border remain locked up.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: On the other hand, little influx of students is reported on the campus of the University of Pamplona.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: There were also cases of sick people who crossed the trails.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: An example was that of a 50yearold woman who had to be carried by her nephew in order to be transferred to a medical center.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: people disagreeFor the inhabitants near the border, the closure is not enough to prevent the spread of covid19, they fear that the virus will arrive and spread quickly in Norte de Santander.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: What Duque does is an outrage, by closing the border it is worse, because nobody controls the trails, now the health issue is getting worse, said Lucio Rodríguez, a regular trader on the border.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia
text: For now, the long lines of people who want to leave Colombian territory remain.

title: Venezuelans resort to trails to cross into Colombia

title: With these measures, Mincomercio will support companies in Cúcuta
text: The Minister of Commerce, Industry and Tourism, Cecilia ÁlvarezCorrea, announced several measures with which she leads the crusade to support the businessmen of Cúcuta and Norte de Santander in the current situation.

title: With these measures, Mincomercio will support companies in Cúcuta
text: The statement was made during a council of ministers headed by the President of the Republic, Juan Manuel Santos, in which he took stock of the actions that the Government has carried out after the closure of the border with Venezuela, and which included the presence of the accredited diplomatic corps in Colombia.

title: With these measures, Mincomercio will support companies in Cúcuta
text: In the first place, the Minister announced the opening of a special line of support for the companies of that Department for an amount of 80,000 million, as follows 40,000 million may be used for working capital (raw material, supplies, inventories and expenses operating operations), consolidation or substitution of liabilities (except with partners or shareholders), and the other 40,000 million in modernization (purchase or lease of real estate, machinery and equipment, vehicles, adaptations or improvements, etc.).

title: With these measures, Mincomercio will support companies in Cúcuta
text: Added to the above is the opening of two calls through Innpulsa Mipyme with nonreimbursable resources of 5,000 million, which are aimed at supporting the productive development of the population victim of forced displacement.

title: With these measures, Mincomercio will support companies in Cúcuta
text: Although the calls have national coverage, the proposals that benefit productive units in Norte de Santander will have additional points in the evaluation phase, as a measure to support economic activity and employment in the Department, explained the Minister.

title: With these measures, Mincomercio will support companies in Cúcuta
text: The first call is aimed at integrating the units into production chains already formed, and the second is intended to support the development of business microfranchises or businesses developed under the social brand scheme.

title: With these measures, Mincomercio will support companies in Cúcuta
text: Additionally, ÁlvarezCorrea reported that the coal dammed in the Department because it has not been able to leave through Venezuelan ports as usual, will now do so through Caribbean ports, while 10 business units called microfranchises will be opened, in which will employ 30 families.

title: With these measures, Mincomercio will support companies in Cúcuta
text: Finally, he announced that starting next Tuesday, September 8, a MiCITio Integrated Services Center will be opened temporarily in the city of Cúcuta, where all interested parties will be able to obtain more information about these announcements and other services of the Ministry, thanks to the advice officials from Bancóldex, ProColombia, iNNpulsa, Supersociedades and Superindustria.

title: With these measures, Mincomercio will support companies in Cúcuta

title: Foreign Minister arrived in Cúcuta to analyze the situation on the border
text: Foreign Minister María Ángela Holguín traveled this Tuesday to the border city of Cúcuta to review, in the company of local and regional authorities, the migratory situation that is concentrated in the 2,200 kilometers of border between Colombia and Venezuela.

title: Foreign Minister arrived in Cúcuta to analyze the situation on the border

title: Foreign Minister arrived in Cúcuta to analyze the situation on the border

title: The 11.8 _ unemployment rate in February confirms the upward trend
text: The unemployment rate in the country, in February, stood at 11.8 percent, one point above that of the same month last year, when it was 10.8 percent.

title: The 11.8 _ unemployment rate in February confirms the upward trend
text: Colombians have been looking for work for up to 3 months, according to the February labor market report presented this Friday by Dane.

title: The 11.8 _ unemployment rate in February confirms the upward trend
text: Two million nine hundred and fortyfour thousand people in Colombia (2,944,000) are unemployed, says the report.

title: The 11.8 _ unemployment rate in February confirms the upward trend
