title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: 26 percent of the population of Cartagena, that is, more than 268,000 people live in poverty, and 3 percent, equivalent to 35,000 people, live in indigence.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: Cartagena along with Cali, are the poorest cities among the seven main capitals of Colombia.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: In the Heroic City, the average income per inhabitant was 29.3 percent lower than the current monthly minimum wage for 2018, which is 869,453 pesos.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: This is confirmed by the oversight committee Cartagena Como Vamos, which presented this week the report on the quality of life in the city.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: Last year, according to Dane, 268,300 people from Cartagena lived in the monetary poverty line that is to say that these people did not reach the minimum income of 257 pesos for food, public services and transportation despite the fact that since 2002 the poverty rate in the city has been falling, said María Claudia Peña, director of Cartagena Como Vamos.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: Extreme poverty continues to be a scourge in Cartagena, that is, there are people who live on 117,000 pesos a month.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: WHAT has raised the rates of malnutrition and malnutrition.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: Sexual violence against girls increased.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: According to Cartagena How We Are Going, the total number of violent deaths in the city decreased by 57 cases, from 458 in 2017 to 401 in 2018.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: Last year there were 230 homicides, which decreased in relation to 2017 they went from 252 to 230, that is, 9 percent less homicides from one year to another.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: Historically, the Olaya Herrera neighborhood has been the sector with the most homicides, but it was also the one that presented the most significant reduction in the number of cases during 2018.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: For the fifth consecutive year, the lack of citizen coexistence among Cartagena was the main cause of homicides with 55 percent, that is, 126 deaths, followed by hired assassins with 51 deaths.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: In 2018, the total number of sexual crimes increased by 60, compared to 2017, going from 514 to 661.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: The neighborhoods with the most reported cases were Olaya Herrera (54), El Pozón (39) and Nelson Mandela (32).

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: In 75 percent, the perpetrator was a family member or acquaintance.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: On the other hand, 87 percent of the total cases were minors, the main victims were girls between 12 and 17 years old.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: In the last 10 years, more than 90 percent of domestic abuse victims were women.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: 67 percent of domestic violence records in 2018 responded to partner abuse.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: In education, there is concern about school dropoutIn Cartagena there are more than 231,000 students enrolled, and of them, 6,645 are Venezuelan migrants.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: The Heroic City has not been able to retain its students in the educational system, and school desertion is 3.9 percent in the city, but in the rural area it is 5.5 percent.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: A public school received an A rating, the highest in the system.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: This is the Soledad Acosta School in Samper.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: However, in rural areas all schools are in category B, the lowest on the scale.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: We have to put a stop to the cycle of bad education in Cartagena, which leads to poverty, says María Claudia Peña.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: The directive maintains that the city presents a mediumlow level of social progress, due to the poor performance of components such as education, health, nutrition, basic health services, housing and public services.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: More Venezuelans in the health systemFor 2018 there was a small decrease in teen pregnancy, going from 19 percent in 2017 to 18 percent in 2018.

title: Cartagena cracks in quality of life and poverty remains
text: In the city there were 3,435 pregnancies in girls and young people between 10 and 19 years old.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: 29 said they have a tourist visa, 20 a temporary permit and only 4 a permanent permit.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: President Juan Manuel Santos, without abandoning his willingness to engage in direct dialogue under certain conditions, hardened his stance towards the government of Nicolás Maduro and notified him that he will not allow himself to be provoked by horseplay.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: Santos from the Casa de Nariño emphasized that Colombia is not to blame for the failure of the Bolivarian government model that has been applied since Hugo Chávez in the neighboring territory, so he will not allow the country to be used as an excuse to hide the harsh problems that exist there.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: It is a product of the model, of that Bolivarian revolution that has failed, that has not worked.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: It is not the Colombians fault, Santos said.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: This change in tone is due to Maduros multiple statements to the effect that he wants to tighten the border closures, according to him, to curb the threat posed by Colombia, on the basis of which he has expelled and violated the rights of at least 20,000 nationals who have returned from Venezuelan territory.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: This, in fact, marks a turning point in binational relations, since, despite the constant attacks from Caracas, a more diplomatic tone had been maintained in Bogotá.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: This Wednesday, even, is the harshest reference from Santos to Maduro in the six years he has been in power.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: On my radar to manage foreign relations there is no room for disrespect or insults, nor for antics or lies, Santos said.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: Although the House of Nariño does not abandon diplomacy, and even insisted on direct dialogue to overcome the harsh crisis that was unleashed by the order to close the border since August 19, the Government of Colombia made it known that, in defense of its sovereignty and its citizens, will not give up its efforts.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: This Wednesday, Santos even reiterated his theses from an event in Cartagena, while Maduro simultaneously lowered the tone of his statements from Caracas and called for dialogue and the construction of a peace border.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: Although he never mentioned the reopening of the border crossings.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: Vice President Germán Vargas also came out yesterday to defend the position of the Casa de Nariño, emphasizing that the Venezuelan problem is not related in any way to Colombia.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: That is due to incompetence in the management of public policies, said Vargas Lleras, who specified that Venezuela must solve its problems and not think that they are the responsibility of another country.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: In fact, the Colombian ambassador to the United Nations, María Emma Mejía, told EL TIEMPO on Wednesday that the objective of raising awareness in that multilateral organization about the harsh humanitarian crisis on the ColombianVenezuelan border was achieved.

title: Border crisis Santos ran out of patience with Maduro
text: He added that this was achieved after the meeting between Foreign Minister María Ángela Holguín and UN Secretary Ban Kimoon on Tuesday, in which he saw and heard the testimonies we presented to him, and I think he understood and was moved by them. difficulties.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: The first victim, 47 years old, had ColombianVenezuelan nationality.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: A long line stretching between two and three blocks piles up outside this place.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: Regardless of the ferocity of the midday sun, they wait for several minutes to receive at no cost what is scarce on the Venezuelan side of the border food.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: Alleviating the hunger of this vulnerable population, which mostly crosses the dividing line between Colombia and Venezuela just to get here and caress this gesture of charity, is the daily mission of the more than 200 collaborators of Divina Providencia, the community kitchen of the Catholic Church, located in Villa del Rosario, Norte de Santander, less than 500 meters from the Simón Bolívar international bridge.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: These volunteers, members of the religious congregations of the Diocese of Cúcuta, confess that they feed their spirit with this humanitarian work.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: They are women and men who from 6 in the morning light the stoves, prepare the food and organize the plastic tables to start at 11 in the morning with the distribution, in record time, of a total of 3 thousand food rations.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: The one who leads this operation is Jairo Alberto Silva Fernández, a food technician who since April 2017, when this community kitchen was inaugurated, formed the base group of helpers.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: He delegates the functions of each cook, supervises the preparation of the menus and oversees the handling of the ton of supplies, including vegetables, fruits and meat, which is donated each week by the United Nations through the World Food Bank.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: We have four refrigerators or tanks, in which red meat, fruit, vegetables and water are stored.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: At 6 in the morning we start work, before this we make a small prayer and we already start with the preparation of the lunches, indicated this collaborator.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: Among the most popular dishes in this place are mixed rice, pasta with tuna, lentils with rice, crispy chicken, soups and salads.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: To transfer the palate of diners to their place of origin, beans black beans and meats with different preparations, inspired by the flavor of Venezuelan cuisine, are also prepared.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: Alexis José Rivero López, a Venezuelan from Acarigua, Portuguesa state, arrived in Colombia 10 months ago and found an option for survival as a kitchen assistant in Divina Providencia.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: Although he does not earn a fixed salary, the food and financial donations he receives during his day have become the main source of support for his home in the Sendero y Paz neighborhood of Villa del Rosario.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: The economic crisis and the lack of food took us out of Venezuela.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: I have always believed that we get nothing out of criticizing ourselves, that is why it caught my attention to help my countrymen, from here, with what is most scarce in my country, which is food, said Rivero.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: Just like him, there are 30 foreign citizens who decided to put on the apron and help their compatriots with the delivery of food.

title: Volunteers alleviate the hunger of Venezuelans at the border
text: Before the end of the year, those in charge of Divine Providence expect to start the adaptation of some bathroom batteries and the improvement of the kitchens, which is being carried out by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in an area of approximately 400 square meter.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: This could facilitate plans to expand the 1,000squaremeter lot, where the platform used for liturgies and dining rooms extends, which are shaded by a series of tents with a sign that says Feel lunch like a caress of God.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: With the goal of collecting more than a thousand tons of nonperishable food through donations and thereby helping nearly 581 thousand families in vulnerable situations, the first Alimentatón 2018 began on Tuesday, with the support of the Archdiocese of Cali.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: This national campaign on World Food Day will run until next Saturday and seeks to encourage the participation of companies and civil society in the collection of products that improve the food and nutrition of vulnerable populations.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: The event is supported by the Colombian Food Bank Association (Abaco) and in Cali by the Food Bank Archdiocesan Foundation, which has been working for food security for 18 years.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: The lack of food on a daily basis and poor nutrition increase more diseases in populations.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: For example, there is chronic malnutrition and among the most affected are children under 5 years of age.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: Last year, 7.8 percent of these children had chronic malnutrition greater than in 2016, when the rate was 6.8 percent.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: Among those who may be in the process of malnutrition are Venezuelan migrants.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: According to the Mayors Office, they are served in the 200 community kitchens in Cali, but they are not enough.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: According to the program Cali How We Are Going, 12 percent of 1,250 people surveyed last year said that in the last 4 weeks, some member of their household had not covered the three daily meals.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: Marvin Mendoza, coordinator of the program explains that this can be seen reflected in the panorama of hunger that crosses the city.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: That 12 percent equates to 145 people with 26 percent saying they ate fewer than three meals a day more than twice a week and 17 percent saying this happened more than 10 times a week.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: Father Oscar de la Vega, director of the Cali Food Bank, stated The call is for everyone in the Alimentatón to help more than 50,000 eCali people who benefit from 250 organizations, which need our support.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: According to Astrid Giraldo, the Banks Management Coordinator, the organizations are given a weekly market according to their needs, depending on the number of people, ages, and the number of meals, among others.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: Donating nonperishable food products such as rice, pasta, oil, lentils, sardines, tuna, sugar, panela and beans.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: Companies or citizens can donate the product in the Food Banks.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: Family basket products and inviting collaborators, colleagues and friends to donate.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: You can donate today and Thursday at stores on 14th Avenue, Centenario and Valle del Lili, Unicentro shopping center in front of the Oasis fountain.

title: Alimentatón_ to face hunger in houses and streets of Cali
text: The permanent point is the headquarters of the Food Bank at 6103 24th Street, San Nicolás neighborhood and at the Santa Teresita, Fátima Sanctuary, Transfiguración and La María churches.

title: Government trusts that UNHCR will support Venezuelan soldiers in Cúcuta
text: Dozens of them spend their nights in the Water and Childrens parks in the capital of Santander, most of whom have arrived after long journeys on foot from the border with Cúcuta.

title: Government trusts that UNHCR will support Venezuelan soldiers in Cúcuta
text: After the Venezuelan soldiers who fled from the Maduro regime and who remain in shelters in the city of Cúcuta, denounced that the UNHCR notified them that in three days they had to leave this place and survive on their own, the Foreign Ministry issued a statement where it assures that he trusts that UNHCR will continue to provide support in the migratory crisis that the country is experiencing.

title: Government trusts that UNHCR will support Venezuelan soldiers in Cúcuta
text: In accordance with its mandate, the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) has responded positively to requests from the Colombian Government to offer logistical support for the care of refugee applicants.

title: Government trusts that UNHCR will support Venezuelan soldiers in Cúcuta
text: The Government wishes to reiterate its thanks to UNHCR for its prompt reaction and trusts that it will continue to count on its important cooperation in handling the mass exodus of Venezuelan citizens, originating in the serious humanitarian crisis that country is experiencing, it is said apart from the statement sent by the Foreign Ministry regarding this issue.

title: Government trusts that UNHCR will support Venezuelan soldiers in Cúcuta
text: According to official figures, since February 23, nearly 1,000 members of the Venezuelan security forces and 400 members of their families have arrived in Colombian territory in search of protection.

title: Government trusts that UNHCR will support Venezuelan soldiers in Cúcuta
text: In a joint effort between various institutions of the Colombian State and international cooperation, the members of this group of people have been interviewed by immigration authorities and have received basic health care, legal support, temporary accommodation and food.

title: Government trusts that UNHCR will support Venezuelan soldiers in Cúcuta
text: Each and every one of them have handed over their weapons and uniforms, which are in the custody of the Colombian Public Force.

title: Government trusts that UNHCR will support Venezuelan soldiers in Cúcuta
text: Likewise, they have declared to cease any type of military activity.

title: Government trusts that UNHCR will support Venezuelan soldiers in Cúcuta
text: A significant number of members of this group have processed refugee applications, according to the Foreign Ministry.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: A 61day hospitalization of a Venezuelan patient with acute myeloid leukemia, which cost 51 million pesos, is part of the long account of 2,249 million pesos that the Departmental Health Institute of Norte de Santander (IDS) has pending to pay the Erasmo Meoz University Hospital (Huem), in Cúcuta, for the vital medical emergency care it has provided to citizens of the neighboring country.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: According to the reports provided by Huem, between August 2015, the date on which the border was closed, and today, this health center has provided care to 1,506 people of all ages who arrived in Colombia in search for medical services, in the midst of the difficulties they have in accessing these in their country. Although much of this care was provided more than a year ago, the hospital still does not receive a peso for it.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: The reason the IDS ensures that the department does not have the financial resources to assume this expense.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: Juan Alberto Bitar, director of the IDS, pointed out that they have made a repeated call to the Ministry of Health to define with what money this debt is going to be paid, which is not only growing in Erasmo Meoz, but in other public entities that provide medical services. in towns located on the border, such as the North ESE of the municipality of Tibú and the hospitals of Ragonvalia and Herrán.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: The volume of care for Venezuelan patients has been increasing so much that in the month of August the value that Erasmo Meoz had been billing doubled, going from 150 million pesos to 280 million, said the official.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: Bitar added that although the system must return stabilized patients to their place of origin, this is impossible due to the health conditions in which they continue and the deficiency in the provision of medical services in Venezuela.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: For his part, Juan Agustín Ramírez, manager of the Erasmo Meoz University Hospital, specified that, according to the law, health institutions that have an emergency service have the obligation to attend to both Colombian and Venezuelan patients, but this is not fulfilled. in most cases, which leads the Huem to always be the paganini.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: What happens is that here the magnifying glass of a different size begins to be seen towards the public institution, which is us.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: If that magnifying glass were just as big for all the entities that have the obligation to provide health services, then we would find that not only Huem is obliged to attend to these patients, but all the institutions that have emergencies here I am referring to the private company, said the director.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: As reported by the IDS, the billing of private clinics for the care of Venezuelans is almost nil.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: So if they were refusing, they would be incurring a crime for not serving that population.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: Although at present, after several efforts, Erasmo Meoz, like few others in the country, does not have economic difficulties, this situation could lead to a financial crisis, since the EPS owe him more than 100,000 million pesos.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: Although the creation of a binational fund for the payment of these medical services had been proposed which would be nourished by resources from the governments of Colombia and Venezuela, to date nothing has been defined.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: The call has been made to the Government to look at the complex situation in this border area, said Bitar.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: In Cartagena they have treated some 200 pregnant womenSo far in 2016, the District Health Administrative Department of Cartagena (Dadis) has attended 200 deliveries, including cesarean sections and vaginal deliveries, of Venezuelan citizens.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: For outpatient procedures alone, Dadis has treated 120 pregnant foreign citizens, of which 99 have been Venezuelans.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: What is appearing the most are women who arrive in the last months of pregnancy, and others in the last days of pregnancy, which makes care more risky, explains the official.

title: No one pays the bills of Venezuelan patients
text: For this care, the District has received about 300 million pesos, but this value does not include care in the last six months or cesarean sections or intensive care for newborns and mothers therefore, we calculate around 1,700 million pesos for attention to Venezuelan citizens, concludes Dr. Meza.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: CAROLINA RINCON RAMIREZCorrespondent THE TIMECUCUTAWith information from Cartagena

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: The hundred irregular border crossings that connect the municipality of Ipiales, in Nariño, with Ecuador became this week the route of hope for hundreds of Venezuelan citizens stranded on the Rumichaca international bridge due to the new immigration measures of the Ecuadorian Government, which began to govern from last Sunday.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: The rough and dimly lit roads are traveled by dozens of migrant families who, although they sealed their departure from Colombia, did not meet the necessary requirements to obtain the temporary residence visa for humanitarian reasons (VRTERH), which allowed their entry from regularly to the neighboring country.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: We are camping in the street and it is cold.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: We ask the Ecuadorian government to extend the deadline to enter the country, to keep in mind that we are here with children and with faith in God so that everything goes well, said Marta Suárez, a Venezuelan migrant who was unable to obtain a visa. humanitarian and does not have the necessary resources to return by bus to Bogotá, the only city in the country where the document can be processed.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: According to reports from the Migrant Population Assistance Desk in Ipiales, at least 300 people who were unable to enter Ecuador are sleeping on the streets and blocking intermittently at the border crossing.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: The shelters, which had a maximum capacity of 700 people, are also not enough.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: Marta assures that, although in Rumichaca her dream of starting a new life away from the Nicolás Maduro regime was cut short, she is thinking of reaching Ecuador through the El Rosario trail, one of the most used by natives and migrants in the area.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: Police intelligence documents in Nariño indicate that there are currently around 100 irregular roads on this 145kilometer border.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: The migrants who travel along these desolate roads are usually accompanied by individuals who charge them large sums of money to guide them on a threehour walk to Tulcán, the first municipality on the other side of the border.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: The proposal of the local administration, led by the social manager Miriam Martínez, consists of asking the Ecuadorian Government to allow a humanitarian corridor, at least for people who do not have Ecuador as their destination, and seek to reunite with their families in Peru and Chile. , said the mayor of Ipiales, Ricardo Romero Sánchez, who added that the socalled coyotes take advantage of Venezuelans and take away the few resources they bring.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: Romeros alert adds to the statements of the director of Migration Colombia, Christian Krüger Sarmiento, who warned that over time, the citizens of the Bolivarian nation will not even reach the checkpoint and, given that Ecuador it is not going to let them pass, they will go down the trails.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: Faced with criticism of the measure, Juan Roldán, private secretary of the presidency of Ecuador, told the media in that country that the new visa seeks to guarantee a safe and orderly migration, adding that, thanks to the visa, the flow of Venezuelans in the first days of this week it went from 2,000 to 50.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: The calculation of the Ecuadorian official agrees with what was reported by Migración Colombia, an entity that assured that since August 26 the number of Venezuelans who registered their departure in Rumichaca went from 657 to 64 in less than three days.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: However, Ipiales authorities stated that the reduction would also be due to the fact that most migrants no longer pass through Colombian controls.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: We believe that after sealing the exit, many would be stranded on the bridge, and others would be taking the trails to reach Ecuador.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: We also assume that, since they know that they cannot cross without a visa, many avoid immigration controls, and when they arrive in Ipiales they head straight for the irregular roads, warned Jackeline López, coordinator of the Migrant Population Assistance Desk. in the town.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: To confront the rise of the coyotes in Ipiales, the Police ordered the 120 uniformed men from the town to carefully monitor the border crossings, to which dozens of buses loaded with Venezuelan migrants continue to arrive.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: The area is also threatened by theft and human trafficking mafias.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: The trails of Nariño would not be the only paths taken by Venezuelans on their odyssey to the south of the continent.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: According to several authorities in the region, the migrants who were unable to cross into Ecuador through Rumichaca would be taking buses or boats to the borders of San Miguel and Puerto Leguízamo, in Putumayo.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: The first route involves taking a bus to the municipality of La Hormiga There they pay 7,000 pesos to a fleet that takes them to San Miguel, a small border town on the verge of collapsing due to Venezuelan migration.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: Very few cross the bridge.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: Most pay car drivers to take them to Ecuador through illegal steps, thus avoiding the immigration controls of the two countries.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: Others embark in canoes to the municipality of La Junta There they take a car to Lago Agrio and then continue on their way to Quito, Guayaquil or Santo Domingo, said Orlando Villacorte, coordinator of Border Affairs and Community Development of San Miguel.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: Villacorte added that the lack of institutions at the border does not allow them to carry out border controls adequately.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: We only have a Colombian Migration post, there is no Ecuadorian Consulate headquarters, and there is no office of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, added the official.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: The municipality also faces a crisis due to the lack of resources to serve the migrant population and an increase in the crime rate.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: According to data from Migración Colombia, between January and July of this year, 13,488 people of all nationalities crossed into Ecuador through the San Miguel immigration post.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: But the greatest alert is concentrated on the route that leads the migrants to the Puerto Leguízamo border crossing.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: Coordinator López told EL TIEMPO that people, not having the option of the humanitarian corridor, would be taking that dangerous route to get directly to Peru.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: That information is already in the hands of the Ombudsmans Office, and we are asking the National Government to help us build a strategy to control these irregular steps.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: The route that the Venezuelans would take initially includes a 293kilometer journey by land to Puerto Asís.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: Then they would get on a boat that would take them for eight hours down the Putumayo River to Puerto Leguízamo.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: There they would pay 10,000 pesos to the driver of a boat to take them to Soplín Vargas, in the Peruvian Amazon.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: It should be noted that by entering the country irregularly, migrants would also avoid passing through Peruvian immigration controls, where Venezuelans are also required a humanitarian visa since June 15.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: Álex Ruiz, mayor of Puerto Leguízamo, stated that they are attentive to what may happen with the arrival of migrants in a municipality whose rural area has become since 2006 the shelter of la Constru, the armed group recognized by the authorities as one of the most important criminal gangs in the south of the country, which would have links with the FARC dissidents and the Sinaloa cartel in Mexico.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: In this territory, the dissidents of the 48th front of the Farc, under the command of alias Dúmar, are also present.

title: The 3 dangerous trails used by migrants to reach Ecuador
text: For now, Colonel Mauricio Ruiz, commander of the Police in Putumayo, assured that the area remains completely normal and that in recent months there have been no violent acts by these armed groups.

title: Migrants requested transfer to the Venezuelan border for fear of covid-19
text: Given the alerts for the safety of migrants issued by the Ipiales authorities, the commander clarified that the Police and other government entities are prepared to face the possible massive arrival of Venezuelans seeking to leave the country.

title: Migrants requested transfer to the Venezuelan border for fear of covid-19
text: In the last hours, more than two hundred Venezuelan migrants arrived at the Water Park, in Bucaramanga, from the city of Bogotá.

title: Migrants requested transfer to the Venezuelan border for fear of covid-19
text: The citizens of the neighboring country expressed their desire to return to Venezuela to the authorities of the Santander capital.

title: Migrants requested transfer to the Venezuelan border for fear of covid-19
text: We want to return because with the quarantine here the situation is very difficult, at least we have a house there, said one of them.

title: Migrants requested transfer to the Venezuelan border for fear of covid-19
text: The panorama in the park was discouraging entire families sleeping on the floor together with other people who were waiting to reach the border area.

title: Migrants requested transfer to the Venezuelan border for fear of covid-19
text: Once the situation became known, thanks to complaints from citizens who made videos of the area, the authorities held a meeting in which they concluded that they would help with the voluntary relocation of these families.

title: Migrants requested transfer to the Venezuelan border for fear of covid-19
text: The transfer was completed in the early hours of this Wednesday.

title: Migrants requested transfer to the Venezuelan border for fear of covid-19
text: However, the authorities were emphatic in pointing out that no more transfers of this type will be made.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: Parque Centenario, in the center of Bucaramanga, has become one of the resting places for foreigners like Fabián, 25, who arrived three months ago from Punto Fijo (Venezuela) after a 38hour road trip.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: Fabián has found a job for a few days on construction sites.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: However, he hasnt worked for two weeks, a situation that has led him to live on the streets and spend whole days without eating or in which he can only eat a piece of bread.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: I came here because I thought it was better here, but it is very difficult to find work, and even less so without having an ID or health care () I am not going back because the situation is worse there a day of work here, about 50,000 pesos that I earn in construction, is equivalent to a months salary in Venezuela.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: Also, because one has money, there is nothing to buy there, says this Venezuelan while fleeing from a police operation that was taking place in the park that has served him to spend his days and nights.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: Fabián, along with two other nationals, point out that after a season in Bucaramanga, where he hopes to be able to work in whatever to raise money, he will travel to Medellín.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: The Mayors Office of Bucaramanga has warned about the considerable arrival of Venezuelans in that city and has urged State entities to clarify the care route that should be provided to foreigners, with the health issue being one of the most worrying due to the high demand for services in this area, mainly from pregnant women.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: Until now, what we have been doing is guaranteeing the emergency service to Venezuelans in the different institutions, call it Hospital del Norte or Uimist, where they treat us as mothers, said the Undersecretary of Health of Bucaramanga, Carlos Alberto Adam Rincon.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: The official added that in January there was a list of 22 pregnant Venezuelan women who were wandering around the city.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: In anonymity, Alba Pereira, a Venezuelan living in the Santander capital for more than thirteen years, has dedicated herself to offering a helping hand to her compatriots who daily come to the city due to its proximity to the border in search of opportunities.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: However, the woman, sadly, recounts the situation that many of them  some professionals  are going through today, who in the midst of the few options to survive have fallen into destitution.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: Pereira, who points out that she became a spokesperson for Venezuelans in Bucaramanga without realizing it, denounces the indifference suffered by her compatriots not only by local authorities, but also by their own consuls in that capital.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: The situation is becoming more difficult every day.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: More and more Venezuelans are falling into poverty in Bucaramanga among them, there are pregnant women, says the woman.

title: Bucaramanga parks have become beds for migrants
text: He adds that the lack of legal documentation is the first obstacle faced by the nationals of the neighboring country to access a job.

title: Santander became a destination for illegal migrants from Venezuela
text: In the document, this control body assures that the Police did not heed the calls and warnings, made at the time to increase actions against insecurity, given the massive and uncontrolled entry of Venezuelans, which benefits the ranks of the criminal gangs, with interference in the border line.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: Since then, some 20,000 Colombians, including deportees and those who fled for fear of being deported, have returned from Venezuela, according to UN estimates.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: They were sitting in order on the platform.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: Patiently, they waited their turn to receive the food.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: Spending the night, even out in the discomfort of the street, was better on a full stomach.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: They waited, calmly, 5, 10, 15 minutes.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: In the end, it was their moment and they fed.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: Thank you, God, for the good hearts of these people They said at the end, as they left.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: The words of gratitude were from dozens of Venezuelans, who arrived in Cúcuta due to the difficult situation in their country.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: They were addressed to a group of volunteers who every night, for several weeks now, come and offer them food, a small show of hospitality.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: The work we do is nonprofit.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: What we seek is to remember when Norte de Santander and the State of Táchira were one, the same family, assured Armando Abreu, binational lawyer, representative of the ColombianVenezuelan community and spokesperson for the group of motorcycle enthusiasts MAC, which is one of the of the groups that have dedicated themselves to the social work of giving food to homeless Venezuelans.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: It hurts us to see what our Venezuelan brothers and sisters go through and that is why in the MAC group we put a little on our part to collaborate with all the people who are in a state of need, added Abreu, while clarifying that the actions, more beyond that they were thought in favor of the colony of the neighboring country, they also shelter Colombians.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: Every night between 6 and 7 p.m. and until 10 or 11 p.m. m., MAC, as well as other citizen groups, visit different areas of the capital of Norte de Santander (including Santander Park, La Merced, La Parada) to fulfill the mission they set for themselves to give away food and waterEverything we give comes out of our pocket and collaborations with some private companies in the region.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: Likewise, private individuals participate, who do not necessarily belong to any association, Abreu pointed out.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: The lawyers intention is to be able to work together with the rest of the groups that are helping to define a schedule and thus not cross each other at the time of deliveries.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: In addition, with that they could assure the most needy a dinner every day of the week. Another of the objectives that they hope to fulfill, when they are fully organized, is to donate medicines.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: He says that the greatest satisfaction of this work is seeing the love and blessings they receive in return, the smiles of those who support them.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: We do this because most of us, if not all of the inhabitants of Cúcuta, have a relative or a good Venezuelan friend, the spokesman said.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: I, particularly, believe in that tithe tithing is giving food, not money, he added.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: And although it is not so clear at present, Abreu does believe that Colombia and Venezuela will once again be the allies they always were.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: I dare to say it Norte de Santander will be the most important port in the entire country, since it is the most important border, he concluded.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: Helping foreigners, authorities from Cúcuta and Norte de Santander have been meeting to design plans that allow them to lend a hand to all Venezuelans who are arriving in the region.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: For now, one of the ideas is to subsidize them, through the Transport Terminal, bus tickets to bring them closer to Ecuador and Peru, which are their destinations.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: Strong collaborations have come from the Diocese of Cúcuta and ordinary citizens.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: The religious organization has a temporary home in the village of La Parada, where Venezuelans can have free lunch, and also has a Migratory Center, where they receive citizens of the neighboring country for up to three days.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: For their part, several citizen organizations have come together to provide food and water to foreigners.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: They approach assembly points and make deliveries.

title: Colombians who provide food to Venezuelans in Cúcuta
text: It is worth noting that there is still no official program for Colombians to donate aid to Venezuelan citizens.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: President Juan Manuel Santos hardened this Tuesday the tone of his claim against Venezuela for the human rights violations suffered by Colombians expelled from that country and made it known that there will be a strong international offensive to denounce this situation before the world.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: In his speech, he revealed that the Attorney General of the Nation is considering taking the case to the International Criminal Court, with which he seeks to demonstrate possible systematic attacks on the civilian population.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: (The Prosecutor) informed me that  within the framework of his autonomy  he is seriously considering filing a complaint with the International Criminal Court against members of the civil and military leadership of the Venezuelan Government who could be responsible for crimes against humanity enshrined in the Rome Statute, said the Head of State.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: Santos added that his government will go to whatever international instance is necessary to safeguard the rights of affected Colombians.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: In this sense, he affirmed that Foreign Minister María Ángela Holguín will denounce the abuses before the IACHR.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: Similarly, before the UN, before the High Commissioner for Human Rights in Geneva and before the International Organization for Migration.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: Likewise, he said that this Wednesday there will be a council of ministers in Cúcuta, to which he will invite the diplomatic corps and representatives of international organizations, so that they can directly verify what is happening.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: In his speech, Santos assured that Colombia has respected the concept of democracy and the economic model of Venezuela, but clarified that one thing is that and another, very different, that the neighboring country violates the human rights of its citizens and what it is more serious for us  the rights of our compatriots who live on their soil.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: As he had already pointed out in previous days, Santos reiterated that Venezuelas right to close its border or expel people for security reasons does not give it the right to violate international law.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: The deportations cannot be massive or arbitrary, nor can the deportees be given inhumane treatment, added the Colombian president.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: In his speech he said that the neighboring country has violated all kinds of fundamental rights and dared to compare the Nazi ghettos with the marking with a D that the Venezuelan Guard made to the houses of Colombian families to demolish them.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: The property of the most humble has been confiscated, or they have been prevented from taking their few belongings.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: Families have been separated, separating children from their parents, because some are Venezuelans and others Colombians.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: It is a scenario of inhumanity and cruelty that we never imagined living in our region, he denounced.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: ON VOTING AT THE OASAfter the vote at the OAS on Tuesday, in which Colombia did not get enough votes to call a meeting of foreign ministers to discuss the issue, Santos was emphatic and criticized what happened.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: Unfortunately, ideology and monetary interests were stronger than humanitarian reasons.

title: Border crisis would be taken to the International Criminal Court _R
text: It is sad to see it, but it was like that, were his words from the Casa de Nariño.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: When approaching to process the respective permit, Venezuelans, spouses or permanent companions of Colombians who have returned, deported or expelled from Venezuela, must provide the following documents

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: The Ombudsman of Colombia, Jorge Armando Otálora, asked the InterAmerican Commission on Human Rights (IACHR) this Wednesday to decide as soon as possible the request for precautionary measures that have been presented by various instances of the Colombian State and with which it would seek to protect the rights of the inhabitants on the border with Venezuela.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: We are concerned about the humanitarian issue.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: We respect the autonomy and independence of the IACHR, but we advocate for a pronouncement as soon as possible because the violation of rights is being experienced today, it may increase tomorrow and the measures taken by the Venezuelan government that affect the Colombians, Otálora said at the end of his meeting with the IACHR on Wednesday in Washington.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: Otálora also extended an invitation to the commissioners to visit the area, but they have not yet confirmed whether they will travel to the country.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: Something that Luis Almagro did, Secretary General of the OAS, who will arrive in Cúcuta this Saturday.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: For his part, the Mayor of Cúcuta, Donamaris Ramírez, also met this Wednesday with IACHR personnel and requested the issuance of 16 precautionary measures to safeguard various rights that would be violated against Colombians at the border.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: The IACHR, a body that depends on the OAS but is independent, had already published a strong statement this past Friday in which it requested the immediate suspension of the collective deportations of Colombians from Venezuela and listed a series of human rights violations in which it would be incurring the government of Nicolás Maduro.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: Let them go, look and verify to be able to make a decision on the precautionary measures.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: (Precautionary Measure) so that they let 1,512 children pass to study, so that they allow all those who have goods to enter and pick them up, so that those who stayed with the children in Venezuela can meet, so that the workers and several more, Ramírez said.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: No one knows for sure if the IACHR will grant the precautionary measures and how long it might take to do so.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: Even if it does, it is unlikely that the Venezuelan government will heed them, it has already disregarded several that have been decreed in the past.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: The only body of the interAmerican system whose decisions are binding is the InterAmerican Court.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: But Venezuela, by renouncing the American Convention, left the Courts jurisdiction, although it remains under the umbrella of the OAS and the IACHR.

title: _It is urgent that the IACHR decree precautionary measures_ Ombudsman
text: Despite this, the governments strategy in carrying out these multiple requests is to expose Venezuelas violations and generate pressure, as it has already achieved with Almagros trip this Saturday and will achieve this if the IACHR adopts precautionary measures or sends a commission.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: SERGIO GÓMEZ MASERIEL TIEMPO correspondentWashingtonOn twitter sergom68

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: In a forum, the Dejusticia think tank promotes reflections on how the coronavirus pandemic affects the migrant population, which is already vulnerable.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: At the beginning of the talk, it was recalled that more than 1,700,000 Venezuelan migrants have entered Colombia.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: The reasons why the migrant population is more vulnerable were also recalled, for example, the fact that although the Colombian Law guarantees health care to migrants, this is only for emergency care, but it is not clear what it is. the health treatment that migrants have with chronic diseases and others.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: After some reflections, the political scientist Hugo Ramírez, director of the Migration and Borders Seedbed of the Universidad del Rosario, recalled that the migration crisis was not born with the coronavirus, but that fact puts migrants in a more vulnerable situation.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: For example, he said, most of the shelters and dining rooms that previously served the migrant population are now closed, in compliance with the governments quarantine order for the prevention of the coronavirus.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: The migratory crisis is not going to disappear with the emergency and not dealing with it could aggravate it even more, he said.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: He said that it is important not to remove from the aid channels local organizations that are very clear about the needs and organization of vulnerable communities.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: Regarding whether the closure of the borders, which is already in force in Colombia, is effective in controlling the pandemic, Ramírez expressed that he is not sure about it but that the borders, in practice, are not closed, people continue to pass through and trails continue to exist irregularities for which migrants seek help.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: Thus, given the porosity of the borders, the director recommended that other measures should be adopted to deal with the pandemic, which could be fulfilled more than a border closure.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: On the other hand, one of his reflections was that isolation is a privilege for many, since there are certain populations for which it is impossible to comply with quarantine, since they need to get things daily for their subsistence.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: Next, Carolina Moreno, from the legal clinic for migrants at the Universidad de los Andes, explained that the pandemic also has effects on migrants who live in cities.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: For example, there are issues of education of migrant children, which is affected, as well as the protection of due process, especially in migratory phases of expulsion.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: This week, he said, they have had cases of need to access health services, irregular immigration status makes it even more difficult to obtain care.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: In a crisis scenario like this, the rights of migrants compete with the rights of nationals, as the authorities have stated, they make them lower on the list of priorities, he said.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: And in terms of evictions and people with complications for subsistence, Moreno explained that the fact that most people are in their homes means that most migrants  who are in the informal sector  have problems making a living. , since they depend on what they achieve each day.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: He also explained that since everyone is at home, it is even more difficult for migrants to obtain a response from public authorities, for example, to continue with administrative processes such as the safeconduct of permanence.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: It depends on these safeconducts that migrants can stay in the country, so it is very important for them that the authorities do not stop these procedures.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: He also highlighted that for many migrants, isolation or even social distancing is impossible, since they can live in places that they share with many people, or even live on the street, so they cannot take those actions that the government promotes to prevent the coronavirus. .

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: Moreno also emphasized the need for coordination between the national and local governments to care for the migrant population, so that their rights are guaranteed.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: In third place, Ligia Bolívar, from Dejusticia, spoke about how the coronavirus is being experienced in Venezuela, as well as the situation of migrants in other countries.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: He indicated that in the neighboring country the governments strategy has been one of denial and repression of those who warn of risks from this pandemic.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: In a country where there is no water everywhere and a large population lives by the day, it is more difficult for them to take intensive hygiene measures, as well as preventive isolation, he said.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: Bolívar also spoke about the main reasons why people migrate, such as security, employment, access to health and food.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: For example, he said that some people leave their countries, even though they have a job, because what they earn is not enough to support their family.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: In Venezuela, for example, Bolívar said, the minimum wage is around 5 dollars.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: The expert also explained that just as there are migrants who arrive, there is a minimal amount that returns for reasons such as thinking that things will improve or that a friend or family who helped them in the past may do so again.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: But the vast majority of the migrant population remains outside their country, which is why, Bolívar said, the public policies of the countries must think about permanence and that these people are going to continue in the countries.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: As for other nations, he cited, for example, countries where there are threats of expulsion of suspected migrants due to coronavirus, as well as other people who are trapped due to the closure of borders.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: For the expert, it is worrying that among the measures of the Colombian government for the quarantine, there is, for example, the prohibition of eviction during the crisis, but specifically of Colombian families, which would exclude migrants.

title: This is how the coronavirus has affected migration in Colombia
text: He also spoke of positive measures that other countries have taken in the midst of the crisis, for example, specifying that the infected migrant population must be protected, among others.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: His permanence, he maintains, dismantles the fake news that there is a humanitarian crisis in Venezuela.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: This Tuesday, during the forum held by the Universidad del Rosario, the Konrad Adenauer Foundation and the United Nations on Venezuelan migration, the Foreign Minister of Colombia, Carlos Holmes Trujillo, assured that in the coming days the Government will be presenting a Conpes document that seeks to trace the public policy to address the crisis hitting the country.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: In addition, he assured that if the migratory flow registered between April and August 2018 continues, we will be forced to make budget readjustments in various sectors of the Government.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: The meeting took place at a time of tension between Bogotá and Caracas, after President Iván Duque led the drafting of a letter addressed to the International Criminal Court, along with five other leaders, in which they ask the authority to investigate alleged crimes against humanity committed by the regime of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: The foreign minister, during the event, indicated that the country is facing the Venezuelan exodus under three levels, one national, one regional and one multilateral.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: In that order of ideas, he said that they have made budgetary efforts, going out to nearby countries with the purpose of harmonizing efforts to order the crisis, as well as saying that he had knocked on the doors of the OAS, the United Nations, the InterAmerican Bank of Development and Colombias allied countries such as the United States to obtain resources.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: Holmes Trujillo mentioned that to date the country has received 936,000 Venezuelans, which makes this migration, in his words, the third largest in the world after those faced by Turkey and Lebanon, and the largest in the Latin American region. .

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: The Minister of Foreign Affairs revealed that the country manages three scenarios on migration a base scenario indicates that 2,166,000 Venezuelans will arrive in Colombia, an optimistic scenario speaks of 1,850,000 citizens of the neighboring country, while a pessimistic scenario speaks of more than four million Venezuelans who will arrive in the country.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: This is a magnitude that our country or our region had not experienced.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: If the registered rate of migrants is maintained, it is estimated that we will reach 4 million, he said.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: This will require additional money for education, health, work, among others.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: According to the foreign minister, by 2021, according to the different scenarios, the amount of the budget would vary, in the base scenario 12 billion pesos would be needed, in an optimistic one, 10 billion pesos and in a pessimistic one, up to 26 billion pesos.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: Faced with this reality, he said We are going to finetune our internal institutional capacity and we are going to make the necessary readjustments without sacrificing other priorities of the national budgets.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: Finally, the Foreign Minister said that the Government will act with the conviction that it is a challenge today, but if we act in an orderly and coordinated manner in the region, we will be building the opportunities that migratory phenomena have historically represented, he also recalled that in the coming days they will be presenting the route that the Duque Government will follow for the management of Venezuelan migration.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: The first to intervene in this forum was the rector in charge of the Universidad del Rosario, Stephanie Lavaux, who said that multilateral efforts are needed.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: For a country like Colombia, which has been characterized as an immigrant, becoming an immigration and transit country generates important challenges for society as a whole.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: Recent migration requires a multilateral effort.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: On this date, the Colombian State is faced with the possibility of guaranteeing that this migration is orderly, he said.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: For his part, Roberto Pombo, director of EL TIEMPO, stated that outbreaks of xenophobia should be avoided in the country.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: We are preparing to face a problem of the magnitude of the peace process we are experiencing and even higher.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: We can speak of a continental humanitarian tragedy that requires an enormous effort from the states, Pombo assured.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: Martín Santiago, UN resident coordinator in Colombia, agreed on this, but nevertheless stressed that Colombia is giving an example of humanity to the world due to the way in which it has received Venezuelan migrants and asked that the work in this sense is both of the entire region and also multilateral.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion
text: There was expectation to know the pronouncement of the United States ambassador to Colombia, Kevin Whitaker, who was tough on the Nicolás Maduro regime on the situation.

title: By 2021, care for Venezuelans could cost up to $26 billion

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.
text: Since last Friday, when the National Guard began the supposed census of Colombians in San Antonio del Táchira, Óscar Saín, 61, and his wife, Enerdina Mora, 60, decided to lock themselves up with their seven grandchildren in their house.

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.
text: They were hidden until Tuesday, when they no longer felt their neighbors, also nationals.

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.
text: Only at that moment did this man, who walks leaning on a cane, understand that in the invasion of My Little Barinas there had been a massive displacement, and, without giving it much thought, he picked up a few things and went out in search of one of the paths that leads to Colombia, after crossing the Táchira River.

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.
text: This fact brought to mind Óscar and Enerdina the memories of 10 years ago, when they had to leave Cucutilla (Norte de Santander), and ended up finding refuge in San Antonio.

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.
text: All because the guerrillas were bothered that two of his sons were in the Army.

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.
text: But after arriving in Venezuela, he says, his perpetrators were members of the National Guard, because they were Colombians.

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.
text: Its one thing to tell about it and another to see it, but Ill never be able to explain what were experiencing, adds Óscar, who due to his age and his health conditions does not plan to return to his farm, on whose land he planted yucca and corn.

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.
text: Stories like that of the Saín Mora, who left the country fleeing the violence generated by illegal armed groups, are among the hundreds deported by Venezuela in the last week.

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.
text: Carrillo, a native of Lebanon (Tolima), was displaced by the FARC, for which she sought asylum in Venezuela.

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.

title: The families that relive the drama of displacement.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: Everything you should know about Venezuelan migration and they havent told you is the title of the most recent report released by Migración Colombia.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: In the document you can find the most uptodate figures on the citizens of the neighboring country who have arrived in the country, the history of Venezuelan migrants who have arrived in Colombia, population data with a vocation to stay, statistics by department, among others.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: These are some of the data that this report revealed.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: This is the most common doubt among organizations, government entities, locals and the civil population.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: According to the document, in Colombia until September 2018 there were 1,032,016 Venezuelans.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: Of these, 573,502 are regular, that is, they have a visa, foreigner identification card, Special Permanence Permit (PEP) or are in the country within the established legal time. Another 240,416 are in the process of regularization.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: This means that they were registered in the Administrative Registry of Venezuelan Migrants (RAMV) and are in the process of issuing the PEP.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: Among the irregular population, 137,718 Venezuelans exceeded the length of stay given by law (that is, 180 days) and 80,380 entered through unauthorized steps.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: It is important to clarify that this figure does not mean that 1,032,016 Venezuelans have entered the country in the last three years.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: That figure corresponds to those who are based in the country as of September.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: The largest increase in Venezuelans living in Colombia, according to the report, occurred in the last two years, where the figure increased from 39,311 in 2016 to 184,087 in 2017 and 769,726 in 2018.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: These figures coincide with the years in which the sociopolitical crisis in the neighboring country worsened with the arrival to the presidency of Nicolás Maduro, successor of Hugo Chávez.
