text: How many Venezuelans are there in my department

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: Unquestionably Bogotá is the city with the largest number of settled Venezuelans.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: It is followed by Norte de Santander, precisely the neighboring department, with 151,803, and third place is held by La Guajira, another border point, with 123,756.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: The Special Permanence Permit (PEP) is one of the migratory measures implemented by the Colombian Government to help Venezuelans who are within the national territory and who seek to remain there.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: This document allows them to stay in the country on a regular basis for 90 days, extendable up to a maximum of 2 years.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: The Venezuelan citizen beneficiary of the PEP is authorized to exercise any activity or legal occupation in the country that is not Regulated, including those that are carried out by virtue of a relationship or employment contract.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: It is not an identification document, it is a tool of the National Government to regularize the permanence of the Venezuelan citizen in the Republic of Colombia.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: It is not valid as a travel document for entering or leaving the national territory and does not replace the passport, affirms Migración Colombia.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: Once this term is over, the Venezuelan citizen must have processed a visa before the Foreign Ministry or leave the country, since otherwise they will incur irregular stay.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: As of September, 415,298 Venezuelan citizens have the PEP and 240,416 are in the process of being issued.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: Of that total, 220,276 are men and 194,847 are women.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: Remember that the PEP can claim it until December 2The days are running out for Venezuelans who made the Administrative Registry of Venezuelan Migrants (RAMV) to claim the Special Permanence Permit (PEP), a document issued by the Government of Colombia and that allows them to be in the country for two years of legal way.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: In addition, it grants you permission to study or carry out a legal activity in the country and join the health system.

title: In figures everything you need to know about Venezuelan migration
text: Although the deadline to claim the PEP expires next Sunday, December 2, more than 180,000 Venezuelans of the 442,462 registered have not done so.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: We are working on protocols so that, if this opening occurs, it is safe to avoid a resurgence associated with Venezuelan migration.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: María Helena and her mother were one of the many walkers who crossed the land border between Colombia and Venezuela in search of a better future.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: His goal was clear to meet María Helenas father, a truck driver who remained working in Colombian territory.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: This story is what sets the primer Lets be panarceros, which offers paths for peaceful coexistence between Colombian and Venezuelan students and which was developed by the Study Group on International Migration and Vulnerability (GEMIV), of the Faculty of Sociology of the Santo Tomás University the SI Borders program of GIZ, German cooperation the Open Anthropology Laboratory, the District Association of Education Workers (ADE) and the IberoAmerican Research Network on Imaginaries and Representations (RIIR).

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: The idea of Seamos panarceros was born under the protection of a research project approved by the General Academic Vice President of the Santo Tomás University, which was developed throughout 2019.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: This sought to observe the integration of Venezuelan students in schools in Bogotá and in Cúcuta, in addition to finding the imaginaries about this integration, explains sociology professor Felipe Aliaga Sáez, coordinator of the Diploma in Social Research of International Migrations of the Santo Tomás University. and one of the developers of the primer.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: The objective of the project was to identify these stories and experiences within educational institutions, for which they carried out field work in establishments in both cities.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: This consisted of 20 focus groups with 61 Venezuelan students, 81 Colombian students, and 28 teachers.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: The work allowed us to identify some variables about the integration and needs of the students to develop a series of dialogues around migrations in the school environment, Aliaga comments.The schools selected for the field work contacted them through the Scalabrinian Mission, in Cúcuta, and the ADE, in Bogotá, and during their dialogue with students and teachers they identified some problematic points that they decided to attack from pedagogical material that would broaden the perspectives about the migratory phenomenon.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: That was the first step for the creation of Seamos panarceros.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: According to Professor Aliaga, one of the findings that most caught their attention was that Venezuelan students did not express themselves freely about their immigration status due to fear of questioning.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: We also identified some cases of harassment within the school and relationships in which the students felt harassed or singled out for the conditions that Venezuelan sex workers may have.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: Precisely, this is one of the reasons why the protagonist of the booklet is a girl, María Helena We wanted to highlight the figure of this feminization of migrations because today we have a high percentage of women who migrate from Venezuela to Colombia but this not only happens in this migratory corridor, but also happens around the world.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: A high proportion of women are those who are migrating, almost reaching 50, says the teacher.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: The story of the primer continues when María Helena is reunited with her father and stays with him and her mother in Cúcuta.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: There she meets Samuel, a Colombian boy younger than her who quickly becomes her best friend.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: Together they begin to explore the meanings of crossing from one country to another, what a border is, and what both Venezuela and Colombia have in common.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: We created a rapprochement that is generated among the students at the level from what in the Theory of Migrations, in terms of integration, we could call the understanding of the different actors, that is, understanding the reality that the other is facing, their trajectories of life, their traumatic experiences, their pain, their fears, explains Aliaga.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: The elements to create empathy and that feeling of being able to put oneself in the others shoes can be found throughout the primer the idea of the territorial union of both countries through the history of Gran Colombia, the exaltation of cultural elements shared or that distinguish one society from another, and also the contribution that migrants offer to the diversity of countries.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: Everything from an approach to the border.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: The most important thing was to break down those stereotypes that affect the collective imagination of Colombian students.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: Among these entrenched images, the research group identified that they had to do especially with the issue of violence.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: There are some cases of delinquency or criminality that intensify a negative imaginary around the Venezuelan population, even if they are very specific circumstances and very insignificant cases, explains the professor.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: The positive and brotherhood messages that exist in Seamos Panarceros seek to fight against the manifestations of intolerance that exist in schools leveraged by these negative stereotypes, mostly expressed through ridicule or harassment.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: According to Aliaga, thanks to the indepth bibliographical review we did for the project, we identified that in IberoAmerica there are cases of xenophobia in the school environment, intolerance and rejection.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: We knew that by doing a very collaborative work between teachers, parents and students, that is, the academic community, it is possible to achieve an improvement in the relationships and in the interaction between its different actors.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: This is what we have called peaceful coexistence.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: Hence, the booklet focuses on the story of María Helena.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela
text: The team wanted to include a story that would connect students and serve as a contrast between the different migratory experiences of those who cross borders and even migrate within countries.

title: 'Panarceros' the booklet that integrates children from Colombia and Venezuela

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: Coal producers in Norte de Santander, affected by the border closure, have not been able to export the mineral so far this month.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: This despite the package of measures promoted by the Government with the declaration of the economic emergency on the border, which includes a reduction in toll rates and lower fuel prices.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: Before, the producers had the capacity to move about 6,000 tons of coal per day.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: To complete the loading of a ship for export, between 28,000 and 30,000 tons are needed.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: Before the closure, in five days the businessmen could complete the loading of a ship to export and now that the distances between the mines and the ports are greater, they are moving about 900 tons by land to Gamarra (port on the Magdalena River), Santa Marta and Barranquilla.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: In addition, last Saturday the first 4,000 tons of coal arrived in the Atlantic capital by river from the border department.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: Approximately, in the 20 days that the port of Maracaibo has been closed for Colombian coal, it has only been possible to consolidate a cargo of less than 11,000 tons.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: Today the exporter has not had a way to return, said the president of Asocarbón (the association of producers of this mineral in Norte de Santander), Jaime Rodríguez.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: One of the possible solutions for this situation is the mobilization of coal through the Fenoco railway.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: For this, the Government issued decree 1802 that authorized (against a restriction of the Constitutional Court) the night transit of the coal train, to mobilize the production of Norte de Santander.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: But despite the fact that the Minister of Transport, Natalia Abello, assured that the idea was that the coal would begin to be transported from last week, the reality is that, until now, it has not been possible to send the first load by this means.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: The reason the decree specifies that only coal from Norte de Santander can be transported at night, which would imply mobilizing a train, which can carry up to 150 wagons, with only ten loaded wagons.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: This would represent losses for the operation.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: Ideally, the train operators could add their operation to ours, to generate the economies of scale that are needed so that it can be profitable for everyone, Rodríguez explained.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: For Drummond, one of Fenocos partners, it is necessary that in the midst of the emergency decree it is allowed to transport coal not only from Norte de Santander, but also from Cesar, this, they consider, would make the operation viable.

title: Norte de Santander does not export coal since border closure
text: Drummond hopes that Asocarbón will present a proposal on the conditions under which it could move North Santander coal, so that with technical elements the government can be asked to modify the emergency decrees.

title: Without health and education, some of the barriers of stateless children
text: Barriers to access to health and education are some of the difficulties currently faced by Venezuelan children who were born in Colombia and who, due to the conditions in their country, do not have documents to be certified with one of the two nationalities.

title: Without health and education, some of the barriers of stateless children
text: Those children, at risk of statelessness, will be nationalized as Colombians and will be able to access more basic services such as health and education.

title: Without health and education, some of the barriers of stateless children
text: This was explained by Felipe Cortés, Coordinator of the Special Group for Migrant Children at the Colombian Institute of Family Welfare (Icbf), who gave an overview of the situation of Venezuelan children and adolescents born in Colombia and what will happen to them in the future. when they obtain their Colombian nationality.

title: Without health and education, some of the barriers of stateless children
text: What is currently happening with Venezuelan children born in Colombia

title: Without health and education, some of the barriers of stateless children
text: Currently, children are not nationals by the mere fact of being born in Colombian territory, since the parents are foreigners and must be domiciled.

title: Without health and education, some of the barriers of stateless children
text: Due to the foregoing, an entry is included in their civil registry indicating that they do not prove nationality.

text: This limits their access to basic social services that mitigate the critical situation of vulnerability with which their families arrive.

title: Without health and education, some of the barriers of stateless children
text: The measure comes into effect from August 20 and is temporary.

text: The measure will be for two years and at that time it will be reviewed if the situation in Venezuela is better and if the children can get their documents for nationality in their country.

text: Depending on that, it is decided whether the measure is extended or not.

text: Overcome the obstacles that parents have today to access the civil registry as nationals.

title: Without health and education, some of the barriers of stateless children

title: Avalanche of Venezuelans in search of health services in Cartagena_R
text: In the first half of the year, the district health administrative department of Cartagena, Dadis, has received more than 111 Venezuelan patients, of which 60 percent have been pregnant women who arrive in the last trimester of pregnancy and without prior examinations. .

title: Avalanche of Venezuelans in search of health services in Cartagena_R
text: There are highcost patients, with cases of HIV and tuberculosis, whose care today is assumed entirely by the District of Cartagena, says the health entity.

title: Avalanche of Venezuelans in search of health services in Cartagena_R
text: These are Venezuelan citizens who, fleeing from the social crisis that hits this nation, illegally arrive in the heroic city by road, after escaping by trails, to settle in Cartagena.

title: Avalanche of Venezuelans in search of health services in Cartagena_R
text: We have had an increase in consultations for services from Venezuelan patients, or children of Venezuelans or children of Colombians born in Venezuela who came to live in Cartagena.

title: Avalanche of Venezuelans in search of health services in Cartagena_R
text: So far this year we have provided 11 1 patients for outpatient services, and we have provided 86 million pesos for the care of patients of this nationality, without adding the patients who have had to be hospitalized to safeguard their lives, explained the doctor Adriana Meza, director of Dadis.

title: Avalanche of Venezuelans in search of health services in Cartagena_R
text: According to the official, work tables have already been held with Migration Colombia, and consultations with the Foreign Ministry, the National Superintendence of Health and the National Ministry of Health.

title: Avalanche of Venezuelans in search of health services in Cartagena_R
text: Although the National Constitution says that they have the same rights as any Colombian citizen and we as a health entity cannot allow a patient to die or have complications, these are resources that are specifically assigned for Colombians and in the specific case for Cartagena. , added the official.

title: Avalanche of Venezuelans in search of health services in Cartagena_R
text: The fourth floor of the Hospital Universitario de Cartagena today houses some of the most delicate cases.

title: Avalanche of Venezuelans in search of health services in Cartagena_R
text: If they arrived in Colombia legally, they would present an alien identification card or passport, but since they enter the country illegally, they only present a Venezuelan identity card.

title: Avalanche of Venezuelans in search of health services in Cartagena_R
text: In addition, in the case of pregnant women, they arrive in the last months for urgent care so, respecting our Constitution and profession, we do not hesitate to pay attention, assured Alberto Soto, operational director of Dadis insurance, who maintains that the majority of Venezuelan citizens are entering illegally by road and not by air.

title: Avalanche of Venezuelans in search of health services in Cartagena_R

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: We have nothing to help those who have historically been living in the city, much less will we be able to help that crisis.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: At the age of 16, Rosa María became a mother and a couple of months later she became pregnant again, but since she is a girl, her 65yearold mother, who also has 10 little ones, had to assume the responsibility of feeding two mouths. plus.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: Rosa Marías children today are 2 and 3 years old, but because of their size they look like they were one year old they eat what the old woman and her husband, also elderly, manage to catch in the sea.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: However, the little they take to the ranchería is to share it among all with some rice that comes from Maicao and that due to border restrictions they buy more expensively.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: The case of the children of Rosa María, who lives in a ranchería in the Tolima sector, in Uribia, is that of thousands of Wayú children who, in addition to being in the care of their grandparents or other relatives, suffer from malnutrition, a situation that It has been aggravated, among other things, by the almost three years of drought and the food shortages that the neighboring country is experiencing and that they no longer freely enter Colombia.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: La Guajira is, according to the National Institute of Health, the department with the most cases of malnourished children.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: As of May 30, 94 deaths from this cause were reported in the country, of which 11 correspond to the peninsula, where last year there were 48 cases.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: According to the regional office of the Colombian Family Welfare Institute (ICBF), 39,000 children under 5 years of age are reported to be malnourished in that department, of whom 90 percent are indigenous.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: Based on these figures, in his recent visit to Riohacha, President Juan Manuel Santos drew attention to the worrying situation of the children of La Guajira and asked the ICBF for a reliable census that allows for the identification of children with malnutrition and the measurement of how many benefit from their programs.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: However, Santos denied versions that indicate that 5,000 peasant children have died in eight years due to malnutrition.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: And although deaths are not as many as has been speculated, there are even more deaths from associated causes, such as diarrhea, respiratory diseases, perinatal (before birth) and maternal mortality, the number of deaths from malnutrition is still worrying.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: A recent report from the Departmental Health Secretariat accounts for 68 children who died in 2015 from other causes.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: But what exacerbates the poor nutrition of Wayú children, mainly in upper and middle Guajira, where an estimated 300,000 natives live, is the prolonged drought, which has meant that in these dusty lands only cacti and trupillos and small herds of goats.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: Nidia Romero, director of the ICBF regional office, says that the drought has led to the jagüeyes drying up and to the indigenous people no longer being able to have their orchards, where they grew beans, corn and squash.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: In addition, explains the researcher and indigenous leader Margarita Pimienta, the Wayú used to have large amounts of cattle and goats, but now that is impossible, many animals have died and the one that has the most does not exceed 4 or 5 cattle and 50 goats. .

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: Another factor that affects the shortage and the consequent malnutrition of the population, not only children but also adults, is the closure of the Venezuelan border for the passage of products from the neighboring country to Colombia.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: Our indigenous people used to buy food there at a lower price for their consumption and to market, but now they say that they cant do it even if they have the money, said Romero.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: Wayú teacher and leader Sonia Barliza agrees with this opinion, saying that rice, oil, sugar and flour used to come through Maicao and they were cheap, but now little happens and what is obtained is expensive.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: Thats why its also famine.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: Barliza, who lives in Puerto Estrella, in upper Guajira, cites, for example, that a bale of flour (20 kilos) used to cost 22,000 pesos, but now it is worth 60,000 pesos.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: This situation has led to the fact that the food that the ICBF provides for the children ends up being consumed by all the members of the families.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: Not only children under 5 years of age consume them, whose nutritional status is very serious, but also siblings and adults, insists the regional director of the institute.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: To this situation, the mayor of Uribia, Abel Giacometto, adds the return of Wayús.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: He assures that his municipality is the main recipient of indigenous people who, in the face of the Venezuelan crisis, decided to return to the country.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira
text: Giacometto estimates that in Uribia there are 25,000 families scattered in the desert and that locating them and providing solutions to each one is not easy, especially when there are no roads and the distances between one settlement and another can be enormous.

title: Venezuelan closure aggravates the malnutrition situation in La Guajira

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: Think, for example, of the Venezuelan women and men with cancer, who had to come from their country because the lack of medication means the progression of a deadly disease and they need frequent chemotherapy or radiotherapy sessions, even if they are not urgent.

text: And, even if they are not sick, imagine pregnant women, who must access prenatal checkups to know the evolution of their baby.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: To understand the magnitude of this reality, we can take the information collected by the Administrative Registry of Venezuelan Migrants (RAMV), which consolidated the information of 442,462 Venezuelans who entered the country irregularly and voluntarily took part in the survey between April and June of this year.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: Of these, only 4,945 (slightly more than 1) are affiliated with the health system.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: In addition, 16,817 (almost 4) have chronic diseases, such as hypertension, diabetes and cancer and there are 8,209 pregnant women, of whom 6,304 (77) have not had prenatal checkups.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: It is undeniable that attending to the different needs of these migrants in an irregular situation (and those that the RAMV did not take into account) implies a cost.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: Fedesarrollo recently published a study in which it estimates that, by the end of 2018, Colombia will have allocated up to 4 billion pesos to pay attention to the basic needs of Venezuelans, 0.42 of GDP.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: But what this figure does not show is how much Colombia could save if it provided health care beyond the emergency room, assuming that the political, economic and social crisis that Venezuela is going through and that is generating this exodus does not seem to be going to be resolved soonAlthough there are no known studies that estimate this costbenefit ratio of health care in Colombia, we can have an indication using the experiences of other countries, which have spent years responding to the arrival of migrants and refugees in their territories.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: For example, in Germany, health expenditures were studied for two groups of refugees some with and others without full access to health.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: The research found that spending per capita (that is, per person) on health was 40 higher in the group with limited access.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: In fact, it meant 375.8 euros per capita per year for each of the refugees with limited access to health services.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: In other words, limiting access to health cost the system almost 400 euros per refugee.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: The study supports with empirical evidence the argument that, in the long term, providing access to health only in emergencies only increases costs.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: This is intuitive, since excluding people from regular access to health does not promote early detection or treatment of preventable conditions.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: There are several investigations that analyze the costbenefit of providing health care to migrants, without it being an emergency.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: Findings are known in the treatment of hypertension, hepatitis B and HIV.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: In the first case, a study by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights analyzed the costs and benefits of providing access to health services to hypertensive migrants in an irregular situation in Germany, Greece and Switzerland.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: The results show that providing this care is costeffective and saves 83 euros, 66 euros and 84 euros per migrant, depending on each country.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: Faced with hepatitis B, the findings of the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment in the Netherlands showed that its early detection and treatment can have a great impact on health, making it costeffective to allow migrants access to Xrays Screening for infections.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: Regarding HIV, antiretroviral treatment significantly reduces HIV transmission and associated costs, thus reducing the number of hospitalizations, among others.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: For example, a study of 10 medical centers in France, conducted by researchers at the Center de Tourcoing hospital, found that early access to highly active antiretroviral therapy reduced hospitalizations by 41, new HIV cases by 41, and deaths in 69.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: In fact, the study concludes that in all cases early access cost less than late access.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: But in addition to the costs of not treating disease, you have to think about the costs of not following pregnant women.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: To measure the costeffectiveness of access to prenatal care, the cost in Germany, Greece and Switzerland was compared for all migrant women in an irregular situation to have access to prenatal care versus the costs of the year after childbirth due to possible consequences of low weight at birth.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: The researchers concluded that doing the controls can save, respectively, 56, 52 and 177 euros per woman for two years.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: In addition, a study at the University of California concluded that eliminating the use of public resources for prenatal care for undocumented women could save the State 58 million dollars, but would cost up to 194 million more in postnatal care due to the consequences of low birth weight. birth and premature births.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: The evidence from other countries shows that in Colombia it is necessary to analyze the longterm costs that arise from denying access to health to migrants in an irregular situation today.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: As long as the Government does not take action on this issue, guardianships will continue to be a mechanism for accessing health services.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: Although it might seem that it is not urgent to create policies to deal with this problem, since Venezuelans could simply join the health system, it is necessary to analyze the existing options to do so.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: Currently, a Venezuelan has three options having entered Colombia regularly with a passport and having a visa that authorizes him to work in the country having applied for the special residence permit (PEP) for which he should also have entered with a passport or having responded to the RAMV with which he could also access the PEP.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: All this is a complex picture.

title: How much does it cost Colombia not to attend to the health of Venezuelans
text: But the arrival of Venezuelans is a reality against which intelligent measures must be taken.

title: New decree to facilitate the sale of border coal_R_
text: Currently, private ports such as Drummond and Río Córdoba (of Colombian Natural Resources, CNR), are not authorized to load this coal.

title: New decree to facilitate the sale of border coal_R_
text: That (the decree) ends up complementing the legal and legal framework that we needed, but it is subject to the existence of commercial agreements that allow the use of those benefits.

title: New decree to facilitate the sale of border coal_R_
text: We are in a costing and market evaluation analysis, there is still no definitive closure, said Jaime Rodríguez, spokesman for Asocarbón, the producers association of Norte de Santander.

title: New decree to facilitate the sale of border coal_R_
text: In the case of the previous decree, which unblocked the night traffic of the Fenoco railway to move coal from Norte de Santander, there has been no agreement between the regional producers and Drummond, regarding the price, for this reason, the intention of the norm has not materialized.

title: New decree to facilitate the sale of border coal_R_
text: Rodríguez assures that, in any case, there is optimism that in about three months around 60,000 tons of coal per month will be mobilized, that is, half of what was transported before the crisis.

title: Shelters in Cúcuta, close to the border, have already been evacuated _R
text: After more than four months of closure of the ColombianVenezuelan border, the Colombian authorities reported that the shelters in Cúcuta were completely evacuated and that some 6,000 returnees from Venezuela have already settled in the interior of the country.

title: Shelters in Cúcuta, close to the border, have already been evacuated _R
text: The data was given by Víctor Bautista, advisor to the Chancellors office in charge of border issues with Venezuela.

title: Shelters in Cúcuta, close to the border, have already been evacuated _R
text: There is not a single shelter, there is not a single person of the deportees or voluntary returnees who is in them, said Bautista.

title: Shelters in Cúcuta, close to the border, have already been evacuated _R
text: The balance of the Colombian authorities was given at the end of 2015, a year in which the country had to receive some 20,000 compatriots returned from Venezuela, some deported and others who returned voluntarily.

title: Shelters in Cúcuta, close to the border, have already been evacuated _R
text: This exodus occurred after the order of the government of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro to close the border crossing on August 20.

title: Shelters in Cúcuta, close to the border, have already been evacuated _R
text: His decision was due, he said, to an alleged presence of Colombian paramilitary groups on the border, which would be generating insecurity in the area.

title: Shelters in Cúcuta, close to the border, have already been evacuated _R

title: Shelters in Cúcuta, close to the border, have already been evacuated _R

title: Shelters in Cúcuta, close to the border, have already been evacuated _R

title: Shelters in Cúcuta, close to the border, have already been evacuated _R

title: Shelters in Cúcuta, close to the border, have already been evacuated _R

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: Federica Mogherini, high representative of the Common Foreign and Security Policy of the European Union (EU), announced this Thursday that Colombia will receive 30 million dollars to support the care of Venezuelan migrants who have arrived in the country fleeing from the complex economic crisis and social life in your country.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: The senior diplomat explained that this support will be focused on the prevention of xenophobia, exploitation and trafficking of migrants, as well as the development of job placement and identification programs for this population.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: Mogherini recalled that the European Union has previously provided 130 million euros to deal with the crisis.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: I am very surprised by the attention that Colombia has given to Venezuelan migrants, this is one of the countries that has received the most migrants in the world and economic support has been little, said Mogherini.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: In his speech, President Iván Duque thanked the support of the European Union and assured that attention to the Venezuelan crisis is a global phenomenon.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: This is about a coordinated and clear action of the region, the crisis generated by the regime of Nicolás Maduro requires global attention, said Duque.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: Precisely, the head of state revealed that next October a conference will be held in Brussels (Belgium, headquarters of the European Union, in which the issue of the Venezuelan crisis will be discussed.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: Colombia will continue to go to all multilateral bodies to present what is happening in Venezuela, said the president.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: Mogherini and Duque also spoke about what happened with the group of FARC dissidents, led by Iván Márquez, who decided to return to arms.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: We have strongly condemned the announcement of a small group of the FARC to return to arms.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: But you cant forget that they are just that, a small group, most of them are complying with the agreement, Mogherini said.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: As part of her agenda in Colombia, the senior European official will meet with young people from the Escuela Taller de Bogotá, who are people in vulnerable conditions who receive training in trades such as construction, carpentry, cooking and tourist guide.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: The idea with this institution is that in the future, with the support of the European Union, former FARC guerrillas can access these trainings.

title: European Union announces 30 million euros for Venezuelan migrants
text: Mogherinis agenda in the country will end in a meeting with the heads of some of the instances that were created from the peace accords between the FARC guerrillas and the government of Juan Manuel Santos.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: Rosalba Duarte Sánchez is a 35yearold Venezuelan who graduated with a degree in environmental management, in San Cristóbal, border state of Táchira, but works as a street vendor on the Colombian side of the border with Venezuela rampant unemployment and the economic situation of his country have prevented him from practicing his profession.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: At noon, when the heat intensifies amid the pilgrimage of people who gather in the La Parada sector, a few meters from the Simón Bolívar International Bridge (between the Venezuelan population of San Antonio and the municipality of Villa del Rosario, in North de Santander), Rosalba, accompanied by her three daughters, stands in line outside an old house, where the Catholic Church adapted a temporary home to feed the Venezuelans who arrive at the site.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: This initiative was conceived within the walls of the San Antonio de Padua parish, located in the center of Cúcuta, where the Archdioceses Social Ministry opened a communal dining room every day for foreigners, like Rosalba and her little ones, but seeing that the flow of people in need of a plate of food increased, the clerics decided to rent a building with a vacant lot, 1,500 square meters in the back, in the middle of the border with Venezuela.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: This started very recently and discreetly, with the support of Father David Cañas and the apostolic movements of Cúcuta.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: (.) The people who come here are very diverse, they are people who come to the national territory to buy rice, oil, sugar and the minimum elements of subsistence.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: There are also poor people, workers, middle class people, who sometimes come from Caracas to buy medicine and return.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: This house is a small consolation for these Venezuelans, we give them a glass of fresh water, a coffee and a plate of hot food, said Monsignor Víctor Manuel Ochoa Cadavid, bishop of Cúcuta.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: In the mornings, those in charge of the shelter distribute about 600 tokens to citizens of the neighboring country, however, the number of rations they deliver daily exceeds that figure in one day they have managed to distribute up to 2,000 lunches on the 70 plastic tables and cement dining rooms that young volunteers organize to locate people.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: The menu that is prepared there is diverse from a plate of rice with chicken accompanied by a slice of bread, to a soup of trifles.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: The foods used in the preparation are products donated by faithful Catholics from the North Santander capital.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: We are very grateful for this attention that our Colombian brothers do on a daily basis.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: On the other side of the border we live with hunger, in the midst of terrible unemployment and the only thing I can find a job is as a street vendor.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: The little I get sometimes is not enough to eat and that is why we come here, to receive this aid, said Rosalba Duarte, a beneficiary of this soup kitchen.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: Women like her and children like her three daughters make up the most vulnerable demographic segment of the migratory phenomenon that originates in Norte de Santander the daily flow of 45,000 people between Colombia and Venezuela, according to a migratory profile prepared by the International Organization for Migration (IOM). and the Colombian Foreign Ministry.

title: This is 'Divina Providencia', the only humanitarian shelter on the border
text: Despite this alarming indicator, the Divina Providencia home is the only space in this border area where foreigners can alleviate their food needs, in a calm and friendly environment.

title: More than 1,000 undocumented immigrants have had to return to Venezuela
text: More than 1,000 Venezuelans have been taken to the Simón Bolívar international bridge, on the border between Colombia and Venezuela, who due to their undocumented status have had to leave the city of Cúcuta in recent months and return to their place of origin.

title: More than 1,000 undocumented immigrants have had to return to Venezuela
text: These transfers, which take place on board buses and with the support of Colombian Migration and the National Police, derive from the constant operations to recover public space carried out since the beginning of this year by the citys Mayors Office.

title: More than 1,000 undocumented immigrants have had to return to Venezuela
text: The first procedure with a large number of these migrants in an irregular situation took place days after the eviction from the sports center in the Sevilla neighborhood, where the foreigners set up a refugee camp with tents, mattresses and boxes that was called Hotel Caracas.

title: More than 1,000 undocumented immigrants have had to return to Venezuela
text: This has been an interinstitutional effort to recover and return order to public space.

title: More than 1,000 undocumented immigrants have had to return to Venezuela
text: The streets remained invaded, but with this procedure we were able to identify many people without proper documentation who had to return to their country.

title: More than 1,000 undocumented immigrants have had to return to Venezuela
text: They have been procedures that have been carried out peacefully and without clashes with the authority, explained Mauricio Franco, Secretary of Citizen Security of Cúcuta.

title: More than 1,000 undocumented immigrants have had to return to Venezuela
text: The official added that these operations are going to intensify with the operation of the Special Migratory Group (GEM), which was announced by President Juan Manuel Santos last week.

title: More than 1,000 undocumented immigrants have had to return to Venezuela
text: Officials from the Police, Colombian Migration, the Colombian Institute of Family Welfare (Icbf) and Dian will be linked to this new unit.

title: More than 1,000 undocumented immigrants have had to return to Venezuela
text: Meanwhile, according to Migración Colombia, in the first week of new controls on the dividing line, they have seized about 15 Border Mobility Cards that were fraudulently carried.

title: More than 1,000 undocumented immigrants have had to return to Venezuela
text: As far as the Simón Bolívar bridge, which connects Villa del Rosario with San Antonio del Táchira, nationals from the neighboring country have also been transferred who have been surprised in other regions of the country in an irregular migratory condition.

title: More than 1,000 undocumented immigrants have had to return to Venezuela
text: Last weekend, 50 Venezuelans who were transiting to Bucaramanga in public transport vehicles were approached by members of Migración Colombia, the Army and the Police who were at the pilot random migration control post that was installed in the district of Berlin, in Tona (Santander), bordering area with Norte de Santander.

title: More than 1,000 undocumented immigrants have had to return to Venezuela
text: The foreigners were returned to the border for not having the documents required to be in Colombian territory.

title: Everything ready for the transfer of Venezuelan migrants from the terminal
text: While the Venezuelans, due to the exchange rate differential (a bolívar was worth 0.0042 pesos yesterday), stopped coming to Cúcuta.

text: In addition, the decree exempts those affected from paying the military compensation fee, the sanction for nonregistration and the issuance of the reservist card, and allows the free delivery of the duplicate of the reservist card for those who have lost it.

title: Colombia and the US want a better future for Venezuelans Pompeo
text: The Secretary of State of the United States, Mike Pompeo, stated from the warehouses where humanitarian aid for Venezuela is stored, near the Tienditas border bridge, that Venezuelans who cross the border looking for better conditions because they have no other option.

text: Colombia and the United States want a better future for Venezuelans, Pompeo said.

title: Colombia and the US want a better future for Venezuelans Pompeo
text: This was the reception of SecPompeo together with the president IvanDuque in Cúcuta.

title: Colombia and the US want a better future for Venezuelans Pompeo
